title: Junk in the Trunk
subTitle: Don't forget to look in back when you shop for a vehicle!  7 cool uses of the rear compartment.
promoTeaserSmall: Don't forget to look in back when you shop for a vehicle!  7 cool uses of the rear compartment.
promoTeaser: Don't forget to look in back when you shop for a vehicle!  7 cool uses of the rear compartment.
metaDescription: Don't forget to look in back when you shop for a vehicle!  7 cool uses of the rear compartment.

pageElements.text: The Chicago Auto Show is, in large part, a truck show. The City of the Big Shoulders is an excellent place to ogle some of the biggest, baddest, most versatile vehicles that we will soon see in showrooms and on the road—as well as a few we may only see here. We couldn't resist making a list of the seven most intriguing uses of all that extra space.

1. 2016 Ford Explorer BraunAbility MXV

Ford is touting this as the world's first wheelchair-accessible SUV. A choice beyond vans for the wheelchair user? Brilliant. This is no mere show display; BraunAbility is putting it into production, and you'll be able to buy one, with base, XLT, and Limited versions of the Explorer on offer. All of them get the power ramp with in-floor lighting, removable driver and passenger seats, and sliding door technology that's been patented.
Not an Explorer in name or looks only, it has the standard Explorer 3.5-liter V-6, gets 17 mpg city and 24 mpg on the highway, and can tow up to 5,000 pounds.

The interior height of the BraunAbility MXV is a very wheelchair-friendly 59 inches in the front seats, 58 inches in the center of the vehicle. The side door opens 55 inches high, and the ramp has 28.5 inches of usable width. In practical terms, that means the wheelchair user can be the one to drive the vehicle or be a passenger.
The BraunAbility plant in Winamac, Indiana, will be supplying this wonder to more than 200 of its dealers around the United States.

2. 2016 GMC Acadia

A heavy rubberized plastic cover, with a waffle-pattern texture, sits in the rear cargo area of this SUV. The cool thing: When you recline the third row of seats, this cover accordions out to cover the back of those, too. It doesn't lie quite flat, or didn't in the Chicago Auto Show model we looked at, but we're guessing it will fall into line quickly in everyday use.

3. 2016 Ford Transit Connect Titanium

Ford's William Mattiace steered us to this compact utility vehicle, describing the in-headliner storage as "airplane style." Let's hope your friends and relatives aren't jostling you trying to be the first to fit their stuff in this overhead compartment. But that's the only downside to this astute use of otherwise wasted headliner space. No more balancing stuff on the dashboard. It's part of an innovative upper-cockpit design that includes enormous sun visors that are drilled underneath for ventilation and weight saving, plus a tiny mirror that lets you scope out what the people in the back (or the cargo you have on board) are up to.

4. 2016 Range Rover Supercharged and 2016 Lexus LX570

Kudos to both of these massive and pricey big SUVs for a gracious butler-like experience in the back. Both have a split tailgate that leaves a raised lip when you lift the back hatch. Once folded down, this becomes a staging area that is carpeted right up to the edge, easing the experience of loading things into the back of your vehicle. The Range Rover is pictured. See the gallery, below, for images of the Lexus.

5. 2016 Toyota Sienna XLE

The midlevel Sienna minivan can be fitted with this Auto Access Seat, which brings the second-row seat on the passenger's side out from the vehicle for those with physical challenges get a ride right from the sidewalk to the van. For those with elderly parents, passengers with handicaps of any kind, or anyone else with mobility issues, it is a blessing, and it's not an aftermarket product but something that comes right from the Toyota dealer.

6. 2017 Honda Ridgeline

Tailgate parties take on a new luster with this feature, which embeds speakers into the tailgate of the pickup. Now you can blast the music, not just out the windows but straight from the truck bed. Not only that, but check out this brilliant in-bed storage compartment. See Jean's designer walkaround of the 2017 Ridgeline on video here.

7. 2016 Ram 1500

Don't you hate small stuff rattling around in the back of your truck? How about this pair of sturdy side-mounted, locking tool boxes on the Ram 1500? It's called the RamBox Cargo Management System Plus, and it has lights and drainage. You can get a remote security system on the Ram 1500 that lets you lock and unlock it by pushing a button. This also comes on the freshly introduced Ram Power Wagon.

images.caption: 2016 GMC Acadia's fold-out cargo area protector.
2016 Ford Transit Connect's aircraft-style overhead storage.
2016 Range Rover Supercharged has carpeting all the way out to the edge.
2016 Lexus LX570's split tailgate folds down for a smooth staging area.
2016 Toyota Sienna XLE's Auto Access Seat comes right out of the van.
2016 Ford Explorer BraunAbility MXV is wheelchair friendly in every sense of the word.
Awesome in-bed storage in the 2017 Honda Ridgeline pickup.
2017 Ram Power Wagon has the RamBox side storage, too.
2017 Ram Power Wagon's rear seat area has fold-flat capability.

title: 2016 BraunAbility Ford Explorer
subTitle: The first wheelchair-friendly SUV! Our new friend Jesse Billauer will be driving it to surf spots.
promoTeaserSmall: The first wheelchair-friendly SUV! Our new friend Jesse Billauer will be driving it to surf spots.
promoTeaser: The first wheelchair-friendly SUV! Our new friend Jesse Billauer will be driving it to surf spots.
metaDescription: The first wheelchair-friendly SUV! Our new friend Jesse Billauer will be driving it to surf spots.

pageElements.text:
2016 BraunAbility Ford Explorer MXV

Type: Two-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive adapted sport-utility vehicle
Price as adapted: $50,000—$70,000
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 290 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic with sliding shifter and hand controls
Fuel economy: 19 mpg city/29 mpg highway
Notable standard features on this model: Lighted side ramp, nerf bars, removable seats, wheelchair docking pins
Notable options:
Towing package (5,000 pounds), zero-effort steering

Wheelchair users have enough limitations and challenges in their daily lives, so why should they be limited to only one kind of vehicle, a boxy adapted van? That's the rationale behind the 2016 BraunAbility Ford Explorer MXV, and kudos to both Ford and BraunAbility of Indiana for coming up with the first wheelchair-friendly sport-utility vehicle. The 2016 BraunAbility Ford Explorer MXV not only has an extended roof height to accommodate a wheelchair in back, it also has removable front seats so a wheelchair user can ride in one or both of the front seats.

Ford has donated this one to thirty-seven-year-old Jesse Billauer, who started the Life Rolls On Foundation to help other wheelchair users enjoy surfing and skateboarding. We met him at the Chicago Auto Show, where he helped Ford and BraunAbility introduce the adapted Explorer. Billauer, who was injured in a surfing accident at age seventeen, has been driving a Dodge Durango; his caregiver lifts him up into the driver's seat. This Explorer should considerably expand his horizons as he travels the country helping other wheelchair users have fun in skate parks and surf spots.

The BraunAbility Explorer will cost $50,000 to $70,000, Braun marketing chief Joe Garnett told us. Compare that with the $31,995 base price of the 2016 Ford Explorer. But this adapted version has something very special: the ability for the wheelchair user to position the chair in the driver's-seat area and drive the Explorer, not just ride inside. Thanks to the 59-inch interior height over the front seats and 58 inches in the center of the vehicle, wheelchair users can sit in either front seat area or in the back. Or, as Billauer pointed out, two people in wheelchairs can ride together in the front seat area. The side door opens 55 inches high, and the ramp has 28.5 inches of usable width.

The wheelchair locks in place thanks to a docking station that locks into a pin on the wheelchair, in much the same fashion that a camera locks onto a tripod, Garnett explained. Then the wheelchair user uses the Explorer's standard shoulder harness. Various controls are available, depending on the user's particular needs, including a sliding shifter that moves from side to side to make extra space on the driver's or passenger's side, hand controls to replace the foot pedals, and zero-effort steering for those who need it.

This Explorer has a power ramp with in-floor lighting, removable driver and passenger seats, and sliding door technology that's been patented.  But, most important, it doesn't look or feel like a wheelchair-friendly van; it looks and feels like an SUV.
The BraunAbility Explorer has the SUV's standard 3.5-liter V-6, gets 17 mpg city and 24 mpg on the highway, and can tow up to 5,000 pounds with the optional towing package.
The BraunAbility plant in Winamac, Indiana, will be supplying this wonder to more than 200 of its dealers around the United States. To find out more about it, check out the BraunAbility website.

title: 2015 Tesla Model S
subTitle: Wonder of wonders, miracle of miracles.
promoTeaserSmall: Wonder of wonders, miracle of miracles.
promoTeaser: Wonder of wonders, miracle of miracles.
metaKeywords: 2015 Tesla Model S; Tesla; American; sedan; electric; plug-in;
metaDescription: Wonder of wonders, miracle of miracles. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: 5- or 7-passenger, rear or all-wheel-drive plug-in electric sedan
Price range: $71,070–$105,670 (includes destination)
Trim levels: 70D, 85, 85D, P85D
Motors: AC induction; 70/85 kWh lithium-ion battery, 329/362/422/691 horsepower
Transmission: Single-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 94 MPGe city/97 MPGe highway
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not rated; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars (2014 model rated)
Our favorite standard feature: Seventeen-inch touchscreen
Notable standard features on this model: Seven-speaker audio system, twelve-way power-adjustable heated front seats, LED taillamps, mobile app remote control
Notable options on this model: Tech package with Autopilot, smart air suspension, premium audio, premium interior, rear-facing third-row seats
You might also be considering: BMW ActiveHybrid 7, Cadillac ELR, Porsche Panamera S E-Hybrid

Since the Tesla Model S made its sensational debut in 2013, engineers who created the car haven’t exactly been sitting on their hands. The Model S, a battery-electric vehicle, combined an unprecedented level of innovation, technology, design, and quality when it was fresh out of the box. Indeed, this American luxury sedan with a rear-mounted motor driving the rear wheels matched up well in style and pace against the European competition. But for 2015, Tesla has addressed some opportunities and achieved a worldwide first for production vehicles. To improve performance, a second motor, placed in front and driving the front wheels, is available. With 691 horsepower and all-wheel drive, the P85D whooshes from 0 to 60 mph in 3.1 seconds, achieves a top speed of 155 mph, and cruises as far as 253 miles. The P85D sits atop the range, which includes the Model S 70D and Model S 85, named for their 70- and 85-kilowatt-hour batteries supplying current to a 329- and 362-horsepower motors, respectively. The fourth model is the 85D, which benefits from the dual-motor layout but has a milder attitude with 422 horsepower; nevertheless, it will also go 155 mph. Besides hot-rodding the Model S, Tesla shows a unique twist on active safety with the available Autopilot, an artificial intelligence application that permits hands-free lane-keeping, changing of lanes, and parking. Software updates add new capabilities to the system. The Model S has a gorgeous, spacious interior with the ultimate in touchscreens, a seventeen-incher that will dazzle your passengers. And the shapely body includes features like “zero profile” door handles that recede into their housings; the P85D has a charge port in the left rear that automatically opens when it senses a charging connector’s proximity. The Model S is a breakthrough car that just keeps getting better.

title: 13 Things You Used to Have in the Car
subTitle: A look at some of the weird crap people used to carry around but don't have to anymore.
promoTitle: 13 Things You Used to Have in the Car
promoTeaserSmall: A look at some of the weird crap people used to carry around but don't have to anymore.
promoTeaser: A look at some of the weird crap people used to carry around but don't have to anymore.
keywords: 13 Things You Used to Have in the Car
metaTitle: 13 Things You Used to Have in the Car - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: A look at some of the weird crap people used to carry around but don't have to anymore.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: Lifestyle factors and improving technology have changed how we maintain, accessorize, and adorn our cars. Whether it’s the more precise fit of components or the implementation of advanced electronic systems, our crude measures of the past are now part of history.

Consider these once common items that are less frequently—or never—found inside or attached to contemporary automobiles.

1. Oil can, spout, and rags

The owner’s manual of a friend’s 1982 Ferrari 308GTSi warns to expect oil consumption of one quart every 250 to 500 miles. “Fill ’er up with ethyl and check the oil” was commonly requested of the service station attendant, no matter what you drove. But as engine design improves, it’s become unusual for a car to consume a quart of oil in 5,000 miles. When did you last see someone open the hood at the gas station and pull the dipstick?

2. Steering wheel knob

Power steering first became available on the 1951 Chrysler Imperial and was considered a luxurious feature even in the 1960s. The 1973 Plymouth Valiant offered power steering as a $100 option. With unassisted steering, clamping a knob over the steering wheel made it easier for the driver to crank it at low speed, when response was heaviest. It also enabled one-handed steering, allowing a guy to throw his arm around his girl.

3. Accessory air conditioning

Even the 2015 Nissan Versa includes standard air conditioning, but fifty-five years ago, A/C was an expensive option found in only 20 percent of all cars. Through the mid-century, some people added an external evaporative cooler, a large cylinder with an internal water tank that clung like a barnacle to the car’s roofline. As the water evaporated by the force of wind, cool air came inside. (Of course, it only worked when the car was moving.) Packard introduced an integrated refrigerated air conditioning system in 1939, charging a whopping $274 for the option. (A new Ford cost as little as $660 that year.) By the late 1960s, about 50 percent of all cars were equipped with A/C. Those on the wrong side of that equation could be fitted with an accessory underdash unit that kept everybody cool.

4. Seat cushions

Wicker or beaded seat cushions prevented a sweaty back on a long drive and insulated against the shock of a cold seat on a freezing day. The seat cushion has evolved to an advanced state, namely, the polyester and foam unit that plugs into the twelve-volt adapter and blows cool air through internal vents. That’s great for thrashing around in an older car. Much more effective heated and cooled seats are available in a wide variety of new cars. Note: The same basic story also applies to rear window shades.

5. CB radio/eight-track player

The citizens band radio provided a way to communicate between vehicles, a useful thing when the national 55-mph speed limit went into effect in 1973. In response, cars and trucks teamed up in convoys to drive faster. Around the same time, accessory eight-track tape decks were mounted below dashboards. Great for Aerosmith, bad for knees. Currently, speed limits as high as 85 mph in some places now have drivers singing a happy tune, no longer calling out a CB handle such as River Rat or Cycle Smoker. As autonomous vehicle technology spreads, cars will talk to one another. As for Aerosmith, Bluetooth streaming delivers them from your iPod to the audio system.

image.altText: Rambler American 1St Generation Black Sedan Credit Czmarlin

pageElements.text:
6. Curb feelers

These springy, segmented pieces of steel were clamped onto a car’s rocker panels, and their probing, scraping noises announced the curb’s proximity when parallel parking.
Replacements: Parking assist technology

7. Tire repair

A jack of the ratcheting or scissors type, a spare tire, and inner tube patch kits—all have been going extinct.
Replacements: Inflation canisters, roadside service, and more durable tires

8. Road Maps

Maps offer their own well-documented rewards, and the AAA still gives out plenty of them. But there are storage and handling issues.
Replacements: Digitized maps for built-in navigation systems, smartphone navigation apps

9. Winter traction sand

Heavy bags of sand or road salt in the trunk added weight over the rear driving wheels, improving traction. And the material could be spread under the tires if the car got stuck. (Sometimes, a shovel was also kept back there.) This has died out a lot less in places with extreme winter climates, of course.
Replacements: Front- or all-wheel drive, traction control systems

10. Snow tires and chains

Rear-wheel-drive cars dug into winter snow with two snow tires, molded with blocky treads resembling those of tractor tires. (They were incredibly noisy on dry roads.) In extreme conditions, the steel chains were wrapped around them, clanking and jangling like sleigh bells.
Replacements: Front- or all-wheel drive; traction control; sets of four snow tires of advanced design

11. Roadside Repasts

A well-stocked picnic basket let travelers stop wherever the state highway department had placed tables under the cottonwoods of a roadside rest area.
Tip: Vintage automotive picnic baskets are collectible these days.
Exception: You may own a Rolls-Royce Phantom, available with a handmade picnic set of oiled teak and saddle leather for four persons (as on the Phantom Drophead Coupe, shown here).

Replacement:

Semi-premium chain restaurants in turnpike service areas have wiped out most of the baskets of fried chicken, potato salad, and chablis.

12. Roadside repairs

Spare fuses, electrical tape, and a radiator hose repair kit were once essential.
Replacements: Smartphone; road service membership; credit card

13. Church key

Some of us kept a church key—the old name for a combination can and bottle opener—in the glove box in order to enjoy an impromptu soft drink or malty beverage.

Replacement:

The wisdom not to drink on the road; open container laws in most states (Mississippi still allows the consumption of alcohol while driving).

Photos: 8 Track: CZMarlin; seatcover: Amazon; Brodie knob: Dean F. Gemberling; jacksaw: interiot; curb feelers: CZMarlin; thermador: Doug Coldwell

title: 2015 BMW 2 Series
subTitle: A racy subcompact.
promoTeaserSmall: A racy subcompact.
promoTeaser: A racy subcompact.
metaDescription: A racy subcompact. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Four-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive coupe or convertible
Price range: $33,050–$48,650 (includes destination)
Trim levels: 228i, M235i
Engines: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 240 horsepower; turbocharged 3.0-liter six-cylinder, 320 horsepower
Transmissions: Six-speed manual, eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 228i manual: 22 mpg city/34 mpg highway; 228i automatic: 23/34–36 mpg; 228i xDrive automatic: 22–23/32–35 mpg; M235i manual: 19/26–28 mpg; M235i automatic: 21/32 mpg; M235i xDrive: 20/30 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: iDrive infotainment system
Notable standard features on this model: Bluetooth hands-free calling, push button start, dual-zone climate control
Notable options on this model: Navigation, ten-way power driver and front passenger seats with lumbar support, rearview camera, park assist, adaptive cruise control, phone and app integration, Harman Kardon premium audio system
You might also be considering: Audi A3, Lexus IS250C, Mercedes-Benz CLA-Class

As the BMW 3 Series continues its growth spurt, the 2 Series has become the new entry-level model if your heart is set on a BMW but you don’t want to wait a few more years until your wallet catches up with your wish list. This rear-wheel-drive subcompact is available as a coupe or convertible, and it delivers excellent driving dynamics, performance, fuel economy, and technology in a smaller package than its 3 Series sibling. On the downside, it seats only four. But buyers are more likely buying this car for its engineering than its people shuttling and cargo capacity (which at almost 14 cubic feet is quite good), and they’ll be pleased with its standard turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine that produces a more than ample 240 horsepower. It’s also one of the dwindling stock of rear-wheel-drive vehicles available with a six-speed manual transmission, and yet for the winter-weather dwellers, it’s also offered with xDrive. The interior is high end, but you’ll pay extra for most bells and whistles. Dual-zone climate control and a 6.5-inch LCD screen are standard, but navigation, a rearview camera, park assist, a cruise control system with braking function, and phone and app integration are all extra. Performance-minded buyers can bump up to the M—also still available with a manual transmission—and get the turbocharged 3.0-liter six-cylinder engine that produces 320 horsepower and 330 pound-feet of torque, producing an impressive power-to-weight ratio. M-specific braking, exhaust, suspension, and chassis tuning complete this tight little package.

New for 2015

BMW’s intelligent all-wheel-drive system available on the 228i xDrive Coupe and the M235i xDrive models; newly available Track Handling package.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive SUV/crossover
Price range: $60,550–$103,050 (includes destination)
Trim levels: sDrive35i, xDrive35i, xDrive50i, X6 M
Engines: Turbocharged 3.0-liter six-cylinder, 300 horsepower; twin-turbocharged 4.4-liter V-8, 445/567 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: sDrive35i: 19 mpg city/27 mpg highway; xDrive35i: 18/27 mpg; xDrive50i: 15/22 mpg; X6 M: 14/19 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not rated; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: BMW Apps
Notable standard features on this model: Power tailgate, 14-way power driver and front passenger seats with lumbar support, heated front seats, USB audio connection and hands-free Bluetooth including Audio Streaming, iDrive, navigation, multifunction leather steering wheel
Notable options on this model: Heated rear seats, head-up display, rearview camera, 20-way multi-contour front seats with ventilation, adaptive LED headlights, manual rear window sunshades
You might also be considering: Audi Q5, Land Rover Range Rover Evoque, Porsche Cayenne

The second-generation X6 is carving a niche in the not well understood luxury coupe-shaped-crossover market. The all-new 2015 BMW X6 retains the same 6-Series-inspired styling cues as the outgoing model, such as the fastback roofline and shorter rear doors, but the interior redesign fixes some of the vehicle’s earlier shortcomings. One of the most noticeable changes is that the X6 has increased its seating capacity from four to five. The first-generation vehicle sat only two in the rear, and the second row now can seat three across. Front and rear passengers will enjoy a bit more headroom, and while legroom is unchanged for the front row, the rear passengers will have two inches more to stretch their legs. But that extra legroom comes at a cost: namely, cargo capacity. The 2015 X6’s cargo capacity is down five cubic feet from the previous generation—now 20.5 cubic feet—and is less than that of the X1. But buyers tend to shop the X6 more for its advantageous forward view and agile performance than its practicality, which is reflected in the new rear-wheel-drive sDrive35i.

New for 2015

The X6 is all new for 2015.

title: How to Keep Dogs Cool in the Car
subTitle: 5 ways to help keep your pet safer in the car during the dog days of summer, or anytime.
promoTitle: How to Keep Dogs Cool in the Car
promoTeaserSmall: 5 ways to help keep your pet safer in the car during the dog days of summer, or anytime.
promoTeaser: 5 ways to help keep your pet safer in the car during the dog days of summer, or anytime.
keywords: How to Keep Dogs Cool in the Car
metaTitle: 5 Ways to Help Your Dog Keep Cool  - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 5 ways to help keep your pet safer in the car during the dog days of summer, or anytime.

pageElements.text:
It’s that time of year again, when you head out on errands or day trips in the car, and your dog comes along for the ride. Problem: How do you keep your pet from getting overheated?
 
First things first: You must take every measure to avoid leaving your dog inside a parked car for any length of time. The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (ASPCA) says that, on an 85-degree day, temperatures inside a car can reach 102 degrees within ten minutes. That’s no time at all.

“The ASPCA never condones leaving a dog in a car; too much can happen too quickly and end in tragedy,” Julie Morris, the ASPCA’s senior vice-president of community outreach, told Jean Knows Cars. The grocery store can wait; your dog’s well-being is more important.

But the reality is, you do have to go in to a store occasionally where you can’t bring your pet along. With experience gained from years of pet ownership and participation in dog shows, here are our five tips to help your dog chill out in the car when it’s hot outside.

1. Improve the air quality.

You can keep the engine on and blast the air conditioning, at least briefly—but bring a second set of keys so you can still lock the car. Your pet should be in a cage or wearing a harness if you do, not moving freely around the car.

Even better, bring some portable, battery-powered fans. Large fans—Ryobi is one brand—with built-in stands and hooks can be hung directly onto a dog cage in the back of your vehicle. Fresh batteries or extra fans will let you keep the cool air going while you are on the move. Ryobi fans also have a charger that works off the car’s cigarette lighter.

2. Find the shade (or make your own).

When you know you’re going to be parked for a while—at a park, for example—find the shadiest spot in the lot. For longer visits, use a pop-up awning that can cover the back of the vehicle. Another good choice is reflective mesh covers on the windshield and the two front doors. This will beat back the sun’s rays while allowing breezes to blow through.

3. Buy a chilly pad (seriously, they’re amazing).

Frogg Togg is a company that makes rainwear, but many people know them for their chilly pad. The chilly pad is constructed of a “man made sponge” that retains up to eight times its weight in water. Frogg Togg explains, “Once wet, the towels produce a cooling effect with the help of simple evaporation, and as long as the towel is wet, exposed to the air, and allowed to breathe, it will remain chilled.” The best part? They make one for dogs. You can line a crate with the ChillyDog Pad, and your pet will stay cool for hours.

4. Bring backup water.

Staying hydrated is just as important for dogs as it is for humans, so keep two to three extra water bottles on hand in addition to a bowl for drinking. If possible, store this water in a cooler with ice. I do not know many people who would prefer warm to cool water on a hot day, and the same goes for your dog. The best thing on hot days is to fill a special cooler with mostly ice, preferably made at home from the water your pet is used to. Then let your dog drink directly from the cooler, the same way most dogs drink directly from the toilet.

5. Leave a note.

The Humane Society of the United States, ASPCA, and PETA all have campaigns for awareness about the dangers of leaving your pet in the car, and they distribute flyers explaining what to do if you come across a dog in an unattended vehicle. The directions include telling the passer-by to call the police and break the window. All good advice. So, if you must leave your pet in the car and have taken proper precautions, let others know. Tape a note to your windshield making it clear that yes, your pup is in the back seat, but that you have set him up with air conditioning and water and will be back in a jiff. Also, include the number of the cellphone you have with you so you can be reached.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/BCVh36ykv7U?list=PLDtKaZSQcnJDBKK4xQsBeRQm1nY0FMAyv" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

title: The New Alfa Romeos
subTitle: Alfa Romeo returns to America with power, passion, and, soon, the Giulia sedan. Do you want one?
promoTeaserSmall: Alfa Romeo returns to America with power, passion, and, soon, the Giulia sedan. Do you want one?
promoTeaser: Alfa Romeo returns to America with power, passion, and, soon, the Giulia sedan. Do you want one?
metaDescription: Alfa Romeo returns to America with power, passion, and, soon, the Giulia sedan. Do you want one? - JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text: You wouldn't know it by reading car-enthusiast magazines, but it is actually not front-page headline news that Alfa Romeo is back in the U.S. market. If it’s caught your attention at all, it’s a good bet that it’s close to subliminal. Now that Alfa is bringing a sedan to join the sports-car 4C, maybe that will change.
Unless you're an Italian-car aficionado, you might wonder: What does Alfa Romeo have to do with me?

The answer to that is a function of how you feel about automobiles. Are they simply transportation, packaged in varying levels of utility, comfort, and efficiency? Or do you want a little more? Distinctive style? Passion?
Those are the elements that have been core traits of Alfa Romeos since 1910, when Anonima Lombarda Fabbrica Automobili was established in Milan, Italy.

But while style and passion have been consistent throughout this long history, quality and reliability have not, a weakness that eroded sales and eventually forced Alfa to fold its tent and withdraw from the U.S. market in 1995.
Now Alfa is back, a return that began last year and continues with a trickle of sports cars and anticipation of a new sedan, the Giulietta, that will reach U.S. showrooms in mid-2016.
Are either of these cars right for you? Let’s take a look.

Alfa Romeo Giulia

The name has hallowed roots in Alfa history, and a proper sedan is definitely something the make’s 120 U.S. dealers need to achieve black balance sheets. It’s also a car that will make a lot more sense to a much wider market than the passionate but hard-edged 4C sports car.

This is not to say that sport and passion won’t be part of the Giulia’s pedigree, particularly in the Quadrifoglio version you see here. It’s reflected in the sexy, skintight sheetmetal, the aggressive stance, the fat, low-profile Pirelli tires.
But four doors and a trunk add an element of practicality that’s obviously not part of the deal with the 4C.

Basics: the Giulia is truly all new—a new platform, which will see adaptations in other Alfas; new skin; and a new twin-turbocharged V6 engine, developed with input from Ferrari. Dimensional specifics were basically absent from Alfa’s presentation, held in the company’s superb museum in Milan, but the Giulia is about the size of a BMW 3-Series, a car that’s everyone’s sports sedan target.

With 503 horsepower on tap from the twin-turbo V6, Alfa is forecasting 0-to-62 mph (100 kilometers per hour) in 3.9 seconds, which is brisk, but perhaps conservative. With just 425 hp, the BMW M3 achieves about the same, and given Alfa’s attention to keeping weight as low as possible, the Quadrifoglio may well be quicker.

It’s also reasonable to expect that the Quadrifoglio's athletic credentials will, at a minimum, rival the moves of the M3, since the BMW was the prime development target. And it’s worth noting that fuel economy did not merit a mention in Alfa’s presentation. Nor was there any talk about autonomous operation; Alfas are all about driver gratification.
What about reliability and assembly quality, two elements that damaged Alfa’s appeal in the U.S. market, and ultimately led to its retreat? That’s obviously a wait-and-see, though it’s not unreasonable to assume that Alfa will be taking pains to make sure its new cars are as flawless as possible for U.S. customers.

The Giulia will be on sale in Europe this fall and will begin trickling into U.S. showrooms sometime in 2016, probably as a 2017 model. Pricing was not on the agenda at the Milan program, and with U.S. availability still a year away, we can only guess. Since the Giulia Quadrifoglio is targeted on the BMW M3, and M3 pricing currently starts at about $63,000, we can probably anticipate a base price of about $65,000.

If that sounds a little stiff, or the Quadrifoglio seems a little extreme, or both, there will be less exotic models following the hot rod, one with a non-turbo version of the V-6, another with a turbocharged four-cylinder engine, both with significantly lower prices. All-wheel drive will also be an option.
Looking further down the strada, the new platform that supports the Giulia will become the foundation for a crossover SUV, probably two years from U.S. availability.

Looking further down the strada, the new platform that supports the Giulia will become the foundation for a crossover SUV, probably two years from U.S. availability, and beyond that there will be other Alfas, still shrouded in secrecy. But we can say that Alfa Romeo is a premium brand, and that there won’t be any offerings aimed at competing with mainstream brands.
After all, style and passion have never been everyday commodities. A certain amount of exclusivity makes them more desirable.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/cCPYmVZwXc4" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Alfa Romeo 4C Coupe and Spider

The classic definition of a sports car is a topless two-seater that can be driven on the street but is also suitable for racing. Among contemporary automobiles, this definition is mitigated by concessions made to comfort, but the 4C makes fewer than most. Fewer, in fact, than any.

To review, the 4C is a carbon-fiber-intensive, rear-wheel-drive two-seater with an exceptionally rigid chassis, stiff suspension tuning, sticky tires, and powerful brakes. It’s propelled by a 1.7-liter engine, its diminutive displacement amplified by turbocharging to 237 horsepower.

That may not sound like much compared to the 275 hp of the basic Porsche Cayman, which is commonly mentioned as an alternative to the little Alfa coupe. But the Alfa weighs in at less than 2,500 pounds, putting the 4C coupe on an equal power-to-weight footing with the 3,000-pound Cayman.

Residing behind the passenger compartment, the little turbo engine sends power to the rear wheels via a six-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission, one of those automated manuals the delivers lightning-fast shifts via steering column paddles. There is no manual transmission option, which has provoked some moaning from the enthusiast publications.
Distinguished by lots of exposed carbon fiber, the interior tends toward spartan and snug, with deeply bolstered seats designed to keep driver and passenger anchored during enthusiastic cornering.
My first look at the Spider was at the Detroit auto show last January, and more recently I logged some California seat time, including an afternoon at Mazda Raceway Laguna Seca, near Monterey.

Impressions that emerged were identical to an earlier experience with the 4C coupe. The Spider is just as quick—0 to 60 mph in less than 4.5 seconds—and just as nimble. Responses are just as eager, body roll is absent, and the steering—with no power assist—is racing-car quick and laser accurate.
The tires generate leech-like grip, and braking performance is formidable—minimal stopping distances, consistent stop after stop after stop.

The only real distinction between coupe and Spider—its removable roof panel makes it more of a targa than a true convertible—is that with the top open it’s even easier to hear the bark of the engine. Which is a long way of saying the 4C Spider can be even noisier than the coupe.

This brings us back to the issue of sports car purity. Coupe or Spider, the Alfa 4C has it double in spades, a car that’s an extension of the driver’s will and thrives on track days, autocross events, and roads with lots of twists and turns. The relationship between car and driver just doesn’t get any more intense than this.

On the other hand, the 4C’s ride quality is stiff, no one could call it roomy, infotainment is minimal (premium audio would be wasted here), there’s not much luggage space, it’s noisy, and getting in or out, though easier with the top open, requires contortions.

Coupe pricing starts at $55,195, similar to the Porsche Cayman, the Spider at $65,495, considerably more than the Porsche Boxster.
Alfa literature insists that the 4C has no real rival in its price class, and thus can’t really be compared to anything else. Given the car’s capabilities, there’s truth to this—it’s an exceptional hard core sports car, that turns heads wherever it goes.

But hard core can become a little tedious as a day to day driving experience. Anyone aspiring to 4C ownership would be well advised to have another car for everyday use. Also, that aspiration should be tempered with patience. Hand-built in Modena, Italy, the 4C’s production rate is essentially glacial; Alfa admits that assembly of the Spider consumes about six weeks.

title: Book Review: 100 Things for Gearheads
subTitle: Are you working on your car adventure bucket list? Jason Fogelson's book has some ideas. So do I.
promoTeaserSmall: Are you working on your car adventure bucket list? Jason Fogelson's book has some ideas. So do I.
promoTeaser: Are you working on your car adventure bucket list? Jason Fogelson's book has some ideas. So do I.
metaKeywords: 100 Things for Every Gearhead to Do Before They Die
metaDescription: Are you working on your car adventure bucket list? Jason Fogelson's book has some ideas. So do I.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
100 Things for Every Gearhead to Do before They Die
by Jason Fogelson
Reedy Press, 2015
208 pages, $18
Available from Books for Gearheads

Jason Fogelson has created a bucket list in this book, supposedly for gearheads, but any driver/historian/adventurer or family looking for next year’s quirky vacation itinerary will enjoy it. To help your imagination, Fogelson has created an index divided thus: Rides and Drives, Auctions, Car Museums, New Car Shows, Classic Car Shows, Concours d’Elegance, Factory Tours, Land Speed Records, Motorcycle Museums, Off-Roading, Racing, Rallies, Test Drives and Experiences, Driving Schools, Track Days, Motorcycle Track Days, and Wrench on Your Ride. The pages of the last category will undoubtedly remain pristine in many books.
I discovered that I have completed almost half of the list—forty-two, to be precise. Not sure I have enough time left to complete Fogelson’s Top 100.

So what strikes your fancy? What adventure have you already completed on your way to automotive nirvana? Which of these do you think you need to tick off to become a certified “car guy"? How about just picking one adventure from each chapter?

Who cares? Well, I cared enough to actually thumb through every single page highlighting the little numbered Interstate logo at the top of each thrilling moment (some not so thrilling, some actually boring) that I had completed in my lifetime. I discovered that I have completed almost half of the list—forty-two, to be precise. Not sure I have enough time left to complete Fogelson’s Top 100. [Nonsense, my dear—Ed.]
I edged the Range Rover all the way down Black Bear Pass, one three-point turn after another, until I reached Telluride. It remains my most accomplished off-road moment.

Imagine if you used this book for the family vacation to Colorado to see the relatives in Fort Collins. You could thumb through the Gearhead List and find the Pikes Peak Highway (#9) and the Alpine Loop from Ouray to Silverton to Lake City (#64). I just happen to have done both. The first was during practice for the actual Race to the Clouds, with Roger Mears at the wheel. We started halfway up the hill, and I distinguished myself by passing out from lack of oxygen with only one leg in the racing suit I’d borrowed from Roger, Jr. I ended up on oxygen in a MASH unit at the base of the hill, while Roger, Sr., carried on and crashed off the mountain, stopped from certain death by a snowbank that hadn’t melted all the way. I completed the second Colorado drive in a Range Rover, then finished off the entire terrifying adventure by edging all the way down Black Bear Pass, one three-point turn after another, until I reached Telluride. It remains my most accomplished off-road moment to date.

Oh, I have more stories, but why not go make your own? Fogelson has created this useful framework for you. I’d suggest you get out a map (you remember those things?) and a highlighter and put dots on the locations of all 100. Then string a few together. You’ll be entertaining yourself—gearhead or not—for years to come.

Now I am preparing my own list, of Things Every Gearhead Should Do in Europe before They Die. I'll post it on this site when it's done. Meanwhile, I would like Fogelson to send me his definitive list of the Top 100 Albums Every Music Freak Should Own Before They Die. He definitely has it in him.

title: 2016: Infotainment to Look Forward to
subTitle: Changes and features you'll love on new models this year, from app integration to wireless hot spots.
promoTeaserSmall: Changes and features you'll love on new models this year, from app integration to wireless hot spots.
promoTeaser: Changes and features you'll love on new models this year, from app integration to wireless hot spots.
metaTitle: 2016: Infotainment to Look Forward to - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Changes and features you'll love on new models this year, from app integration to wireless hot spots.

pageElements.text:
If you’re considering a new car, truck, or SUV in the 2016 model year, you’re in luck. The auto companies are pulling out all the stops when it comes to infotainment in the car, making the touchscreen faster, easier to use, and full of features so enticing, you soon won’t know how you lived without them. 
Here’s our rundown of some of the new models where you’ll find the latest and greatest.

1. More Like a Smartphone

Finally, no more aggravated arrow pressing. Many automakers have adopted the tile-like icon format you see on tablets and smartphones to give you quick access to music, messaging, and navigation in the style you’re used to outside the car. As on the iPhone and iPad, you can customize your menu bar by dragging and dropping your favorite applications. The all-new Ford Sync 3 system, coming out on a limited basis this fall with full availability in the 2017 model year, also lets you swipe, tap, and pinch like you would on a tablet or smartphone. Jaguar's 2016 XF has this, too, with its InControl Touch 10.2-inch screen.

Who’s Got It (2016 models)

Chevrolet: most models, including Cruze, Malibu, Camaro, Tahoe
Chrysler 200 and 300
Dodge Challenger, Charger, Durango, Viper
Jeep Cherokee and Grand Cherokee
Ram 1500
Ford Escape and Fiesta
Jaguar XF

2. Apps, Fully Integrated

Along with Sync 3, Ford is improving AppLink, which allows you to connect your smartphone to your car and control a wide range of compatible apps. AppLink automatically recognizes apps including favorites like Pandora and NPR One. Now you can sing along to your customized Roadtrip Pandora station in the car with no hassle. Honda’s HondaLink also connects your car and phone and provides location searches, local weather and messaging. These app integrators provide a simple way to control your apps while driving, balancing the access you want with the limitations you need.

Hyundai is adding Apple Watch and Android smartwatch functionality to its BlueLink telematics, letting you do things like locate, lock, and start your car remotely from your wrist. Any Hyundai equipped with first- or second-generation BlueLink works with it.

Who's Got It (2016 models)

Ford Escape and Fiesta
Honda Pilot and HR-V
Hyundai (all models with BlueLink infotainment)

3. Siri as Your Co-Pilot

We all know it’s not a good thing to talk on the phone while you’re driving, but the temptation can be strong to fish it out and ask Siri the name of that actress who made a cameo in the movie you just saw. Siri Eyes Free has that need covered. Just push a button on your steering wheel—instead of your smartphone—and put Siri to work for you.

Who’s Got It (2016 models)

Acura ILX, MDX
Chevrolet (most models, including Cruze, Malibu, Camaro, Tahoe)
Chrysler 200 and 300
Ford Escape and Fiesta
Dodge Challenger, Charger, Durango, Viper
Honda Civic, CR-V, Pilot
Jeep Cherokee and Grand Cherokee
Ram 1500

4. Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, Soon to Be Everywhere

Okay, your 2016 car’s touchscreen layout strongly resembles your smartphone’s, and you have access to your most-used apps. There could not possibly be a way to make this more intuitive, right?

Wrong. Apple CarPlay and Android Auto have copied your iPhone and Android home screens and pasted them directly onto your car’s touchscreen. As soon as you start the ignition, you will come face to face with a screen that appears nearly identical to your iPhone or Android’s, displaying apps you want and need while out on the road. CarPlay even features the home button we all know and love. You still cannot play Angry Birds while driving—nor should you, ever—but now you can access your audiobooks, maps, and messages in a way that makes sense.

Who’s Got It (2016 models)

Buick LaCrosse and Regal
Chevrolet (most models, including Cruze, Malibu, Camaro, Tahoe)
GMC Yukon and Sierra
Hyundai Sonata
Volvo XC90

Here is a full list of auto brands that will soon be getting Android Auto and a full list of those getting Apple CarPlay.

5. Your Car as a Rolling Wireless Hot Spot

Say goodbye to the post-road-trip “you have used 90% of your monthly data allowance” texts. General Motors, already offering it on twenty-five vehicles in 2015, is expanding its range of models that can operate as 4G LTE rolling wireless hot spots. Audi is expanding availability across the range. Subaru is introducing 4G LTE to selected models for the first time with its Starlink system that uses AT&T and SiriusXM connected vehicle services. For road warriors who want to pull over (please pull over) and catch up on email, for parents whose kids need to do homework or stream YouTube on the way to soccer games, for anyone who wants to have connectivity everywhere for any reason, this is likely only the beginning of a trend for automakers to turn your car into even more of an extension of your home.

Who’s Got It (2016 models)

Audi (all models)
Buick (most models)
Cadillac (most models)
Chevrolet (most models)
GMC (most models)
Subaru (Legacy, Outback, Forester)

images.caption: Apple Watch now interfaces with Hyundai vehicles that have BlueLink.
Hyundai BlueLink infotainment, now for smartphone and smartwatch.
Dodge Challenger's UConnect infotainment is now more like your smartphone.
FCA's Ram 2500 Limited has Siri Eyes Free.
Apple CarPlay is soon to be found on dozens of auto brands.
Ford's new Sync 3 is coming first to Fiesta and Escape, to other Fords in 2017 model year.
2016 Chevrolet Spark is one of many GM products to use smartphone integration.
The multi-device 4G LTE wireless hot spot in the Cadillac Escalade.
The Apple CarPlay screen in the car works much like the one on the iPhone.

title: Automoblox Toys Add Brembo Brakes
subTitle: Coolest toy cars ever are adding colorful, high-performance Brembo brakes to the 2016 lineup.
promoTeaserSmall: Coolest toy cars ever are adding colorful, high-performance Brembo brakes to the 2016 lineup.
promoTeaser: Coolest toy cars ever are adding colorful, high-performance Brembo brakes to the 2016 lineup.
metaTitle: Automoblox Toys Add Brembo Brakes - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Coolest toy cars ever are adding colorful, high-performance Brembo brakes to the 2016 lineup.

pageElements.text: How do you know that Automoblox toy cars are the coolest toys ever?
Because these are toys you can take seriously. The proof is in the just-announced partnership between the artisanal toymaker and Brembo, the high-quality brake specialist.

At the 2015 Concours d'Elegance of America at the Inn at St. John's in Plymouth, Michigan, this weekend, the partnership will make its debut by showing the 2016 lineup of Automoblox vehicles, almost all of which will have Brembo brakes, calipers, and rotors. They'll look just as cool, too, with three different rotor designs and a rainbow of colors like the ones on the real-life Chevrolet Corvette and Cadillac CTS-V and ATS-V. Brembo, of course, has been involved in motorsports since the 1970s, starting by supplying racing brakes to Ferrari in the 1975 Formula 1 World Championship.
Unlike the Cadillac and Corvette, you can mix and match the Brembo brakes on the toy cars with a quick twist-off.

Brembo North America president and CEO Dan Sandberg says one reason for the pairing is to "put Brembo components in the hands of future generations of car buyers." But who is he kidding? Adults can play with Automoblox, too. And we'd recommend it.

The Brembo-equipped 2016 cars won't be out until later in the year, but while waiting, you can have a look at the current Automoblox lineup at www.automoblox.com. Or read our earlier review of the Wish-List-Worthy Toy Cars they make.

title: 2015 Volvo XC70
subTitle: As capable as ever.
promoTeaserSmall: As capable as ever.
promoTeaser: As capable as ever.
metaKeywords: 2015 Volvo XC70; Volvo; SUV; sport-utility; crossover; Swedish
metaDescription: As capable as ever. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive SUV/crossover
Price range: $36,775–$47,825 (includes destination)
Trim levels: T5 Drive-E, 3.2 AWD, T6 AWD
Engines: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 240 horsepower; 3.2-liter inline six-cylinder, 240 horsepower; turbocharged 3.0-liter inline six-cylinder, 300 horsepower
Transmissions: 6- or 8-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 2.0-liter: 24 mpg city/31 mpg highway; 3.0-liter: 17/24 mpg; 3.2-liter: 18/25 mpg
Safety ratings: Not rated
Our favorite standard feature: City Safety collision-avoidance system
Notable standard features on this model: Cruise control, heated side mirrors, dual-zone climate control, Bluetooth, front and rear skid plates, rain-sensing windshield wipers, roof rails
Notable options on this model: Blind-spot warning, active xenon headlights with washers, rear parking sensors, navigation, Harman Kardon sound system
You might also be considering: Acura MDX, BMW X3, Buick Enclave, Lexus GX470

Volvo calls the XC70 an SUV, but it’s really more like a tall, off-road-ready station wagon. With raised ground clearance, skid plates, and scratch-resistant lower side molding, this is a vehicle that is ready to take you just about anywhere you want to go, whether the road is paved or not. And you can carry a lot of stuff with you: With the rear seats folded, the XC70 offers a generous 72.1 cubic feet of cargo space. In some trim levels, the front passenger seat also folds forward, expanding cargo capacity even further.

Volvo has added what it calls Drive-E technology across its lineup, and the XC70 is no exception. What that means is that there is an all-new, 240-horsepower, turbocharged four-cylinder and eight-speed automatic transmission teamed with ECO+, a fuel-saving technology that uses auto stop/start and other measures to improve gas mileage. The four-cylinder is only available with front-wheel drive, however, so anyone planning to use their XC70 for off-road adventures will have to settle for one of the six-cylinder engines, which are paired with all-wheel drive. We suggest skipping the 240-horsepower 3.2-liter unit, which is being phased out across the Volvo lineup, and going for the 300-horsepower, turbocharged 3.0-liter six-cylinder.

The XC70’s interior boasts the same ultra-supportive seats found in every Volvo—anyone with a bad back would do well to give them a test. Ergonomically, the XC70 is hard to beat, with intuitive controls, like the climate controls shaped like a human—press the legs to direct air to the lower extremities, press the head to direct air out the upper vents, etc. Mid-year, Volvo introduced a few new standard features, including a leather-wrapped steering wheel and a six-month subscription for On Call, a smartphone app that allows you to control your car remotely. There is also an overhead button in the cabin, similar to GM’s OnStar, that serves as an SOS should you need emergency assistance.

New for 2015

Revised standard and optional features, and an available 240-horsepower, turbocharged four-cylinder with automatic stop/start technology and an eight-speed automatic transmission.

title: 2016 Hyundai Tucson
subTitle: Strong player in the competitive crossover game.
promoTeaserSmall: Strong player in the competitive crossover game.
promoTeaser: Strong player in the competitive crossover game.
metaDescription: Strong player in the competitive crossover game.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive SUV/crossover
Price range: $22,700–$31,300 (prices include destination charge)
Trim levels: SE, Eco, Sport, Limited
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 164 horsepower; 1.6-liter four-cylinder, 175 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic, seven-speed automatic
Fuel economy: FWD SE: 23 mpg city/31 mpg highway; AWD SE: 21 mpg/26 mpg; FWD ECO: 26 mpg/33 mpg; AWD ECO: 25 mpg/31 mpg; FWD Sport: 25 mpg/30 mpg; AWD Sport: 24 mpg/28 mpg; FWD LTD: 25 mpg/30 mpg; AWD LTD: 24 mpg/ 28 mpg
Safety ratings: Not yet rated by IIHS or NHTSA
Our favorite standard feature: Steering wheel audio control, cruise control, and Bluetooth connecctivity
Notable standard features on this model: Dual-level cargo floor, eight-way power adjustable driver’s seat with power lumbar support (optional on SE), projector headlights with LED accents
Notable options on this model: Cargo cover, windshield wiper de-icer
You might also be considering: Ford Escape, Honda CR-V, Kia Sportage, Toyota RAV4
New for 2016: 1 mpg more fuel efficient, Automatic Emergency Braking

In the ever-growing crossover game, Hyundai’s Tucson remains a reliable option. With 102.2 cubic feet of passenger volume and 31 cubic feet of cargo space, it offers generous space in a surprisingly neat and compact package. There are two engines and transmissions available: six-speed or seven-speed automatic hooked up to either a 2.0-liter four-cylinder or a 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine. You might not take a second look at the standard features, but options like all-wheel drive and a tech package move this model up a few notches on the crossover totem pole. The Popular Equipment package on the SE offers a power driver's seat with lumbar support, LED daytime running lights, roof side rails, and automatic power windows. The Ultimate package amps it up a bit with pedestrian detection, rear parking sensors, and a panoramic sunroof. The 2016 Tucson embodies many of the qualities customers have come to expect from Hyundai: affordability, quality, practicality.

title: 2016 Hyundai Veloster
subTitle: Looks as good as it feels.
promoTeaserSmall: Looks as good as it feels.
promoTeaser: Looks as good as it feels.
metaDescription: Looks as good as it feels.

pageElements.text:
Type: Four-passenger, front-wheel-drive hatchback
Price range: $18,825–$24,625 (prices include destination charge)
Trim levels: Veloster, Turbo R-Spec, Turbo Rally Edition, Turbo
Engines: 1.6-liter four-cylinder, 132 horsepower; turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder, 201 horsepower
Transmissions: Six-speed manual, six-speed dual-clutch automatic, seven-speed dual-clutch automatic
Fuel economy: Six-speed manual: 27 mpg city/35 mpg highway; six-speed automatic: 28/36 mpg
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated
Our favorite standard feature: Rearview camera
Notable standard features on this model: Heated outside mirrors, tilting and telescoping steering wheel, cruise control, remote keyless entry
Notable options on this model: Seven-inch navigation system, push-button start, leather-wrapped steering wheel, panoramic sunroof
You might also be considering: Ford Fiesta ST, Scion xB, Volkswagen Beetle Turbo

The Hyundai Veloster already delivered hard and edgy style, but the 2016 Rally Edition takes it to the next level. A more performance-focused suspension, lightweight wheels, and carbon-fiber-look aero accents give the Rally Edition a sporty feel. All of the planned 1,200 units of this model will come in Matte Blue paint.  There are three choices of transmission: six-speed manual or six-speed and seven-speed dual-clutch automatic. Standard features include heated outside mirrors, a rearview camera, and cruise control. Options include a seven-inch navigation system, push-button start, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, and a panoramic sunroof. The Veloster is a front-wheel-drive hatchback with an undeniably sporty feel and look, one that does not compromise on either style or performance. If you want a popularly priced vehicle that veers a bit off the beaten path, put this on your list.

New for 2016:

Rally Edition

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. pageElements.text: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/dnK7XkhutXk" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Type: Four-passenger, rear-wheel-drive compact hatchback
Trim levels: i3, i3 with Range Extender
Base price: $43,350 for i3; $47,210 for i3 with Range Extender (prices include destination charge)
This car: $52,750
Engine: All-electric motor, 170 horsepower
Transmission: Single-stage automatic
Fuel economy: 117 MPGe; 39 mpg (combined city/highway) on gasoline power
Safety: Not rated
You might also be considering (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Chevrolet Spark EV ($25,995)
2016 Kia Soul EV ($32,775)
2016 Mitsubishi i-MiEV ($23,845)
2015 Nissan Leaf ($29,860)

Fun-O-Meter: 7.5

People buy electric cars for many reasons: environmentalism, futuristic fannishness, a particular kind of acquisitive desire that makes people want to be the first to get the newest technology. But why would people spend almost $50,000 (minus potential federal and local incentives) for a city-car-size electric BMW?

Just open the door and look inside; that’s your first answer. The i3 is a runway model of a car, with an interior that is as big a fashion statement as I’ve seen in a long time. Just a look at the materials list is exciting: a lightweight but strong carbon-fiber-reinforced plastic body—quite unusual for a non-sports car—enclosing interior panels made out of renewable Asian kenaf plants, and topped off by eucalyptus wood trim to complement the soft leather seating. And it’s not just the unusual materials, it’s the manner in which they are arrayed. The eucalyptus sheets are asymmetrically applied and bent in supple curves. The information screen appears to float in midair above the low cowl.
It’s beautiful. It’s inspirational. It’s groundbreaking. All of that, but we’ve seen the larger (and more expensive) i8, which is even more gorgeous.

The BMW i3 was introduced as a 2014 model, the first in the German automaker’s new i sub-brand of electric vehicles. Its passenger cabin is the world’s first mass-produced Carbon Fiber Reinforced Plastic (CFRP) automotive passenger cell. CFRP is as strong as steel, BMW says, yet 50 percent lighter, and 30 percent lighter than aluminum. When you save weight, you save fuel.
The interior materials—lovely as they are—were also chosen for sustainability and recycle status.

Range anxiety, of course, is a big issue with an electric car. BMW addresses that with a range extender at an additional cost of $3,850. The range extender is a generator powered by a little two-cylinder gas engine that comes from a BMW motor scooter. Its job is not to drive the wheels; it’s to kick in when the electricity dips below a certain charge, and then maintain that charge. You can drive a mere seventy-two miles on a charge without it, and double that to 150 miles with it. One caveat: You really don’t want to plan a long trip; the gas engine’s 1.9-gallon capacity will have you stopping for tiny little fill-ups every, oh, seventy-five miles or so. I would say put the range extender at the top of your optional equipment list.

Then you’ll want to accessorize with the BMW iCharging station for your garage, at another additional cost ($1,080) that doesn’t include installation. It has a twenty-five-foot cord. Using it will cut charging time down to a reasonable 3.5 hours from the unaided charge time of “forever” when using a standard 110-volt household outlet.

As long as you’re using it for short jaunts, that’s no problem. It’s perhaps unfair to quibble, since you’d expect a car this small to be more of a city car, but I’m here to say that it completely handles the freeway. It is able to blow by the surrounding traffic with ease, in the all-in way that electric vehicles give you everything they have the second you hit the go pedal. The difference between lesser electrics and the i3 is that you don’t feel like it’s going to explode because you’re going too fast at 70 mph. What did happen in my test car at a steady 70 mph was a small but disconcerting side-to-side front-end drift. Most irksome.

It was enough for me to set our Fun-O-Meter at 7.5. When could that ever happen in the Perfect 10 world of the BMW driving experience? Only, perhaps, in this case, because a gorgeous interior and heady acceleration do not make up for the drawbacks of permanently thrumming range anxiety and that very un-BMW-like on-center drift. In city driving, though, the fun jumps to a solid 9.5.

The i3 I drove was well equipped, although still not fully loaded, even at $47,210. It featured the Giga World package ($1,500), which adds keyless entry, a universal garage door opener, and a set of 19-inch alloy wheels. Its stunner of a Solar Orange/Frozen Grey two-tone paint job was an additional $500. The Tech + Driving Assist package ($2,500) gives you navigation, adaptive cruise control, BMW online and BMW apps, and advanced real-time traffic information. Not present on our i3 were a Harman Kardon sound system ($800) or a set of 20-inch alloy wheels ($1,300).

It’s questionable, the value of spending this kind of money for an EV when gas prices seem to be on a lowering trend. As a consumer vehicle, the i3 is the most expensive car in its class by a long shot. Certainly there is the Tesla Model S, at $75,000 before incentives, but other electric-powered competitors—the Nissan Leaf, the Chevrolet Volt, the Toyota Prius Plug-in, and EV versions of the Chevrolet Spark and the Kia Soul—are much more popularly priced in the mid-$20,000s-to-low-$30,000s range.

The BMW i3s you might see in the wild will be rare birds indeed. But they will most definitely stand out from the more common Volts and Leafs and Priuses and Sparks, which will go by unnoticed. Discerning owners of the i3 will appreciate that, you can be sure.

But now and then, every i3 driver should leave the confines of the urban hood and take to the highway just to experience that instantaneous, full-on blast of the i3’s mashed-foot-pedal, absolutely electric acceleration.
Get a little extra bang for those fifty thousand bucks.

The 2016 Acura ILX brings value and affordability to the sport-sedan class. Competing against popular choices including the Audi A3 and the Mercedes-Benz CLA-Class, the ILX offers a comparable level of luxury and sophistication at a reasonable price. Also, feel free to gawk at that fuel efficiency: 25 mpg city, 36 mpg highway. This sedan has a 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine producing 201 horsepower mated to an eight-speed dual-clutch transmission. The standard features on this vehicle drive home the overall theme of value. Heated front seats with driver’s eight-way power adjustment, push-button ignition, a five-inch color information display, and a rearview camera are standard. Some of the latest safety features are optional: a collision mitigation system, adaptive cruise control, and navigation. Bottom line, the ILX will deliver tasteful and comfortable bang for your sensible buck.

New for 2016: 2.4-liter engine, AcuraWatch safety and driver-assistive features

2016 Acura ILX: Introduced at Los Angeles Auto Show

The Encore may be a five-passenger crossover, but it is refreshingly, surprisingly compact. For those looking for utility without bulk, it's an intriguing choice. There are two 1.4-liter engine options. One produces 138 horsepower, the other 153. Its fuel efficiency bests that of the Enclave by about eight mph. As far as features go, Buick did not skimp. OnStar, cruise control, ambient lighting, rearview camera, full-color display, and leather-wrapped steering wheel all come standard. The optional convenience package will provide rear cross traffic alert and side blind zone alert, among other safety boosters. For 2016, there is a new Sport Touring model that has appearance upgrades for a sportier look, including special eighteen-inch aluminum wheels and a winged rear spoiler.

New for 2016: Encore Sport Touring with exclusive 1.4-liter turbo and stop/start technology, plus winged rear spoiler, and special eighteen-inch aluminum wheels; new River Rock Metallic, Graphite Gray Metallic, and Summit White exterior colors

The X6's size and shape beg the questions: Is it a coupe? A hatchback? A crossover? According to BMW, it's a Sports Activity Vehicle, and that might be the most suitable name for it.  Changes for 2016 are largely confined to electronics and feature upgrades. The 2016 xDrive50i now comes with four-zone automatic climate control and a one-year satellite radio subscription. The sporting M package adds $3,900 to the price.  If your tastes fall more on the unusual side – unusual being a relative term when talking about BMW – and you don’t blink at a $60,000 plus price, the X6 could be your next wagon.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive coupe or sedan
Price ranges: Sedan: $34,210–$50,205; coupe: $38,990–$51,320; ATS-V sedan $61,460; ATS-V coupe $63,660 (prices include destination charge)
Trim levels: Standard, Luxury, Performance, Premium, ATS-V
Engines: 2.5-liter four-cylinder, 202 horsepower, turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 272 horsepower; 3.6-liter V-6, 321 horsepower
Transmissions: Six-speed manual, eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 2.5-liter: 21 mpg city/33 mpg highway; 2.0-liter, automatic: 21/30 mpg; 2.0-liter, manual: 19/30 mpg; 2.0-liter, automatic, AWD: 20/28 mpg; 3.6-liter, RWD: 18/28 mpg; 3.6-liter, AWD: 18/26 mpg
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated
Our favorite standard feature: New eight-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters
Notable standard features on this model: Push-button start, Bost premium audio with SirusXM
Notable options on this model: Wireless phone charging, Cadillac Cue infotainment with Natural Voice Recognition and Apple CarPlay, head-up display, lane departure warning with lane keeping assist, Brembo performance brakes
You might also be considering: BMW 3 Series, Mercedes-Benz C-Class

The 2016 Cadillac ATS is the Cadillac aesthetic, writ small. For the price of an ordinary sedan, you can get the lively styling and the invigorating driving credentials of a Cadillac, and that's the whole point of the ATS. For 2016, there's an all-new 3.6-liter V-6 with cylinder deactivation and stop/start technology to save fuel. Even bigger news is the arrival of the twin-turbo ATS-V performance version as a coupe or sedan, upping the ATS desirability level considerably. You get a choice of normally aspirated or turbocharged four-cylinder engines along with that V-6, and there are sedan and coupe body styles to choose from. All engines come with an eight-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters. On the ATS-V, a six-speed manual transmission is standard, while the eight-speed automatic is a $2,000 option.

Much of the enjoyment of this car, of course, will come from personalizing it. To that end, Cadillac offers four levels of interior olor and trim that leans heavily on two-tone color schemes—Light Platinum/Black, Kona Brown/Black, Medium Cashmere/Light Platinum, for example—and interesting materials and textures. There's oil-rubbed "bronze appearance" trim, carbon fiber, metal plating, high-gloss Sapele wood, and more, not to mention semi-aniline leather, sueded microfiber, and leatherette seating material choices. On the technology front, you'll find a full-color head-up display, a 5.7-inch instrument panel display with three windows, OnStar with 4G LTE on-board Wi-Fi, and Cadillac's Cue infotainment on an eight-inch touchscreen, compatible with Apple CarPlay and, later in the model year, Android Auto.

For active safety, choose the Safety and Security package on the Luxury trim level, or the Driver Awareness package on the Performance and Premium models. Among the technology features are the fabled GM Safety Alert Seat, which gives you a little buzz in the leg if you're about to veer out of your lane, along with forward collision alert, side blind zone and lane change alerts, rear cross-traffic alert, and rain-sensing wipers. An even higher level of active safety comes with the Driver Assist package for Performance and Premium models ($2,885), which includes full-speed-range adaptive cruise control and front and rear automatic braking. The latter is something that the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, along with GM and nine other automakers, is vowing to make standard on all vehicles in the not-too-distant future. On the Cadillac ATS, you can have it right now, if you want.

New for 2016:

ATS-V performance model, coupe and sedan
3.8-liter V-6 engine with stop/start and cylinder deactivation
Apple CarPlay and (late availability) Android Auto for smartphone app connectivity

More about the Cadillac ATS

2015 Cadillac ATS Coupe Designer Walkround January 24, 2014
