pageElements.text: I have a front-row seat in the unfolding Volkswagen diesel drama.

I not only own a 2015 VW Golf SportWagen TDI, I sold a 2013 VW Jetta SportWagen TDI to a good friend on the East Coast. So, I now realize, we are both out here whooping it up in our mega-mileage VW wagons while spewing pollutants all over our respective woods, fields, and wetlands.

To recap from last Friday’s official EPA news release, the Fed alleges that “four-cylinder VW or Audi diesel cars from model years 2009-2015 include software that circumvents EPA emissions standards for certain air pollutants.” At first blush, it just sounds pathetic. Dig deeper, and it becomes much more cynical and calculating.

The Notice of Violation claims that “a sophisticated software algorithm...detects when the car is undergoing official emissions testing, and turns full emissions controls on only during the test.” The rest of the time, the emissions controls are virtually useless emitting “nitrogen oxides at up to 40 times the standard.”

The emissions defeat device software was discovered when researchers from West Virginia University and the International Council on Clean Transportation raised questions about high emissions levels during independent analysis. EPA and CARB began their own investigation, and in September after they “demanded an explanation for the identified emissions problems," Volkswagen admitted that the cars contained defeat devices.
Appalling, pathetic, cynical, and calculating. And they’ve been caught, the too-clever-by-half cheaters. How embarrassing is this?

Before I get too carried away by the automotive scandal of the month (and too bad for any auto company that had good news breaking this week), I’m going to sit back and see just how much the Wolfsburghers have learned from watching General Motors stumble through its own morass of secrecy, complicity, and cover-up, a nightmare that is far from over, despite a reported tally to date of $2.3 billion in fines, repairs, and lawsuits. Far, far from over.

For VW, every hour seems to bring new revelations, accusations, and questions—not just 500,000 U.S. cars, but as many as 11 million around the world. Not just the 2.0-liter diesel engines, but possibly other VW diesels as well. Who knew what and when? Martin Winterkorn, chairman of the board of management and CEO of VW AG (and oh by the way, also head of VW R&D since 2007) has resigned. Will he be replaced by the U.S. head of Porsche, Matthias Muller? How much will this cost Volkswagen? And, will this be the death knell for the diesel in the U.S.?
I have skin in this game. I’ll be back as news develops with a recap.
Love, Jean

title: 5 Cool Things: Internet in the Car
subTitle: Survey says you want to be connected while you drive. AT&T and others are happy to oblige.
promoTitle: 5 Cool Things: Internet in the Car
promoTeaserSmall: Survey says you want to be connected while you drive. AT&T and others are happy to oblige.
promoTeaser: Survey says you want to be connected while you drive. AT&T and others are happy to oblige.
keywords: 5 Cool Things: Internet in the Car
metaTitle: 5 Cool Things: Internet in the Car - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Survey says you want to be connected while you drive. AT&T and others are happy to oblige.

pageElements.text: Is Wi-Fi completely indispensable to your life yet? If you say no, chances are you have never taken a long trip with a car full of teenagers. Or found yourself stopping at fast-food joints far too often to catch up with your work on the computer. That may be about to change. Many automakers have started incorporating on-board wireless into their new models. AT&T and phone supplier Ericsson just released a survey that shows almost four out of five car shoppers are willing to wait a year to buy a car, if it means they can get connectivity on board. Even if you're not that patient—or not in the market at this moment—the study also shows that this is the most desired feature on a new car.

At first glance, it's another one of those modern "improvements" that seem easy to resist. We're guessing, however, that it won't be very many years before the idea of on-board Wi-Fi is considered as essential to the inside of your car as air conditioning or power windows. Here, then, are our five cool things about being connected in the car.
AT&T and Ericsson just released a survey that shows four out of five car shoppers are willing to wait a year to buy a car, if it means they can get Internet on board.

1. You get a stronger signal. That's because you are running your Wi-Fi through the car's antenna, in essence using the vehicle like a big metal connecting box, Joe Mosele of AT&T explained. Mosele showed off his company's 4G LTE wireless connection in a Cadillac Escalade, explaining that wireless speed is "significantly better" if you use the embedded Wi-Fi in the car versus going through your smartphone.

2. You won't have to buy an expensive optional (or aftermarket) entertainment system. Bonus: everybody is not forced to watch the same movie, and you don't have to pack DVDs for your trip to the soccer field or vacation spot that make a bunch of noise but can only be viewed by those in the second row. You have no idea how many Disney movies I've only listened to but never seen. With on-board wireless, you can stream from your Netflix account, or everybody can catch up on email and homework assignments while the driver enjoys some peace and quiet.

3. You can be so much more efficient, in your own time and space. Whether it's a driven college student with a paper to finish, or a business owner pulling in to a parking lot to send a few quick emails on the laptop, it's all so much easier to do right inside your own car, at your convenience and where you wish. Wouldn't you rather be doing all that when sitting by the lake than in a McDonald's? And with no fear of being kicked off the Internet after a half-hour at peak times, as happens in some of the joints I've stopped in? Bonus: AT&T's 4G LTE works for a fifty-foot radius around the car.

4. You don't have to pay for navigation on your new car. Not if you have a smartphone and on-board Wi-Fi. If your car has Apple CarPlay or Android Apps, you can run navigation right off your phone and onto the infotainment screen in your car. If not, you can still run it from your smartphone using the car's Wi-Fi.

5. It's not actually very expensive. Popular brands like Chevrolet (along with the other General Motors brands) already have on-board Wi-Fi hot spots. Others will follow. On GM vehicles, you can add the 4G LTE into your existing OnStar subscription, but AT&T says that most consumers surveyed said they'd prefer to add the cost of on-board Wi-Fi to their existing mobile phone plans. For those who have shared data plans like AT&T's Mobile Share, your vehicle can become another data user on the same plan, making your added expense close to unnoticeable. Or you can buy a Tesla: the electric-car maker picks up the cost of data used by owners in its cars.

Wireless in the car is far from universal, but Jaguar Land Rover, Audi, and General Motors are all on board already, and others are coming. AT&T says it will have more than 10 million vehicles on its network before the end of 2017—and they added almost a million in the second quarter of 2015 alone—so the likeliness is growing that you'll be able to get a car with the Internet on board very soon.

title: Which Cars Have Wireless Phone Charging?
subTitle: Want to charge your phone in the car? Sick of messing with cords? Here are your current choices.
promoTitle: Which Cars Have Wireless Phone Charging?
promoTeaserSmall: Want to charge your phone in the car? Sick of messing with cords? Here are your current choices.
promoTeaser: Want to charge your phone in the car? Sick of messing with cords? Here are your current choices.
keywords: which cars have wireless phone charging
metaTitle: Which Cars Have Wireless Phone Charging? - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Want to charge your phone in the car? Sick of messing with cords? Here are your current choices.

pageElements.text: You know the drill. You get in the car, you reach for your phone to plug it in and charge it, and then you realize you forgot the cord. Or your cord, for some reason, isn’t quite working. (They do that.) Or you want to use the phone, but first you have to wrestle with the charge cord. All far too low tech when you’re charging a $300 phone in a $30,000 vehicle, don’t you think?

Many automakers are responding to the seemingly limitless need to charge smartphones by providing wireless charging pads. They’re so much easier to manage in the car. Just drop your phone onto the surface, and the charging happens with no further intervention from you.

Wireless charging works through communication between a transmitter built into the charging mat and a corresponding one in the smartphone. Apple’s iPhones aren’t wireless charging ready, although an increasing number of Android phones are. If yours is not, you will need a special case or attachment from your friendly Best Buy, wireless carrier, or other technology supplier.
There’s no doubt wireless charging is the direction charging is going, so why not be an early adopter?

1. Cadillac

What models have it? All 2016 Cadillac models except SRX
The luxury arm of General Motors rolled out wireless charging on the 2015 ATS and now offers it on every 2016 model except the SRX as standard equipment. Visit the Cadillac website for full details and information on whether your smartphone is compatible.

2. Chevrolet

What models have it? 2016 Impala, Malibu, Volt, Cruze
The populist automaker has just introduced something nobody else has (yet): Active Phone Cooling, which has a vent to direct air from the car’s A/C system to the charging pad. You already know that heat is very bad for your phone’s battery, and charging pads can be hot; this is intended to fix that problem.

3. Dodge and Chrysler

What models have it? Dodge Caravan R/T, Dart, Viper, Ram; Chrysler 200 and Town & Country
In this case, the wireless charging mat is supplied by the automaker’s Mopar aftermarket company. The purchase of the vehicle comes with a voucher that you redeem for a special case for your smartphone. See the details here.

4. GMC

What models have it? 2016 Yukon and Yukon XL (SLT and Denali models)
Wireless phone charging is standard on the uplevel SLT and Denali versions of the Yukon/Yukon XL SUV. Visit https://my.gmc.com/learn/wirelessCharging/ for full details and information on whether your smartphone is compatible. Watch a demonstration:

5. Jeep

What models have it? Cherokee (Limited and Altitude models)
Wireless charging has been available on the Cherokee since 2014. It’s different technology than the Mopar products on Chrysler and Dodge vehicles, even though they have the same parent company. You select it as an option with the Uconnect infotainment system.

6. Lexus

What models have it? LX570, NX200t (standard and F Sport), NX300h
The wireless charger is a $220 option on these select Lexus models. The center console holds a tray with an indicator light to tell you when your phone is fully charged.

7. Toyota

What models have it? Avalon, Camry, Land Cruiser, Prius, Tacoma
Toyota’s wireless charging tray is similar to that of its corporate sibling Lexus: there’s an amber light while charging is in progress, and a green light once the phone is fully charged. Watch a demonstration here.

images.caption: Chevrolet wireless charger with Active Phone Cooling.

image.altText: 2016 Chevrolet Suburban Full Size Suv Design 1035X440 004

pageElements.text: You know, when you look at GM's photo of a Suburban with an entire kayak comfortably fitted inside, that you are looking at a seriously capable hauler. But the 2016 Chevrolet Suburban is more than just the sum of its practical parts; it's a major lifestyle choice, one that gives you some of the latest and best connectivity and safety—and luxury—along with its capaciousness. Available in rear- or all-wheel-drive versions, the Suburban doesn't come cheap, and it doesn't sip gasoline, but if you need to carry up to nine people, tow a boat, or put a kayak inside the vehicle, there's virtually no substitute.

In addition to the wireless hot spot provided by OnStar 4G LTE wireless technology, you can get a foot-operated power liftgate, a set of six-spoke twenty-two-inch wheels, and power-release second- and third-row seats.

New in 2016

Forward collision alert, lane keeping assist, and safety alert seat all available in Enhanced Driver Alert package, a bargain at $695 on LS (standard on LT and LTZ)
LTZ gets digital head-up display as a no-cost option
Apple CarPlay with enhanced Chevrolet MyLink smartphone integration
Two new colors: Siren Red and Iridescent Pearl Tricoat

title: 2016 Toyota RAV4 Hybrid
subTitle: Now there's a new choice for the hybrid buyer in the popular SUV's lineup.
promoTeaserSmall: Now there's a new choice for the hybrid buyer in the popular SUV's lineup.
promoTeaser: Now there's a new choice for the hybrid buyer in the popular SUV's lineup.
metaDescription: Now there's a new choice for the hybrid buyer in the popular SUV's lineup.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text:
Type: All-wheel-drive, five-passenger, four-door crossover utility vehicle
Trim levels: Hybrid XLE, Hybrid Limited
Base price: $34,510 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $36,560
Engine: 2.5-liter four-cylinder with electric motor, 194 combined horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic
Fuel economy: 34 mpg city/31 mpg highway/33 mpg combined
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated
Favorite standard feature: Height-adjustable power liftgate
Notable standard features on this model: Trailer sway control, hill start assist, eighteen-inch alloy wheels, LED exterior lighting, heated outside mirrors with integrated turn signal and blind-spot warning indicators, blind spot monitor with rear cross-traffic alert, Toyota Safety Sense suite of driver-assistance features, seven-inch touchscreen, Bluetooth and iPod connectivity, premium audio
You might also be considering: Honda CR-V, Ford Escape, Hyundai Tucson, Kia Sportage, Chevrolet Equinox

Twenty years ago, the Toyota RAV4 helped to change our way of thinking about compact vehicles. As a “cute ute,” the RAV4 offered a high seating position, great maneuverability, and more utility than compact sedans. And it was indeed cute, even with its carbuncle of a spare tire on the tailgate.
Now the RAV4 Hybrid joins the lineup. It’s the first time a gasoline/electric hybrid powertrain is offered in the lineup of the popular compact crossover utility vehicle.
The new Hybrid model, available in XLE and Limited trim and arriving now in dealerships, joins a refreshed 2016 RAV4 lineup that incorporates comprehensive improvements and revised styling.
For those who love command seating, need all-wheel drive, and like the idea of an efficient hybrid powertrain, the 2016 Toyota RAV4 Hybrid is an interesting new choice.

For those who love command seating, who need all-wheel drive, and who like the idea of an efficient hybrid powertrain but find the Toyota Highlander Hybrid too big or expensive, the 2016 Toyota RAV4 Hybrid is an interesting new choice. There was previously a RAV4 EV, but the Hybrid doesn’t make that battery-electric vehicle’s compromises. In fact, in addition to class-leading fuel economy of 33 mpg combined, the RAV4 Hybrid is quicker out of the gate and has greater towing capacity than its gasoline-powered siblings.
“We think we’re going to broaden our appeal in a really hot segment,” said Bill Fay, Toyota’s general manager.

The RAV4 Hybrid’s 33 mpg is noteworthy. I recall a 4,500-mile road trip in the original RAV4. It was dainty and lightweight, with a smaller engine, yet it slurped fuel and was as loud as Van Halen. Compared with other 2016 RAV4 all-wheel-drive models, the Hybrid gets about 32 percent better fuel economy in city driving.  
	
Basic revisions to the 2016 RAV4 results in a stiffer body, better braking and steering response, and more supple suspension. Our test vehicle, a top-of-the-line Hybrid Limited, was quiet and smooth.

Rather than a clockwork mechanical system, the on-demand all-wheel-drive cleverly distributes driving forces using electric motors in front and rear and selectively engaging the wheels as road conditions change. The benefit is being rid of the pushy front-drive effect that takes you to the outside of the turn under acceleration.

The surprising news is that the Hybrid offers increased performance beyond fuel economy. The dash from 0 to 60 mph takes 8.1 seconds, which Toyota says is about one second quicker than non-hybrid models. And it tows a 1,750-pound trailer, compared with 1,500 pounds for non-hybrid models. By the way, trailer sway control is standard with the Limited, so you have less reason to fear crosswinds and sudden lane changes when hitched to your personal watercraft or utility trailer.

The continuously variable automatic transmission has six ranges that can be manually selected by moving the shifter into the Sport setting, but I couldn’t figure out the point of it and stayed with full automatic mode. An EV mode lets the driver creep along on battery power for six-tenths of a mile at speeds below 25 mph.

There is some slight downside to the Hybrid. The nickel-metal hydride battery pack and electric motors add 320 pounds, bringing the Hybrid Limited to just shy of 4,000 pounds. And you bet the added mass was noticeable on California Route 74, the Ortega Highway, which curved first through housing developments beyond San Juan Capistrano, then through sycamores and oaks along Caspers Wilderness Park, finally delivering us to the Ortega Oaks Candy Store and Goods (“Holiday Orders Welcome”) in the Santa Ana Mountains.

Oh, by the way, because of the battery pack behind the rear bench, the Hybrid’s cargo area is about two percent smaller than the standard RAV4, at 70.6 cubic feet. That difference means the seat backs don’t quite fold flat. We use our utility vehicles for nearly every conceivable purpose and think it’s a big tradeoff. For example, Giovanni the Italian Spinone’s car kennel might not fit.

People at the candy store distinguished the RAV4 Hybrid Limited from merely gas-powered LE, XLE, Limited, and the new SE models by its unique eighteen-inch alloy wheels (seventeen-inch on Hybrid XLE) and wide Bridgestone Ecopia tires. It had an assertive stance, a large semi-elliptical expanse of glass on the side, and an overall look that’s more suggestive of mall crawling than trail running. The latter is the Toyota 4Runner’s job. Our car wore a sparkling coat of Blizzard Pearl paint and had standard full LED exterior lighting. Blue-accented badges are also unique to the Hybrid.

The upgraded cabin trim looks terrific on the whole 2016 RAV4 lineup, but we were unimpressed with the soggy feel when we pulled open the cargo area’s cover. Under the cargo floor, there’s a full-size (seventeen inch) spare tire, which allows the fitting of a traditional liftgate instead of the swing-out tailgate of 1996. The power close button and six-setting height-adjustable operation are big advances.

Whereas the Hybrid XLE has cloth upholstery, the Hybrid Limited had lovely cinnamon-and-black SofTex simulated leather upholstery with white stitching. The lower part of the dashboard, which is covered in the same material, sweeps away toward the passenger door, enhancing the open and spacious feel. The a new 4.2-inch display between dials in instrument cluster is included in Hybrid XLE and Limited models. The bright, touch-sensitive 7-inch central screen is included in the Limited, available in XLE, and it’s a jim-dandy for how it splits displays and can be customized.

The Limited included an optional eleven-speaker JBL audio system. Its merits include remarkable sharpness, door-rumbling bass, and spacing that gave the feeling of being amid the audience in a live recording. Naturally, there’s an impressive level of connectivity and voice recognition.

Toyota Safety Sense, a new suite of driver assistance features, is standard in the Hybrid Limited and an option in the Hybrid LXE. It combines a pre-collision braking system with pedestrian detection, lane departure alert with steering assist, automatic high beams, and radar-governed cruise control. A blind spot monitor with rear cross-traffic alert was also included. The optional bird’s-eye 360-degree camera is the cherry on top of the cake.

Revised styling gives all 2016 RAV4 models a gawky, Abstract Expressionist front end and a slightly ducktailed rear, but we think we’ll get used to it. The driving experience is pleasant, and 33 mpg will be easy to endure. Toyota’s hybrid system still whines when the regenerative braking function engages, reminding us of streetcars and the trains that run between airport terminals. But this, too, is endurable.

The RAV4 Hybrid Limited represents a lot of value, with premium touches that suggest a trickle-down from Lexus. Toyota offers seven other hybrid models, but the RAV4 is expected to attract 30,000 to 45,000 buyers per year—maybe even you.

title: 2017 Fiat 124 Spider
subTitle: Italian answer to the Mazda Miata is coming next summer.
promoTeaserSmall: Italian answer to the Mazda Miata is coming next summer.
promoTeaser: Italian answer to the Mazda Miata is coming next summer.
metaKeywords: Fiat at Los Angeles Auto Show
metaDescription: Italian answer to the Mazda Miata is coming next summer.

pageElements.text:
Type: Two-passenger front-engine, rear-wheel-drive roadster
Release date: Summer 2016
Estimated price range: $26,000 to $35,000
Competes against: Mazda MX-5 Miata
What's most interesting: Italianate interpretation of Japanese design

Ever since the new Mazda MX-5 Miata made its debut, we’ve been waiting for its Italian counterpart, and here, at last, it is. Unveiled at the L.A. Auto Show, the Fiat 124 Spider revives a cherished name from the past with a design that draws its inspiration from the 1967 Pinin Farina original. But while the sheetmetal is all Fiat, most of the subdural elements of the new two seater—chassis and suspension design—are Mazda.

The key difference lies under the hood, which shelters Fiat’s turbocharged 1.4-liter four-cylinder, rated for 160 horsepower—about the same as the Miata’s non-turbo 2.0-liter, but with considerably more torque: 180 pound-feet. That’s important, because the fetching Fiat interpretation of the roadster is substantially bigger than the tightly wrapped Miata—five inches longer—and substantially heavier: the basic Spider with six-speed manual transmission weighs about 100 pounds more than the Mazda version.

To lovers of Italian style, this probably won’t matter. There will be two models, the basic Classico and the uplevel Lusso (Italian for luxury). With the on-sale date still a half-year away—the roadster will reach Fiat’s U.S. showrooms next summer as a 2017 model—pricing is still a guess.
But with its more luxurious persona, expect it to be higher than its Miata cousin.

pageElements.text:
Type: Four-door, five-passenger sedan
Release date: Late 2016 as 2017 model
Estimated price: $22,000
Competes against: Honda Civic, Ford Focus, Chevrolet Cruze
What’s most interesting: Unprecedented aggressiveness of Subaru design
Subaru will no longer play nice. So we conclude from the new Impreza, billed as a concept car but sure to closely foreshadow the 2017 model.
One problem with the Impreza was lack of availability. That will change soon, as factory space becomes available. Then, everywhere, we will see this handsome sedan.

This compact sedan had the temerity to roll onto the stage, give several hundred people a dirty look, and then just sit there in a cloak of blazing carmine, all self-satisfied about its prospects. And why shouldn’t it be? One problem with the Impreza was lack of availability. That will change soon, as new factory space in Indiana becomes available. Then, everywhere, we will see this handsome little sedan. It is simple and unfussy. Yasuyuki Yoshinaga, president and CEO of Subaru’s parent company, Fuji Heavy Industries, said it’s a “design carved out of hard rigid materials.” And it’s “fused with dynamism.”

The so-called hawkeye headlamps, the highlight of a perfectly composed face, indicate fury. Maybe the car has been following the news. In silhouette, the Impreza looks more like a coupe. Oh, wait, it has rear doors! Character builds through the line that arcs over the front wheel and dips into the door, becoming the bottom lip of a sensuous concavity. It comes off as original, uncontrived, and appealing. Even the large wheels have a sculptural quality with satin, black, and red in a unique combination.

We admire the effort. Combining what we saw with the Impreza’s known hallmarks—efficient four-cylinder engine, turbocharging technology, and all-wheel drive at a modest price—we proclaim our excitement about this concept and eagerly await its production.

title: 2017 Cadillac XT5
subTitle: Understated, for a Cadillac, but with all the luxury touches you'd expect.
promoTeaserSmall: Understated, for a Cadillac, but with all the luxury touches you'd expect.
promoTeaser: Understated, for a Cadillac, but with all the luxury touches you'd expect.
metaKeywords: Cadillacs at Los Angeles Auto Show
metaDescription: Understated, for a Cadillac, but with all the luxury touches you'd expect.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive luxury crossover
Release date: Spring 2016
Estimated price: $40,000
Competes against: Audi Q5, Acura RDX, BMW X3, Infiniti QX50, Lexus RX, Lincoln MKX
What’s most interesting: Rear Camera Mirror system with video display

The luxury crossover formerly known as the SRX has been replaced with this all-new model named the XT5 (which, according to Cadillac, stands for crossover touring five-seater). Cadillac crossovers are going to get the XT designation from now on. This one is lighter (by a not inconsiderable 278 pounds) and more spacious for rear-seat passengers than the outgoing model. It's also, we should mention, better-looking, and it has ridiculous levels of technology on board.

"A feeling of space is the ultimate luxury," said global design chief Andrew Smith, and especially in a crossover, that makes perfect sense. To that end, the lines and surfaces inside the XT5 are clean and—for a Cadillac—relatively unadorned.

Cadillac's Cue infotainment system gets an upgrade for the XT5, featuring a faster processor—you'll just have to try it out and see if you think so—plus a wireless phone charger in the center console, 4G LTE making it a wireless hot spot, and Apple CarPlay and Android Auto smartphone integration. There's an optional head-up display and LED lighting inside and out—although full LED headlamps are optional.

The XT5 gets the same new 3.6-liter V-6 engine that's in the 2016 ATS, CTS, and brand-new top-of-the-line CT6 sedan. It makes 310 horsepower and is teamed with an eight-speed automatic transmission, also new. The XT5 is front-wheel drive, but an all-wheel-drive model is available.

There's a full slate of safety technology. Most notable is the Rear Camera Mirror system, which shows streaming video over the rearview mirror that has been corrected to keep from showing passengers, rear pillars, and roof images. This is claimed to increase the driver's rear vision by 300 percent, but not to worry—those passengers are still there. Lane keeping assist, full-speed-range adaptive cruise control, rear cross-traffic and side blind zone alerts, and automatic parking assist are all standard.

title: 12 Gifts for People Who Love Cars
subTitle: It’s that time again! Our picks of the most fun, frivolous, and fantastic for gift givers.
promoTitle: 12 Gifts for People Who Love Cars
promoTeaserSmall: It’s that time again! Our picks of the most fun, frivolous, and fantastic for gift givers.
promoTeaser: It’s that time again! Our picks of the most fun, frivolous, and fantastic for gift givers.
keywords: 12 Gifts for People Who Love Cars
metaTitle: 12 Gifts for People Who Love Cars - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: It’s that time again! Our picks of the most fun, frivolous, and fantastic for gift givers.

pageElements.text:
1. Tools for car and home to die for
Sonic Tools USA, $1.51 to $1,899.99
Women can do anything if they learn how to use the tools. And what beautiful tools Sonic makes!! Our visiting college freshman spontaneously threw herself on the floor to unbox this shipment Jean ordered. Beautiful to view, each arrayed in its own labeled spot carved from dense foam. Substantial heft, clever designs, ergonomic perfection. On Jean’s wish list (yes, she signed on to the site): A bright red ¼” disc ratchet ($22.99) that fits in your palm for working in tight spots. Stubby screwdrivers, one slotted, one Phillips head ($1.51). The 16-in-1 ratchet screwdriver ($45.99). The amazing flash pen ($43.99). The sweet utility knife ($12.99). The 91-piece filled suitcase toolbox ($1,399.99). Must have more!!! Trolling for sponsors...

2. Original portrait of a car, motorcycle, or boat
Wirth Motor Company, $395
If you know someone whose car is their most loved possession—or if you are that person—an original portrait may be in order. Iowa artist Tim Wirth paints profile views of cars, each placed in a special landscape. The vehicle’s year, model name, even nickname are hand painted on top of the frame. Each portrait measures 17 by 17 inches and comes in a handmade white pine frame, ready to hang. The work takes six to eight weeks, but that just means you can give a gift certificate and let the lucky recipient get some input into the commissioned work.

3. For the person who wants total garage door control
MyQ Garage, $129.99
You know about apps that will lock or start your car, apps that will check that you remembered to turn off the porch light, and now, an app to open and close the garage door. Those of you who never know what to get Mom and Dad, here you go. Or, for any techie or frequent traveler who wants to control the garage door using a smartphone, MyQ Garage is just the thing. It’s an easy-to-mount door sensor that works with a free app, and it uses the house’s Wi-Fi to operate the garage door.

4. Glovebox-size jumper cable replacement
Cobra JumPack, $119.95
A ten-ounce battery pack that will jump-start a dead battery, charge your phone, and also serve as a flashlight? That’s the claim of Cobra’s JumPack lithium-cobalt battery pack, which has peak current of 360 amps and a set of jumper cables to use it with, plus a 2.4-amp USB to charge phones and other devices. It also has an LED flashlight function that strobes in case you’re stuck at the side of the road. Cobra claims it holds up to 90 percent of its charge for up to eight months.

5. A giant bow for that car you’re buying your sweetheart
Dodson Group, up to $76.50
A four-foot-wide red velvet magnetic bow for that new car you’re gifting this year? Here’s where you can get one. They’re sold by Dodson Group, supplier to auto dealers, but individual orders are OK, or they’re on Amazon.com from the same source. The velvet one in red costs $76.50; you need to order from Dodson before Dec. 16 if you want it for Christmas.

6. A personal electric blanket for the car
Car Cozy, $39.99
Your car has a heater, you say? You still haven’t lived (nor have your back-seat passengers) until you’ve had this warm blanket to snuggle up to on a wintry car trip. It plugs into the 12V outlet in the car and has auto shutoff, so you don’t have to worry about your kids or grandma falling asleep with it on. Beyond mere relaxation, think of the perks of having it in a traffic stoppage or other emergency situation. Watch a video to see it in use.

7. A keychain-mounted tool kit
Ringtool, $28.00
This was originally designed for cyclists to keep them from having to cart around a full-size set of tools. Well, who wants to cart around a full-size set of tools, even if they’re driving something much bigger? This will keep you minimally supplied, in style, with a variety of tools from spoke wrenches to screwdrivers to hex heads and even a bottle cap opener on a ring of hardened stainless steel. You can even use it as a drill bit in a pinch. Made in New York, and approved for getting through security by the TSA.

8. An interactive book for young car fans
How Cars Work, $19.99
British historian Nick Arnold is the author of many fine works for the mechanically minded kid, such as How Machines Work and the Horrible Science series. With How Cars Work, he outdoes himself as he demystifies ten essential systems on a car. The book comes with heavy cardboard miniatures of the components so kids can build their own as they read. Gearbox, steering, exhaust valves, suspension, brakes, and more yield their secrets in simple, everyday language. Hey, maybe your teenage driver trainee should be reading this. Maybe you should, too.

9. Parent-and-child gear and books
Little Red Racing Car, $17.99 and up
Some of the best and most beautiful story books about cars come from the fertile mind of Carpe Viam’s (“seize the road”) Dwight Knowlton. In addition to The Little Red Racing Car and The Greatest Race, you can buy his adult-and-child matching T-shirts that say PLAYS WITH CARS (for the kid) and STILL PLAYS WITH CARS (for the grownup), $33.99 for the pair. The website lets you make and download free posters and blueprints, too.

10. Best anthology of car stories ever
Road Trips, Head Trips, and Other Car-Crazed Writing, $14
Our own Jean Jennings gathered some of the best car stories ever written in this 258-page book that features brilliant tales by authors from Jack Kerouac to Hunter S. Thompson to Dave Barry. Every bathroom and home workshop needs one of these. Signed by the editor. Shipping is free.

11. Car enthusiast stocking stuffers with style
Blipshift, $4 and up
You can find T-shirts about horsepower. You can find bumper stickers that celebrate the joys of the manual transmission. But this company also sells good design, which is harder to find. The creative edge stays fresh because Blipshift invites artists to submit designs (for which they earn $1 per shirt sold). Blipshift only offers up one T-shirt design at a time, priced at $15, and when they’re gone, they’re gone.

12. Homemade gift: car comfort/emergency kit
If you think homemade gifts are best, this is one everybody will appreciate. Pack a sturdy lidded crate with emergency and comfort supplies. Visit the people at Survival Supply for ingredients, if you want to be really thorough. Ideas: an extra mobile charger for the phone; a sturdy candle inside a metal can or a glass jar, plus matches to light it with; packaged or canned food that won’t spoil or freeze (peanut butter, bread, crackers, packaged cheese, snack sausages), and aseptically packaged juice boxes; flashlight and batteries; emergency blanket.

images.caption: #1: More gorgeous photos of the highly desirable Sonic Tools line.
#1: Sonic Tools'  16-in-1 ratchet screwdriver ($45.99), ¼” disc ratchet ($22.99), utility knife ($12.99), and flash pen ($43.99).
#2: Six examples of original car art from Tim Wirth.
#3: MyQ Garage: control the garage door from anywhere, via smartphone.
#4: Cobra makes a glovebox-size jumper cable.
#4: A better look at Cobra's small battery charger.
#5: Dodson Group's giant bow for the top of a car.
#6: The Car Cozy electric blanket for the car. Make sure your car still has a 12V outlet!
#7: A tool set you can carry on your key ring, from Reductivist.
#8: A book to encourage elementary-aged car fanatics, published by Running Press.

#9: Page from The Little Red Racing Car.
#10: Our own anthology of the best automotive writing.
#12: Some of the end-of-the-world gear offered by Survival Supply.

title: 2016 Toyota Prius
subTitle: The concept is familiar, but the execution is all new.
promoTeaserSmall: The concept is familiar, but the execution is all new.
promoTeaser: The concept is familiar, but the execution is all new.
metaDescription: The concept is familiar, but the execution is all new.

pageElements.text:
2016 Toyota Prius 3 Touring

Price: $28,935
Engine: 95-horsepower 1.8-liter four-cylinder, 80-hp electric motor, maximum hybrid system output 121 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic
EPA fuel economy: 54 mpg city/50 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Eight-year/100,000 mile hybrid component warranty
Standard features I can’t live without: Toyota Safety Sense safety system
Notable standard features on this model: Six-speaker Entune premium audio with integrated navigation, voice recognition, CD player, iPod connectivity, Bluetooth, Siri Eyes Free, power adjustable front seats, rearview camera, SofTex (simulated leather) upholstery, SofTex trim steering wheel, push-button start, wireless smartphone charging, Toyota Safety Sense-P (low speed auto braking, pedestrian detection, lane-keeping assist, adaptive cruise control), blind spot monitor
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Volt, Ford C-Max

It’s startling to realize that the Prius has been around for two decades worldwide (and sixteen years in the U.S. market), and it's amazing to reflect that in this country it continues to outsell all other hybrids combined. Other amazing stats: Toyota sells thirty different hybrids worldwide, fourteen in the U.S. (eight Toyotas, including a new RAV4 version, six wearing Lexus badges). And over those sixteen years in the U.S. Prius sales have exceeded two million, according to Toyota.
Toyota resisted complacency, and the Prius that will appear in showrooms in early January, generation four, is as all new as all new ever gets.

With that kind of success, when the time came for a Prius update it must have been tempting to keep changes to a minimum and profit to a maximum. But Toyota resisted complacency, and the Prius that will appear in showrooms in early January, generation four, is as all new as all new ever gets; only the wheelbase (106.3 inches) carries forward from the current car.

The unitbody is the first example of the Toyota New Global Architecture (TNGA) that will soon be the foundation for at least half of the company’s new cars in the near future. Structurally, it’s a far more rigid package than the current Prius, always a plus in the dynamics department.

It’s also a bigger Prius—2.5 inches longer, 1.6 inches wider, close in size to the Corolla sedan. It’s roomier, too—a pair of adults can reside comfortably in the rear seats, without rubbing their knees against the front seatbacks, or their hairdos against the headliner, even though the roof of the new Prius is slightly lower.

That lower roofline is just one element in an improved aerodynamic package, which adds up to reduced drag. And the slicker aero combines with a number of noise reduction measures for a much more serene interior, whether in urban traffic or rural freeways.

Like previous generations, the 2016 Prius is propelled by Toyota’s solidly established Hybrid Synergy Drive, with an internal-combustion engine, augmented on demand by an electric motor, driving the front wheels. The basic operating concept is unchanged but all this hardware is new, too—new 1.8-liter four-cylinder engine (95 horsepower), new electric motor, new electronic management, new continuously variable transmission, new battery packs.

Total hybrid system output—121 horsepower—is down slightly from the previous setup, although Toyota anticipates 0-to-60- mph times to be the same as the current Prius (just under ten seconds), and 0-to-30-mph times to be a little quicker.

More important, improved system efficiency begets improvement in the most important performance stat of all for a hybrid: higher fuel efficiency ratings. The EPA projects the current Prius to achieve 51 mpg in urban driving, 48 on the highway. The 2016 Prius is projected to achieve 54/50, and a new Eco edition is rated 58/53, thanks largely to the absence of a spare tire and a few other minor weight reductions.
Toyota U.S. boss Bill Fay says the ratings are “better than anything that doesn’t have a plug,” referring to plug-in hybrids. (There will be a new plug-in version of the Prius in the near future.)

Every element of the interior has been redesigned, highlighted by a new instrument panel with two 4.2-inch color screens side by side, and a bigger color touch screen in the center stack. Also, higher trim levels offer a color head-up display, as well as a new pedestrian detection system.

The addition of color to the two upper display screens, which provide operating information such as the speedometer, enhances legibility, but some may find the location of the instrument package, which sits squarely in the middle of the upper dash, a little annoying. Toyota has used this approach—primary instruments centered atop the dashboard—in other applications, claiming that it reduces the driver’s eye redirection. A more likely explanation is that it reduces the cost of making cars for right- and left-hand-drive markets.

Interior materials, including seat upholstery with a new synthetic leather in higher trim levels, have a classier look and feel, and the reduced height of the new center console gives the forward passenger compartment a more open feeling, However, the hard white plastic of the console in higher trim levels is jarringly out of step with the rest of the interior décor, not only in the eyes of your humble narrator but other journalists on hand for the Southern California preview drive. How do you say “what were they thinking” in Japanese?
Back on the positive side of the ledger, infotainment features are up to the minute,

A stiffer chassis is a fundamental prerequisite for good handling, and the new Prius has that in spades—60 percent stiffer, according to Toyota, which suggests the current chassis is composed of tofu. The new foundations are augmented by a new independent rear suspension system, retuned front suspension, revised steering, and a lower center of gravity.

Toyota promotes the sum of the revisions as a Prius that’s not only more responsive, but actually fun to drive—a car you drive because you want to. This may be a bit of a stretch, although the new Prius is certainly more responsive than the current version. It offers less body roll, it's quicker in brisk maneuvers, and perhaps it's a smidge quicker across the intersection when the light turns green. Braking performance is likely to be about the same as the current Prius, thanks to tires designed to optimize fuel economy—skinny, with a tread compound formulated to reduce rolling resistance.

Steering is also improved, and nicely weighted as speed increases, although it still lacks a sense of actual road feel, and doesn’t self-center very quickly recovering from a turn. But if the dynamics aren’t exactly compelling, there are other virtues. Ride quality is smooth, the seats are all-day comfortable, and the quiet interior is one of those comfort-enhancers that aren’t apparent until one has endured a noisy car.

Safety was another top development priority for this car, and there are a number of new safety features, most notably Toyota Safety Sense, which will stop the car in low-speed traffic when the system brain decides the driver isn’t paying attention, and a new adaptive cruise control system capable of doing the same.
Toyota anticipates top ratings from National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) and the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS), but the 2016 Prius has not yet been tested.
The new Prius scores well in the eye candy department—longer, lower, wider, and edgier, with a stylish contemporary look that makes the current car seem a bit dowdy.

Hybrid or not, design is always a top purchase consideration, and the new Prius scores well in the eye candy department—longer, lower, wider, and edgier, with a stylish contemporary look that makes the current car seem a bit dowdy. The going-away view, in particular, is striking with its boomerang vertical taillights and eye-catching angularity. 
The new Prius will be offered in six trim levels—Prius 2, Prius 2 Eco, Prius 3, 3 Touring, Prius 4, and 4 Touring, with prices ranging from $25,030 to $30,830. The focus of our Southern California test drive was on a Prius 3 Touring, which is near the top of the pecking order.

Although the fourth-generation Prius is all new, it can be viewed as an evolutionary redesign—an improvement on the original concept and current car in every metric. Toyota promotes a more engaging driver experience as a new attribute, hard as that is to quantify. But beyond that, the new Prius is a comfortable, capable family sedan that continues to set the pace among hybrids.

title: 2016 Mazda CX-3 Touring AWD
subTitle: More car than ute, but what about that zoom-zoom?
promoTeaserSmall: More car than ute, but what about that zoom-zoom?
promoTeaser: More car than ute, but what about that zoom-zoom?
metaDescription: More car than ute, but what about that zoom-zoom?

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, all-wheel-drive compact crossover
Trim levels: Sport, Touring, Grand Touring FWD and AWD models
Base price: $27,120 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $27,670
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 146 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic with Sport mode
Fuel economy: 27 mpg city/32 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not yet rated; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Buick Encore AWD ($25,385)
2016 Mini Cooper Paceman S All4 ($29,950)
2016 Nissan Juke AWD ($22,925)

Fun-O-Meter: 8

Before you read this review of the all-new 2016 Mazda CX-3, you should know this: I am predisposed to like Mazdas. I own a 2004 Mazdaspeed Miata, which I dearly love, and I believe fervently in Mazda’s evocative and enduring tagline, “zoom-zoom.” As Mazda so simply explains, “All children instinctively know it. A few adults still remember it. One unique car company refuses to outgrow it.”

Being a twelve-year old boy trapped in the body of an adult woman, I also refuse to outgrow my love of zoom-zoom. I have been looking forward to driving the new Mazda CX-3 since I saw it in concept form a year ago at the 2014 Los Angeles Auto Show.

The first thing you notice, even before you drive it, is what the Mazda CX-3 looks like. Call it step one in establishing your zoom. Simply stated, the CX-3 is the coolest-looking subcompact SUV on the market, as interesting in its final production sheetmetal as the concept version that  took the L.A. show by storm. Design is important to me, and Mazda’s design department has consistently overdelivered in the past few years, making its line of SUVs as interesting to look at as its cars.

Carved like a crouching animal in profile, the CX-3 carries on the Kodo design “soul of motion” language that Mazda first introduced in the 2012 CX-5. It is taut, exciting, with a short rear overhang and one of the longest hoods in this category, making it look every bit the sports car it is not. It’s a teensy, tinsy subcompact SUV. And in this case, it’s heavy on the sport, but very light on the ute.

The 2016 CX-3 has just about the amount of cargo room that you’d expect, which is not exactly an overabundance. In fact, quarters are tight in general. The CX-3 is rated to hold five passengers, but if all five are my size, at least three of us will be grumpy about it. In fact, any medium-size human riding in the back seat will have a time fitting legs in there, too. There wasn’t enough space for my large briefcase to fit on the floor behind the driver.
You can make better use of the 60/40 split-folding rear seat by flipping it down. That will almost quadruple the cargo volume, from 12.4 to 44.5 cubic feet.

Up front, it’s tight enough that driver and passenger will feel like they’re sitting cheek to cheek, and I do mean that in every sense of the word. There’s a single flip-down armrest between the two seats, and like the one you’ll find on an airplane back in coach seating, it is not really shareable. Tucked partway under that armrest is the multifunction controller for the seven-inch center console infotainment screen. The controller manages audio, home screen with apps, and the navigation function.
Compact quarters aside, our CX-3 Grand Touring AWD test car’s cabin was lovely: a very simple, elegant interior with the minimum of distractions.

Compact quarters aside, our CX-3 Grand Touring AWD test car’s cabin was lovely: a very simple, elegant interior with the minimum of distractions, and a maximum amount of rich leather and suede in a combination of dark grey, maroon, and parchment (off-white). The dash is set up horizontally, with parchment leather trim running from the left of the steering wheel to the right-side door, which sets up a clean appearance. Vents and their controllers are fitted along that horizon, adding to the simple elegance, with the center information screen up above it for easy access by the driver.

Leather also covers the steering wheel, the gearshift knob, the brake handle, and all “five” seating positions. The seats are extra luxe, with perforated suede inserts. The fronts are heated. All of this and much more (like a rearview camera, rear cross-traffic alert, blind spot monitoring, keyless entry, Bluetooth hands-free phone and radio, a nav system, and power moonroof, for instance) is included in the base $27,120. In fact, the only option added was Mazda Mobile Start for $550. Although we didn’t test it, the Mazda Mobile Start app looks pretty cool, allowing you to access a variety of remote features from your smartphone: locking and unlocking your car, starting it from anywhere in the world (okay, whatever), finding your car in that holiday mess of a parking lot, and more. Not sure about that price, though.

And I’m not sure if I’d give the CX-3 two “zoom”s. Maybe more horsepower, something I find myself saying about almost every Mazda I drive. Even 20 hp more would do it. But Mazdas are engineered and designed with all hands operating as one, with the intent to create a vehicle with maximum efficiency, weight savings, and power output, and to achieve the optimal balance of performance, fuel economy, and emissions. Hard to argue with that.

The CX-3 AWD weighs in at an amazingly low 2,952 pounds (the front-wheel-drive version is only 2,809 pounds). In comparison, the curb weight of the Nissan Juke AWD is 2,981 pounds, the Mini Paceman All4 is 3,260 pounds, and the Buick Encore AWD is 3,358 pounds. Weight matters, in both fuel economy and overall performance.

The CX-3 only really disappointed in initial acceleration—more labored and noisy than I would personally like. But once up to speed, the CX-3 was fully engaged. Here in Michigan, where curvy roads are as rare as smooth pavement, there are those who use freeway on- and off-ramps at speed to test cornering capability, a practice referred to fondly as “ramping.” In a little bit of impromptu ramping, the CX-3 handled like a dream, helped by a small button at the base of the automatic gearshift lever. Put that button on Sport, switch from automatic to manual shifting via the paddle shifters mounted in perfect position just behind the steering wheel’s cross spokes, and suddenly the CX-3 finds its zoom-zoom.

For the past twenty-five years, Mazda has set itself up as the car company for people who love to drive. The CX-3 may not be a pure performance play, but it’s fun, it’s balanced, and it’s emotionally pleasing to drive. It’s a beautiful car in terms of handling, steering, suspension, brakes, and its ability to go through a turn at a fairly decent clip. It is more sporting than the average compact SUV, because being fun to drive has always been a critical part of Mazda’s DNA. It matters so much that Mazda’s new tagline is...Driving Matters.
But if you’re shopping for a crossover for more practical reasons, this may not be what you’re looking for.

title: 2016 Dodge Dart Rallye Blacktop
subTitle: Blacked-out appearance packages make the most of this compact sedan.

promoTeaser: Blacked-out appearance packages make the most of this compact sedan.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive compact sedan
Trim levels: SE, SXT, Aero, GT, Limited
Base price: $20,195 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $24,115
Engine: 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 184 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic with Powertech manual mode
Fuel economy: 23 mpg city/35 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated (2015 model was a Top Safety Pick)
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Ford Focus SE Sedan ($19,390)
2016 Honda Civic EX Sedan ($21,875)
2016 Mazda 3 iSport Sedan ($20,015)

Fun-O-Meter: 6

Are you looking for a comfortable compact sedan that seats four people, at a price that hits right around the $20,000 mark? You’re in luck; there’s a boat load of those. Why would you pick this one, other than to buy into an authentic American muscle-car brand? Well, the 2016 Dodge Dart offers a decent-size trunk and room for adults in the back seat, for the price of a cramped subcompact. And, for its surprisingly low price, the Dart looks pretty good. But make no mistake. The Dart is a long way from a Dodge Challenger SRT Hellcat.

After a hiatus of almost four decades, the Dart name reappeared in 2013, attached to a car that was kind of tinny and not impressive in any way. It was an inauspicious launch for a car with such a classic name: one that dates back to 1960 and, for people of a certain age, brings back fond memories. It has been an uphill sales climb since then. Although 2015 Dart sales are up five percent compared to 2014, the car has set no sales records. With 80,661 sold in 2015 through November, the Dart is nowhere near competitors like the Honda Civic, which sold 302,588 in the same time period.
The Dodge design team has cleaned up the hood to make it look a touch sportier. To really add some zing, you need to check out the optional packages.

Not much has changed, although the base Dart SE is $500 more than last year, at $17,990, including destination charge. Otherwise, the 2016 Dart is a carryover, still a stubby-nosed, front-wheel drive car. It can be tricky to make front-drivers look sexy, but the Dodge design team has cleaned up the hood to make it look a touch sportier. To really add some zing, you need to check out the optional packages.

Our test car, an SXT, which is second in the five-level lineup of Darts, starts at $20,390 and adds two optional packages I would call crucial to your self-respect—Rallye and Blacktop—and neither breaks the bank.

The Blacktop package adds some more badass attitude for a very reasonable $295. Actually, that’s super cheap when you consider you’re getting eighteen-inch five-spoke aluminum gloss black wheels, blackened foglamp bezels, and exterior mirrors with a gloss black finish. All that blackety-black really changes the exterior, giving it a little bit of menace, a little like an undercover cop car.

The Rallye appearance package is an extra $595 and adds even more black to the outside, along with chrome dual exhaust tips, a leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob, front and rear floor mats, and a Rallye badge. But interestingly, it’s not just an appearance package: there’s also a touring suspension and a rear stabilizer bar. I hate to imagine what the ride quality and handling would be without those, because the Dart as equipped is a kind of bangy thing with a little roll in turns on two-lanes and on rough road. Electronic roll mitigation probably keeps it from rolling any more than the slight but noticeable amount it was rolling, which I noticed around the same time I was hearing the suspension slapping around behind me.

There are three engine choices in the Dart lineup. The base model has a 2.0-liter four-cylinder making 160 horsepower, while the Aero gets the same horsepower from a 1.4-liter turbocharged four-cylinder. The SXT we tested had the top engine, a 2.4-liter four-cylinder that makes 184 horsepower.

The six-speed Powertec automatic transmission ($1,250) with Power Stick shifter allows you to operate in manual mode, and it shifts very well. Otherwise, leave it in automatic mode. You’ll find the transmission is a little edgy around 1,500 rpm as if unsure what gear it wants to stay in. Either use the manual mode or just drive a little faster to smooth things out, I say. (Always my go-to position.)

Inside the car, there is a lot that seems like carryover from another era. It’s fairly plastic but clean and nicely detailed. When adding on to the 2016 Dart, one must-have is the Touchscreen Group ($595), where you get the rearview camera and the generously sized 8.4-inch touchscreen display. These are standard on the Aero and GT models. It is a bit incongruous to see the big touchscreen alongside the dot-matrix-print information center on the dash, which takes you back to the 1990s in a hurry. Another throwback is the single-disc CD player.

Where the center console meets the dash, there’s a pair of rotary dials for radio and climate control functions. These controls are also accessible inside the touchscreen,  which is way more annoying than just using the controls in front of you. For example, you can’t adjust the mode to modulate the air blowing on your face or your feet unless you go into the touchscreen. Here is another indication that this car has one foot in the past and one in the present.

The seats, front and rear, are comfortable. Between the front seats, you’ll find a lidded bin that is padded to serve as an armrest. The bin is deep, but its dimensions are saltine-box-like. On the other hand, the glove box is fairly deep and big, with a built-in bin in the lid to hold the owner’s manual and a plastic clip to hold an envelope with your insurance and registration papers. Those handy features leave you with a big, open bin where you can put a small soft purse.

At the base of the shifter, there’s a little kickup that meets the center console. In Volvos and a few other vehicles, that’s a pass-through where you can put your purse down below. It’s a solid piece in the Dart, but they’ve cleverly done little cutout niches, one for the passenger and one for the driver, that will hold maybe a wallet or some coins, a good use of otherwise wasted space. You would want to consider its proximity to the accelerator pedal before you just jam a bunch of stuff in it.

As for seating, the back seat really will hold two average-size adults, although the center seat, as in most back seats these days, is not comfortable for the big’uns except in a pinch. The trunk is really big at 13.1 cubic feet, and the rear seats flop down to increase the space, although it’s not a full-width opening.

For active safety features that are becoming common on a growing range of vehicles, you’ll have to go up to the Dart GT or Limited (starting at $23,090 and $25,390, respectively), and pay an added $1,095 for the Technology package. It includes HID headlamps, rear cross-path detection, rear park assist, blind spot monitoring, and rain-sensing wipers.
This is a heavily contested segment with a lot of players, and the Dart is not a head-to-head competitor with any of the important cars in the compact-sedan segment.

In 1960, the entry-level Dart was by far the top seller in the brand’s lineup. Not so these days. Let’s face it, the Dart is long in the tooth. This is a heavily contested segment with a lot of players, and the Dart is not a head-to-head competitor with any of the important cars in the compact-sedan segment.

If you’re shopping in this price range, you’d be well served to look at all the usual entry-level suspects in the under-$20,000 range: a Kia Forte, a Mazda 3, a Ford Focus. Until there’s a new Dart, it will get its clock cleaned by new offerings such as the brand-new Honda Civic and Nissan Altima. It’s easy to name about a dozen compact and subcompact cars that are sexier, fresher, and have newer equipment.
But if you are a Dodge boy, and there are plenty, Dodge is a storied brand, and there are still people who want to buy American cars. Maybe you’re one of them, and there’s nothing wrong with that.

title: Pro/Con: Roundabout or 4-Way Stop?
subTitle: Molly and the experts approve of roundabouts. Laura prefers a four-way stop. Whose side are you on?
promoTeaserSmall: Molly and the experts approve of roundabouts. Laura prefers a four-way stop. Whose side are you on?
promoTeaser: Molly and the experts approve of roundabouts. Laura prefers a four-way stop. Whose side are you on?
metaDescription: Molly and the experts approve of roundabouts. Laura prefers a four-way stop. Whose side are you on?

contributors.displayName: Laura Sky Brown and Molly Jean

pageElements.text:
Laura Says: Give Me a Good Old Four-Way Stop or Even a Stoplight Anytime

I'll admit something to you: I go out of my way to avoid roundabouts. Not all the time, really; mainly at rush hour, school dropoff or pickup time, and any other time I have good reason to worry about the other people who will be taking that up-to-360-degree spin with me. Four-way stops have their own issues, which in fact are the same issues that bother me in every kind of driving: selfish drivers who don't honor the social contract to take turns. All those people who zoom ahead in the lane that's about to close, then want to forcibly insert themselves in front of you. All those people who don't realize the light has changed because they're texting, holding up everyone behind them. All those people who assume it's their turn every turn. Now put them all into an endlessly spinning circle and see whether they yield when you expect them to.

I know that the roundabout holds a scientifically proven advantage for both safety and efficiency. I know that the reason is because cars can keep moving through an intersection in a nice, smooth pattern; and yet I admit, I am not totally comfortable with the idea that cars will just keep moving through complex intersections. I  like to see a brief stop required from all those oblivious texters, all those aggressive me-firsters, and all those perfectly nice people who just need to scope out the intersection and think about what they're doing for a minute.
If I had my way, I would prefer stoplights at any intersection with moderate to heavy traffic or any kind of complexity.

I mean, you can cite statistics that traffic moves more smoothly through roundabouts, or that more cars get through in the same amount of time, but a roundabout in my town was named this spring as the site of the most accidents of any intersection in the state of Michigan. Really, if I had my way, I would prefer stoplights at any intersection with moderate to heavy traffic or any kind of complexity. They were good enough for my Midwestern grandparents, and they're good enough for me.

Molly Says: Get with the 21st Century and Embrace the Traffic Circle

Honorable Laura Brown, I wish to disagree with you. No surprise there. If you saw my video Mastering the Roundabout, you know I'm in favor of them.
Since humans are flawed and can’t seem to stop blabbing on their phones or even worse, texting, let's all welcome the added safety of roundabouts.

When your grandparents were born, those crazy Wright brothers were flying gliders at Kitty Hawk. The first electric traffic light had yet to be installed. They adapted along the way to many advances in vehicle safety throughout their lives: freeways, mandatory seatbelts, and safety glass, for instance. All of these advancements have saved lives and the roundabouts that have long been common in Europe have burst onto American soil to save our lives with an added benefit of reducing traffic congestion.

The roundabouts are here to stay, so it is time you stopped avoiding them and start to embrace them. I wholeheartedly agree they are a bit daunting at first. I especially dislike the double roundabout just north of Ann Arbor at the freeway interchange. I once accidentally re-entered the freeway when I was trying to go to a restaurant. My daughter, then ten years old, was starving and sobbing in the back seat as the restaurant receded in the background. We could see the food; we just couldn't get to it. But since that time I have boned up on proper usage, and I have slayed the double roundabout.

When vehicles enter a roundabout, their speed is reduced, and the counterclockwise flow of traffic eliminates head-on, left turn, and angle collisions. These facts alone make it a no-brainer to install them in areas where traffic is heavy. Every single day, I witness cars speeding through intersections after the light is red. I can’t imagine there are very many drivers who have not witnessed a car blatantly running a red light. Since humans are flawed and can’t seem to stop blabbing on their phones or even worse, texting, let's all welcome the added safety of roundabouts.

So in closing, dear Laura, these advances in vehicle and traffic safety are marching forward. Unless people live in the sticks, they are going to need to deal with roundabouts. So let's promote proper usage and a positive attitude toward our new best friend, the roundabout.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Welcome to Five Cool Things from JeanKnowsCars.com!
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/dSrcN_H_MO0?autoplay=1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

This is the third-generation Honda Pilot. It has a sleek new body, a lot of new stuff in the interior, a powerful new engine, and new six-speed and nine-speed automatic transmissions. For 2016, the Pilot also gets top safety and crash ratings from both the federal government and the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.
So let's count down the five coolest things about the 2016 Honda Pilot.

1. This unique transmission controller with fingertip control. It's like nothing I've ever seen before. You can use it without looking because each of the gear selectors is a different shape and feel, so you instantly know where you are.

2. An available intelligent traction management system adjusts traction to improve handling across all kinds of terrain. Extra cool points for the Sand, Mud, and Snow animations swirling around the icon of the Pilot, depending on which mode you check with this button. God, I love this, especially the Sand one.

3. This back-seat passenger paradise. I might occasionally give up the driver's seat to experience these second-row heated captain's chairs, especially if we add in the nine-inch rear entertainment screen that plays BluRay discs. I might just hire a chauffeur.

4. The Pilot is very serious about this whole luxury lounge vibe for the wayback third-row passengers, too. It begins with one-touch walk-through. That makes it a lot easier to get back there. And once you're settled, the panorama sunroof lets the sun shine in.

5. Now this is really cool. With all the seats up and a bench instead of these captain's chairs, the Pilot will hold eight passengers. And there's a cargo area under this little floor that will hold an eighty-two-quart mega cooler without moving the third row.
So get used to being the official party vehicle of your neighborhood.
Pick your own cool things about the new Pilot at automobiles.honda.com/pilot.

pageElements.text: Welcome to Five Cool Things from JeanKnowsCars.com!
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/MmQumdw_kCQ?autoplay=1" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
The Honda Accord is one of America's most respected sedans. It has won thirty Car and Driver 10 Best awards in its lifetime, more than any other car.
The 2016 Accord offers the premium Honda Sensing suite of advanced driver assist technologies that help assist the driver to stay on the road, in the lane, and out of trouble.
The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety has given the Accord its top safety rating for crashworthiness: the Top Safety Pick Plus.
Here are the Five Cool Things you'll find on the 2016 Accord.

1. At the top of my hit list, for the first time in a Honda, is Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, the ultimate smartphone connectivity, offering you seamless, hands-free connection to your phone, your music, and some of your favorite apps. All of that coming through a nice big touchscreen display so you're looking forward at your touchscreen instead of down at your phone.

2. There's a V-6 engine in the Touring edition. Honda didn't have to put a V-6 in the Accord. This category typically uses a turbocharged four-cylinder engine for a power boost. I'd rather have a V-6, and this one has 278 horsepower. It sounds great, it's responsive, and it has soul. It also has a six-speed automatic transmission that helps it get 34 miles per gallon on the highway.

3. Not only does the Accord have a multi-angle rearview camera, which gives you a choice of three different backup views, it has LaneWatch, which is one more camera that shows you live video of the right lane when you flip on your right turn signal. It's perfect for going around tight turns but also for seeing that big rig roaring up on you just as you're about to change lanes on the freeway.
4. The Accord already has a huge trunk, but now there's also a 60/40 folding rear seat. There's a release on each side, basically turning this thing into a mini-ute.
And the split seat accommodates the long load and a passenger at the same time.
5. Do you like your back-seat passengers? Well, you can now give the two outboard passengers heated seats. Share the love! The middle-seat passenger: still out of luck.
Pick your own cool things about the Accord at automobiles.honda.com/accord.
