pageElements.text: Jean Knows Cars, with backing from mighty Tribune Publishing, moved into 318 North Main, a 1915 annex to Chelsea’s historic Clocktower, in January 2015. We’d been working out of a Panera restaurant, a local Ann Arbor vegan restaurant called Seva, Molly Jean’s kitchen table, and Laura Sky Brown’s kitchen table for several months, so it was a Big Deal. We had no time to celebrate. In fact, we’d just thoroughly covered the North American International Auto Show in Detroit, and were thrilled to finally have a home. We worked on card tables until our desks arrived, and borrowed Wi-Fi for a month from Dr. Paula Koch’s Cherry Optometry next door to us until we bullied ATT for a microcell.
Howdy Holmes, former IndyCar driver and CEO of the towering Jiffy Mix mill across the street, called to say, well, “Howdy!”

Our property manager, Andy, hung my Soap Box Derby Car of Damocles from the ceiling above my head and declared us his “new hands-down favorite tenants.” We plugged in a coffeepot and hit the ground running, following the Detroit show with Chicago, Geneva, New York, and Los Angeles. We’ve published more than 100 car reviews and nearly fifty video reviews, including designer walkarounds of the most important new concepts at the major car shows.

We’ve flown more than 100,000 miles this year (and easily driven that many as well) to walk auto shows, to test drive new cars, to judge concours d'elegance (our new favorite is the Hilton Head Island Motoring Event), and to speak (to the students at McPherson College in Kansas, to women in Las Vegas at the SEMA Show, to diehard car fans in Chicago at Cooper Technica Restoration, among my favorites), and to visit old friends, including Dan and Evi Gurney at All-American Racers; Walker Evans, Parnelli Jones, and Linda Vaughn at the Motorsports Hall of Fame induction of Walker; and most important, my heroine, racing driver and extraordinary driver Denise McCluggage at her home in Santa Fe, three days before she passed away at the age of 88, leaving a void that will never be filled. I had to stop a moment before I wrote that.

If you’ve not noticed our three most recurring bylines, let me point you to the wit and wisdom of our executive editor, Laura Sky Brown. The quirky musings and excellent artistic eye of our creative director, Molly Jean. The erudite and deeply informed test drive analyses (aka Swan Drives) of our token “old car guy,” Tony Swan, former editor in chief of Motor Trend magazine. He has a 1954 Mercury sedan. What’s not to love?

Here are just a few of my favorite stories over the past difficult, glorious year:

Giving My Dogs a Day, Subaru Style
I imagine a dream vacation for each of my (spoiled) dogs.

Old Friends and a New Volkswagen
Between the Motorsports Hall of Fame party and Ford's new-tech meeting, I found time to buy a new car.

Jean's Driveway: 2016 Nissan Maxima SR
The newest version of the four-door sports car was worth the wait.

Car Repair? How to Talk to the Shop
Five ways to tell the service department what's wrong with your car in terms they'll understand.

6 Things to Never Ever Do in a Car
You don't do any of these things. Right?

5 Reasons to Spring for Winter Tires
If it gets below freezing where you live, consider putting winter tires on your vehicle. Here’s why.

Pro/Con: Roundabout or 4-Way Stop?
Molly and the experts approve of roundabouts. Laura prefers a four-way stop. Whose side are you on?
Now. What are you missing? Yearning for? Sick of? Need desperately? Please write. We read every email.
Happy New Year! Share the joy, aim for the light.

Love,
Jean

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive luxury crossover
Trim levels: RX350, RX350 F Sport
Base price: $43,800 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $54,755
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 295 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 20 mpg city/28 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not yet rated; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Audi Q5 Premium ($40,900)
2016 BMW X3 sDrive 28i ($39,945)
2016 Lincoln MKX ($39,185)
2016 Mercedes-Benz GLC300 ($40,800)
Fun-O-Meter: 5

It’s possible that you will never get used to the look of the 2016 Lexus RX350. The side profile looks like it was in a sword fight. The way the sheetmetal wraps around that crazy front spindle grille looks like Darth Vader’s helmet, held in the grip of a stag beetle’s mandibles. The floating roof (an optical illusion where the C-pillar is blacked out so the roof panel appears to be floating above the glass) works better on the Nissan Murano, but I like it. Overall, though, you could say that the all-new fourth-generation RX350 is a work of origami that does not turn the sheetmetal into a swan, but I admit that after a week on the road with one, I became fond of its polarizing design.

The RX has been paying Lexus’s light bills from its beginning in 1998. It is the perfect size, has always had a juicy V-6, and offered the right luxury sensibility at a reasonably competitive price. Worldwide sales of the RX have topped 2.2 million. The hybrid RX400h, launched in 2005 as the first hybrid Lexus model, distinguished itself by accounting for well over half of all Lexus hybrids sold by the end of 2012. The RX is everywhere. Everywhere.

You have to admit, it’s an astonishing move for Lexus to give its breadwinner such a polarizing face. But it’s clearly in line with what Toyota chairman Akio Toyoda wants to accomplish with Lexus: to move it upmarket from Toyota and make it something special. Mission accomplished on the design. You’re either going to love it or hate it, but you’ll definitely have a strong opinion.

The interior is another story altogether. It’s stunningly beautiful, luxurious in a Danish furniture kind of way. The horizontal dash layout that has been rolled out in Toyota and Lexus models for the past few years in this car is a layering of exquisite leather, sweeps of satin-finish metal, and wide swaths of trim pieces that look like wood with aluminum pinstripes, but are actually laser-cut aluminum with inserts of sapele mahogany.

The chocolate-colored semi-aniline leather (which means it retains more of the natural grain of the leather) is edged in red stitching and used on all the touch surfaces, and it’s perforated on the seat surfaces. The seats in our loaded test car were heated and ventilated. I believe the only hard plastic surfaces I could hunt down were on the underside of the dash and the steering column.
During our week-long round trip from Michigan to New Orleans, the first thing noticed by every person who looked at our car was the massive 12.3-inch information screen.

During our week-long round trip from Michigan to New Orleans, the first thing noticed by every person who looked at our car was the massive 12.3-inch information screen floating in the center of the long dash. It. Is. Huge.

It is also beautiful and a welcome option, especially on a long road trip where navigation tends to become the center of your adventure. A map sprawled across the RX’s screen is nearly as big as an old-school paper map. It’s so big and clear, you can pretty much  catch every direction it maps out with just the farthest corner of your right eyeball.

Voice recognition wasn’t fond of my Midwestern accent, which forced me once or twice to pull over and pick through the digital keypad and spell out my destination. Hated that. The mouse-style controller on the center console was jumpier than I remember, although its “haptic” feedback is pretty strong. The base of the controller has a redundant switch on each side to enter commands instead of pressing the mouse.

The center console also holds a double cup holder. You can put a tall, deep cup in each of them, but it will swallow a little cup unless you hit the PUSH button, which raises the floor inside one of the cupholders up like a little tiny dumbwaiter.

The rear seats are 60/40 one-touch folding, which I love. We flipped down the left passenger’s seat and packed everything we owned in the cargo hold, optimistically leaving the right rear (heated) seat open so that I could lounge back there and watch movies using the Bluetooth headphones that come with each of the massive 11.6-inch headrest-mounted rear screens while my husband drove.
Never happened. Someday I’m going to be a back-seat passenger.

This car is as quiet as any Lexus I remember. When you put the windows up and down at a stop, you have to visually check that the windows are going up and down; that’s how quiet it was. I loved the one-touch panoramic roof, and the overhead light switches, which are as close to proximity touch as you can be. It knows you’re coming, and you don’t have to search for it. Just get your hand up anywhere on that surface and the light goes on. Other features include rain-sensing wipers and keyless entry, which is as sensitive as the overhead light switches. Put your hand through the door handle, and it unlocks. It’s a beautiful thing when you never have to take your key out. On the other hand, waving your hand past the Lexus logo on the hatch produces the slowest power-opening moment in existence. Soooo slow.

The Lexus Safety System Plus was an option package, priced at $635 on our model. (You can also get the safety package with adaptive front lights for $1,050, or with LED headlamps for $2,250.) Basic Safety System Plus includes four features: intelligent high beam, lane departure alert with steering assist, pre-collision system with pedestrian detection, and all-speed dynamic radar cruise control. I have come kicking and screaming to smart cruise control, but I prefer it for heavy traffic, not the long-distance interstate cruise. You can switch to fixed-speed cruise control in the RX, but you have to cycle through the ignition to return to the dynamic radar cruise control mode.

A long trip like this showed off the lovely pairing of 295-horsepower V-6 engine and eight-speed automatic transmission. Driving to Louisiana through Kentucky and Tennessee was an opportunity to drive on hilly roads, which we don’t have a lot of in Michigan. The eight-speed automatic shifts more than I’m used to because of the hills, but the shifts were seamless, clean and quick, almost unnoticeable. (You have to watch the tach needle.)
We averaged 22.2 mpg on the long trip from Michigan to Louisiana and back, going 70 to 80 mph. The 19.2-gallon fuel tank was the minimum size you’d want for a long trip.

Unfortunately, all that driving did nothing to improve the RX’s reputation for having uninterested steering feel, numb handling, and excessive body motions over rough roads and through turns.

There are three drive modes: Eco, Normal, and Sport. I went right for Sport the minute I realized that in Normal and Eco modes, the handling requires constant peripheral attention with firm hands on the wheel. It’s like keeping a slightly wayward child in line. This is a vehicle that needs a little more attention than most people want to pay on a long-distance drive. In Sport mode, it settles down, but the ride is still a little floaty.

Sport mode was acceptable, but Normal was not. The problem is, every time you turn the car on and off, it reverts to Normal mode. Then you remember that it doesn’t ride the way you’d like, and you have to reset it to Sport mode. There is an F Sport version of the RX350, with standard all-wheel drive, but I haven’t driven it yet, so the jury’s out.

The hedonist in me says the RX350 brings a lot to love, the world’s most beautiful nav screen at the top of my list. The materials used in the cabin and the craftsmanship exhibited are exquisite. And despite being more pricey than some formidable competitors, the RX scores points for its dramatic new presence.
But it’s going to need to push that Fun-O-Meter up a couple of notches to win me over. Maybe I will find it all in the F Sport.

Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/64XIN09SzwA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

The previous Honda Ridgeline had its critics, especially those who didn't like the way the front end looked and the fact that it was a one-box vehicle. Honda took care of that with this all-new Ridgeline. You might recognize the look of the new Honda Pilot when you’re looking at the front. And at the back….what is that? As you can see in the video, there’s a very sharply designed crease between the cab and the truck bed that’s sleight of hand — a crease with a heavy black gasket pressed in behind it, which is totally a visual design device to make the truck look like it has a separate bed from the cab. It did make me raise one eyebrow when I realized that.

I’m one of the people who loved the old Ridgeline, so I didn’t need that black piece of rubber for my eyes to see it as more than a pickup truck. It doesn’t matter, anyway, whether this truck will appeal to the big-pickup-truck people, because that’s not their customer. Those people are going to buy a Ram, a GMC, or a Ford pickup. The Ridgeline is a play truck, not necessarily a work truck.

People may not have liked the old Ridgeline’s visual statement, but they liked everything else. And the 2017 Ridgeline still has all the cool things we liked about it. It has functionality for people who want a very light truck that will drive and handle well. And now, it conforms more to a traditional visual.

James Jenkins, Honda Trucks product planning manager, showed me the changes here on the Honda stand at the 2016 North American International Auto Show in Detroit.

Type: Five-passenger, front-engine, all-wheel-drive mid-size pickup truck
Release date: Early summer 2016
Estimated price range: $30,000 - $39,000
Competes against: Chevrolet Colorado, GMC Canyon, Nissan Frontier, Toyota Tacoma

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, rear-wheel-drive luxury sport sedan
Trim levels: ATS-V
Base price: $61,460 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $75,835
Engine: Twin-turbocharged 3.6-liter V-6, 464 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual with active rev matching and no-lift shift
Fuel economy: 16 mpg city/24 mpg highway
Safety: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: Not yet rated; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Not yet rated
Competition (all prices include destination charges):
2016 Audi S4 Prestige ($57,975)
2016 BMW M3 ($64,495)
2016 Mercedes-AMG C63 S ($74,175)
Fun-O-Meter: 9

Cadillac’s current design language can be polarizing, but there’s no question that it’s distinctive. And the most distinctive are those in the high-performance V-series, like this ATS-V sedan I just tested. This is a personal sport sedan, which is a beautiful thing to live with.

I used the ATS-V to commute to the North American International Auto Show in Detroit last week, where I parked right downtown in front of hotels. Every time the valet would bring me my car, at least one person, if not two or three, on the street stopped to look at it and asked me, What is this Cadillac?

You can get the ATS-V for 2016 in either coupe or sedan versions. The twin-turbo engine and the choice of transmissions are also new for 2016. All of those are even more reasons to look at the ATS-V this year.

Let’s not mince words: the ATS-V looks hot. The little points on it make it look like a folded airplane. It hangs together front to rear because there’s not as much between the two ends as on the larger Cadillac CTS-V.
But enough about the looks. Let’s talk about that powertrain.

The 2016 Cadillac ATS-V features the highest-output V-6 in the segment—464 horsepower—and its engine is also notable for being the very first time Cadillac has turbocharged a V-series model. This turbocharger is exceptional. The power comes on instantaneously, there’s a big roar out the back, and it’s viscerally and emotionally rewarding. The monster Brembo brakes are rewarding, too.

The twin-turbocharged V-6 in the ATS-V is one of GM’s more modern engines, technologically speaking. The point of two turbos is that one overlaps the other, so when you step on the gas you don’t get lag. The smaller turbo spins up faster to bridge the gap until the second turbo kicks in, so you have the seamless delivery of power, and there’s a lot of it.

The ATS-V was so exciting to drive that, between the power of those two turbos and the noise coming out of the exhaust, I became the hooligan I really am, hitting the gas over and over again to hear a roar and feel myself get thrown back in the seat while the exhaust was booming behind me. Loved it.
When you’re not doing that, the car is perfectly behaved. You don’t feel like it’s anxious or edgy in any way.
Between the power of those two turbos and the noise coming out of the exhaust, I became the hooligan I really am, hitting the gas over and over again to hear a roar.

The transmission on the car I tested is an eight-speed automatic with beautiful long, slender magnesium paddles behind the spokes of the wheel. I don’t usually use paddles, but I loved using these because they feel like real controls, not some bastardized version or some push button. I found them very satisfying to use. While you’re driving, you can reach up with your fingers to up- or downshift, and it is a beautiful, instantaneous shift quality. Of course, I most enjoy downshifting, because that’s when the sound and the fury come together.

Having said that, I would have loved to have tested the ATS-V with the standard six-speed manual transmission with Active Rev Match, which makes you feel like a driving genius and makes your track day ever so much more exciting. That would have saved $2,000, the price of the optional automatic transmission. It also would have added no-lift shifting new for 2016, which means you can shift without trying to figure out your feet.

Even though you might not care about 0-to-60-mph times, in this car, it’s 3.9 seconds. That is lightning fast. That literally is a matter of, hit the gas and your head will be slammed right into the seat. The top speed of this car is 189 mph, which explains why everyone was collecting around it everywhere I parked. You can’t beat a car that’s still turning heads and causing people to stop on the sidewalk even though it has been on sale for months.

Having driven the bigger CTS-V recently— the first V-series in 2004—it was interesting to compare, and I found that everything about the design that seemed overwhelming on the CTS-V looks better on the ATS-V.

When I drove a regular CTS, I felt a little cramped, and yet the ATS feels perfect, because the ATS-V is very simple inside. The scale seems better, minus about 80 percent of the bells and whistles, but with all the fun. Including a track setting, by the way, should you be so inclined. And if you’re looking at the V, you probably are.

Everything that felt a little garish about the CTS-V is dialed down in the ATS-V. You still have the shiny piano black and red, white, and blue color graphics for the gauges and controls, but there’s a lot less of it.

Let me talk for a minute about Cadillac’s Cue infotainment system. General Motors already has the excellent IntelliLink system on its other vehicles. I know Cadillac wants to be more fabulous, but if the Chevrolet Spark has a better infotainment system, that’s a sad commentary.

Cadillac’s Cue looks slick, but it’s not so slick to use it, starting with an uncomfortable interface between finger and dashboard controls. I don’t know if I’m supposed to make things happen by  tapping on the screen, resting my finger on the tiny metal bar under the screen, or actually moving the bar. Controls that should be simple, like setting the temperature, will change so slowly, you always have to look at it to figure out what’s going on.

Some of this is probably my fault. The Cue system works better if I don't pound on it like I’m playing Rachmaninoff. The lightest touch, almost like a proximity sensor, works very well. I can be such an animal.

As for voice recognition, it went out four days into my test period, so I couldn’t make calls while driving. One of the problems with all these controls is that, when they don’t work, you don’t know if it’s user error or something more serious. In the end, the electronic gremlin in voice recognition was fixed the way we fix most electronic glitches--I shut the ignition off, then I turned it back on, and it started to work again.

I’m sure if I lived with this car long enough, I would learn what it took to make that thing work, but its lack of intuitive operation is a bit much. Carmakers need to take that seriously, not only to make things easier on their customers, but because non-intuitive controls can seriously affect J.D. Power and Consumer Reports scores. Cadillac should follow Ford’s lead, throw in the towel, and move on. After years of problems with its Sync system, Ford now has a great Sync 3. They figured out that it has to be simple and clear. Don’t reinvent the wheel.
The way the whole interior is put together is first-rate. Someone knows what they’re doing in the interior design department.

Now the rest of the interior: gorgeous. This ATS-V had great Recaro sport seats that match the exterior design vibe. The way the whole interior is put together, from the carbon fiber strips to the nappy black pig suede materials, is first-rate. Someone knows what they’re doing in the interior design department. The use of the materials exudes beautifully executed luxury. The seats evoke the exterior’s folded-airplane design, and they’re super comfortable and very supportive.

The Cadillac ATS-V we tested carried $14,000 worth of options. The reason the paddle shifters feel so good is that they’re magnesium, and they’re part of the eight-speed automatic $2,000 option that comes with adaptive remote start.

The $6,195 Track Performance package has little to do with actual performance. It has an extra, low-mass battery, and everything else in the package is about cutting weight. The package deletes floor mats, tire sealant and inflator kit, and a tow hook. It adds carbon fiber front splitter, air extractor, and rear diffuser, plus composite black rocker extensions and a body-color rear spoiler. None of that has anything to do with the engine or brakes; it’s a primarily visual package with two extra pieces that have something to do with lowering weight. The ATS-V does look awesome with this package, but I don’t know if it adds $6,200 worth of awesome. But if you’re spending $60,000 already….

As for the other options, the Recaro seats would be hard to give up, even though they are priced at $2,300. The spectacular Red Obsession Tintcoat paint job adds $995. The wheels are polished but have red Brembo calipers behind them, which is an extra $595 but it actually means something: not only are they really cool-looking in red, they’re the hottest brand of brakes that make the difference between performance and non-performance cars. A Corvette wouldn’t be caught dead without Brembo brakes.

Cadillac Cue with Bose surround sound and navigation adds $1,085. If you want nav, you have to get Cue. As everyone should know by now about GM products, the OnStar five-year basic plan is included as standard, and so is the 4G LTE hot spot with a limited data trial.

The Verdict

Between the ATS-V and the CTS-V, Cadillac really has something to take to the track and to the performance competition from Europe. The CTS-V is a little less comfortable to me on a day-to-day basis.

The first ATS was more of a Lincoln competitor, although it had BMW 3 Series aspirations, as do all cars in this class. Now, this ATS-V comes right nose to nose with it, and is the car you can take to your neighbor’s BMW M3 as a worthy competitor.
It draws Cadillac right alongside BMW M and Mercedes AMG, the first American car to do it. And it is an all-American car, right down to the graphics of its red, white, and blue gauges.

If you’re one of those people who think a BMW equals jerky stockbrokers on Wall Street, this is definitely your car. If you were considering a BMW, Audi, or Mercedes-Benz, make sure you look at this car. It has a much fresher design, an American feel, a powerful engine, and a highly attractive interior. This is America’s first true head-to-head competitor against the cars the car enthusiasts have been holding up as the bar.

How fun is this car? So satisfying that I hated giving it back. If you like a high-performance car, appreciate luxury, can afford it, and don’t want what everyone else is having; if you’re looking for the next cool thing? This is it.

I've known Ralph since he joined Chrysler, and to see his growth as a leader in the design community has been very gratifying. This has been recognized by Fiat Chrysler Automobiles; he was just promoted to the position of global design chief of the FCA Group, succeeding the formidable Lorenzo Ramaciotti.

One of the things I like most about Ralph is that he also really knows how to enjoy himself and his vehicles. He has a very large following on Twitter because he's out at tracks, he's driving Vipers at club events, in the woods Jeeping, or with Jay Leno doing an episode of Jay's show. All this and the auto show, too.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five- or seven-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive mid-size crossover
Price range: $25,195-$42,595 (includes destination)
Trim levels: LX, EX, SX, SX Limited, Limited V6
Engines: 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 191 horsepower; turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 240 horsepower; 3.3-liter V-6, 290 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic with Sportmatic
Fuel economy (mpg): 2.4-liter FWD: 20 mpg city/27 mpg highway; 2.4-liter AWD: 19/25; V-6 FWD: 18/25; V-6 AWD: 18/24 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars overall; Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick
Our favorite standard feature: YES Essentials anti-stain fabric treatment
Notable standard features on this model: Front active headrests, hill start assist, stability control, second-row underfloor cargo storage
Notable options on this model: All-wheel drive, 19-inch wheels, programmable power liftgate, panoramic sunroof, second-row sliding sunshades, ventilated front seats
You might also be considering: Dodge Journey, Ford Edge, Toyota Highlander

The 2016 Kia Sorento has a new look, and that's important in a market segment with so much competition. How many crossovers, after all, can you look at before feeling a little overwhelmed (or bored)? The 2016 Sorento makes excellent use of LED lighting and body sculpting to catch your attention. There's also a new turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine making 240 horsepower, alongside a pair of other engine choices, a four-cylinder and a V-6. All are teamed with a six-speed automatic transmission. Interestingly, you can equip your Sorento with or without a third row of seats, giving you the choice whether to make it a five-passenger SUV or a seven-passenger.

The 2016 Sorento is slightly larger and roomier than the model it replaces: 3.1 inches longer in wheelbase, with 74 cubic feet of total cargo capacity, when seats are folded, versus 72.5 cubic feet in the past. That's on par with the Ford Edge (73.4 cubic feet) and a little better than the Honda CR-V (70.9 cubic feet).

New for 2016

2016 Sorento is an all-new model.

More to Read

title: 2016 Kia Forte and Forte5
subTitle: As a hatchback or a sedan, this is a lot of little car for a little money.
promoTeaserSmall: As a hatchback or a sedan, this is a lot of little car for a little money.
promoTeaser: As a hatchback or a sedan, this is a lot of little car for a little money.
metaDescription: As a hatchback or a sedan, this is a lot of little car for a little money.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive subcompact sedan, hatchback, or coupe
Price range: $16,840 – $20,840
Trim levels: LX, EX
Engines: 1.8-liter four-cylinder, 145 horsepower (LX); 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 173 horsepower (EX)
Transmission: Six-speed manual (LX), six-speed automatic (LX, EX)
Fuel economy: 25 mpg city/37 mpg highway (LX, manual); 26/39 mpg (LX, automatic); 24/35 mpg (EX, automatic)
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars (sedan); 5/5 stars side crash, 4/5 stars rollover, no overall rating (hatchback); Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good in four areas, Marginal in small overlap front crash testing
Our favorite standard feature: Bluetooth connectivity (standard on all models)
Notable standard features on this model: Rearview camera, leather-trimmed steering wheel, cooling glove box (standard on EX only)
Notable options on this model: Navigation with seven-inch touchscreen, sunroof, leather interior (EX Premium package, $3,000)
You might also be considering: Ford Focus, Honda Civic, Hyundai Elantra, Toyota Corolla

The Kia Forte is the very embodiment of an entry-level car: priced right starting under $17,000, it still comes standard with Bluetooth, keyless entry, and the basic amenities such as power-adjustable seats and power windows, meaning it's far from stripped down. The Forte is available in two body styles, hatchback and sedan; the Forte Koup was discontinued after the 2015 model year. There's even a sporty SX version of the Forte hatchback, featuring 201 horsepower from a turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine, paired with a standard six-speed manual transmission, and still coming in under $22,000. If you spring for the $3,000 EX Premium package—which will bring the total price up close to $25,000—you'll get such higher-end features as heated and ventilated seats, a seven-inch touchscreen with navigation, and a sunroof. On the savings end of the scale, the base LX will cost $1,000 more with automatic transmission, but it also edges close to the holy grail of 40 mpg with its 39-mpg highway numbers.

The Forte comes up against strong competition in the subcompact segment: the Honda Civic, Mazda 3, Ford Focus, Toyota Corolla, and many others. That ten-year, 100,000-mile warranty from Kia should be part of the argument for considering this car. Another is its good looks and reasonable interior space, falling only slightly short of the Honda Civic's. And a third is that a six-speed manual transmission is standard on the base Forte LX sedan and the Forte SX hatchback. That's increasingly hard to find.

Related story: Cars with Manual Transmissions You Can Buy Now

New for 2016

Forte LX gets four new colors, remote keyless entry, and rearview camera
Forte EX gets rearview camera and seventeen-inch alloy wheels
Navigation available on Forte EX (Premium package, $) Forte Koup is discontinued

title: 2016 Kia Rio
subTitle: A fresh face for the economy-minded subcompact.
promoTeaserSmall: A fresh face for the economy-minded subcompact.
promoTeaser: A fresh face for the economy-minded subcompact.
metaDescription: A fresh face for the economy-minded subcompact.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive subcompact sedan and hatchback
Price range: $15,015 – $21,605 (sedan); $16,345 – $21,755 (hatchback) (includes destination)
Trim levels: LX, EX, SX
Engine: 1.6-liter four-cylinder, 138 horsepower
Transmissions: Six-speed manual (sedan), six-speed automatic hatchback; optional on sedan)
Fuel economy: 27 mpg city/37 mpg highway
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Marginal (small overlap front); Good (moderate overlap front, roof strength, head restraints & seats), and Acceptable (side); National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars overall rating, with safety concerns noted
Our favorite standard feature: Direct-injection engine
Notable standard features on this model: Stability control, hill start assist, steering-wheel-mounted audio controls, 60/40 split-folding rear seats
Notable options on this model: Push-button start, Bluetooth connectivity, UVO2 infotainment system
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Spark, Ford Fiesta, Honda Fit, Nissan Versa

If you're looking for a bargain-priced, entry-level car, this is one of the more attractive offerings out there. Ante up a little more cash, and you can get the SX, with a sportier suspension, paddle shifters on the steering column, and a leather-wrapped steering wheel, plus uplevel amenities such as navigation, push-button start, a rearview camera, and a power sunroof.

The hatchback version, called the Rio Five-Door, is cuter than the sedan in our opinion. Both models, though, have their strong points. One in particular is the six-speed manual transmission in the Rio sedan, an increasingly hard-to-find feature these days (it was discontinued from the hatchback for 2016). You can get the sedan with an automatic at a $1,230 upcharge.

If you're truly looking for a cheap base model, you can't beat the LX with its under-$15,000 price, even though features modern car buyers take for granted, such as power windows and locks, keyless entry, and Bluetooth connectivity are all optional. The mid-level EX model adds those things, plus a Designer package, new for 2016, costs $750 and adds black-and-gray cloth and leather seat trim, with gray stitching throughout, and a 4.3-inch touchscreen and a rearview camera. A $600 Eco package, also for the EX, adds a stop/start system for fuel saving and some lighting and other interior upgrades.

New for 2016

The Kia Rio was updated for 2016, with the new model rolled out at the 2015 Chicago Auto Show.
New front and rear fascias update the look.
Two new colors: Urban Blue and Digital Yellow

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: You’ve heard of snow tires. You’ve heard of all-season tires. Now get ready for the variable condition tire, the Toyo Celsius. Not a pure snow or winter tire, but more than a traditional all-season tire, the Celsius is a true hybrid.

Toyo Celsius Tires

Type: Variable conditions
Variants: Celsius Passenger, Celsius CUV
Benefits: Warranty for 60,000 miles; 500-mile/45-day "no regrets" trial offer
Claimed to stop up to 14 feet shorter on snow and eight feet shorter on ice than an all-season tire
Celsius CUV tires claimed to stop up to 31 feet shorter on snow than an all-season tire

The asymmetrical tread design, Toyo says, will help the Celsius perform well, no matter what conditions Mother Nature throws at you. Although it’s intended for areas that don’t get a lot of snow but do deal with slush and rainfall, the Celsius still is intended to be an improvement over all-season tires. It has higher sipe density on the inside tread for ice and snow, and lower sipe density on the outside tread for wet and dry conditions.

The Toyo jargon includes talk of “snow claws” and “slush grooves,” but the bottom line is, this tire is built to handle snowy and wet conditions, yet still deliver a quiet ride. Best of all, these tires, unlike dedicated snow tires, are suitable for year-round driving.
All of that explains why I knocked over my colleagues to be the one to test them, and I currently have a set on my 2003 Volkswagen Passat.

I am a hard-core believer in snow tires. I live in Michigan and understand that tires are first responders in an emergency. Hopefully, they will help me avoid needing the airbags or any of the other safety equipment. But I am a huge procrastinator. I have been known to put on my snow tires in January and take them off in July. So a tire that I put on and leave on until the tread wears off is a hell-yes for me.
The beauty of the Toyo Celsius tire is that I can leave them on all year long, with no need to go back to the tire store until I need to rotate my tires.

The beauty of the Toyo Celsius tire is that I can leave them on all year long, with no need to go back to the tire store until I need to rotate my tires. When I would flip back and forth from summer to winter tires, I loathed the trip to get them changed,  and storing the off-season set in my cluttered garage was a hassle. Somehow, I always seemed to be at the store during a snowstorm with every other procrastinator, and a tire store is the very last place I want to be during Michigan’s micro summers.

Getting the Toyo Celsius tires in place was an education in itself. Here’s what I learned: If you’re interested in trying these, you’ll may have to special order them. This is a new product that you won’t find in every shop. In my case, UPS dropped off my tires. They came nude, no box, with the shipping label taped to the tire itself. That was when I realized I needed to find a place to actually install them. I have always bought my tires directly from the tire store. During the process, I have always felt rushed and overwhelmed. But coming in with my own tires and just needing the installation I felt more in charge.

When you buy tires directly from a retailer, the installation is much cheaper than the charge when you bring in your own tires. At my local store, Discount Tire in Ann Arbor, Michigan, the charge $64 ($16 per tire) to install tires that you purchase directly from them, which includes rotation and balancing for the life of the tire. I paid much more—$156—to have Discount Tire dismount my old tires, mount the Toyo Celsius tires I brought in, and balance them. Future rotation is included, but any balancing that might be needed in the future is not.

In the past, I never called and made an appointment; I just showed up and inevitably sat around for a few hours waiting for my turn. This time I made an appointment and was in and out in about forty minutes. I strongly suggest you do the same.

The process of getting my tires installed was like a symphony. There was a director behind a podium overseeing the process as the team scurried around and quickly removed my tires. It was a sloppy winter’s day, far past the prime time to slip on your winter shoes. I had thoughtfully washed my car before bringing it in to make the job a little nicer for the installers. As I watched them working together to move cars through at a pace that would make Henry Ford crack a smile, I thought that they deserved a heated floor.

The question of whether to buy your tires remotely or at a tire store comes down to economics. The cost from an online seller may be cheaper, but the cost of installation may offset those savings. I found the Celsius available online for $82 per tire, plus shipping. My local Discount Tire did not offer the tire so I cannot compare apples to apples, but it’s always important to compare not only price per tire, but installation charges.

So, should you count on shopping locally for tires? Consider the pros and cons, such as being able to research your tires on the Internet, take your pick from a much larger selection than you’ll find at a single store, and possibly get a price deal; all of that might outweigh the higher installation cost and the hassle factor of  getting tires mailed to you, then lugging them to the tire installer.

As for the tires, so far I am very pleased with the ride and the lack of noise—and I must admit that the very mild winter we’ve had so far has been an easy test environment for these “variable condition” tires. Conditions have been variable as hell in Michigan! Still, I am hoping for a big dump of snow like the one New England recently received to give the tires a real test. Fingers crossed that my next report on the Toyo Celsius will include the yet-to-be-named storm of the century.

images.caption: My Volkswagen Passat, getting its Toyo Celsius tires installed.
Toyo Celsius tires as they arrived via UPS.
Discount Tire employees swarmed the car.
Passat about to get its new tires.

title: 2016 Nissan Sentra SL
subTitle: An attractive small car, strong on basics, hold the excitement.
promoTeaserSmall: An attractive small car, strong on basics, hold the excitement.
promoTeaser: An attractive small car, strong on basics, hold the excitement.
metaDescription: An attractive small car, strong on basics, hold the excitement.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive mid-size sedan
Base price: $23,005 (prices include destination charge)
This car: $25,545
Trim levels: S, SV, FE+S, SR, SL
Engine:1.8-liter four-cylinder, 130 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic
Fuel economy: 29 mpg city/38 mpg highway
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars; Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick
My favorite standard feature: NissanConnect with navigation (SL model)
Option I can’t live without: Forward emergency braking (part of Technology package, $1,230)
Notable standard features on this model: Seventeen-inch alloy wheels, four-wheel disc brakes, LED headlights, fog lights, heated side mirrors with LED turn signal repeaters, leather seats, heated front seats, six-way power-adjustable driver seat with power lumbar, NissanConnect with navigation and mobile apps, 5.8-inch color touchscreen, audio and navigation voice recognition, blind spot warning, rear cross-traffic alert
Notable options on this model: Power tilting moonroof, Bose premium audio (part of SL Premium package, $1,130); intelligent cruise control, forward emergency braking, NissanConnect emergency and remote services (part of Technology package, $1,230)
You might also be considering: Ford Focus, Honda Civic, Hyundai Elantra, Mazda 3, Toyota Corolla, Volkswagen Jetta
The Sentra is a perennial Nissan staple. It has been competing in the compact sedan market since 1982, through seven generations, the most recent generation making its debut in 2013.

The current Sentra still belongs to that generation, but Nissan has given the car an extensive freshening for 2016 that includes new front end sheetmetal, revised rear end trim, several interior updates, and retuned suspension.

The net result is a Sentra with a stronger family resemblance to the mid-size Nissan Altima—which is not a bad thing—and one that’s also more responsive to commands coming from the helm. That’s not a bad thing, either.
Nissan engineers have made improvements to the Sentra’s electric power steering gear, increasing system stiffness and altering steering effort, providing a strong sense of connection and accuracy.
There's a firmer feel to the Sentra’s ride and quicker response in rapid maneuvers. Very useful in emergency situations, e.g., a rhinoceros suddenly trots into your path.

Simultaneously, the chassis team has selectively stiffened the structure; they've made small increases in the spring rates and corresponding adjustments to the shock absorbers. There's a firmer feel to the Sentra’s ride and quicker response in rapid maneuvers. Very useful in emergency situations, e.g., a rhinoceros suddenly trots into your path or (more plausibly) a chicken decides to cross the road. Why is it crossing the road? Who cares. The instinct to avoid is automatic, and vehicle response time is critical.

Power can be another ally in situations calling for quick maneuvers, but that’s not a Sentra strong suit. There is one engine, a 1.8-liter four-cylinder rated for 130 horsepower. That’s near the bottom of the list for standard engines among compact sedans, and most of the Sentra’s major competitors offer optional engines that deliver even more power.
There are two transmission options, a six-speed manual and a continuously variable automatic (CVT). Progress can be charitably characterized as unhurried with either one.

There are two transmission options, a six-speed manual and a continuously variable automatic (CVT). Progress can be charitably characterized as unhurried with either one, particularly the CVT, and there’s a catch concerning the manual: it’s offered only in the basic S trim level.

If you choose the base Sentra S, you'll be faced with a modest (albeit adequate) list of standard equipment and no possibility of adding extras like navigation or upgrades to the audio. Nissan’s rationale for this limitation is that the take rate for manual transmissions is very low, although it could be argued that the arrangement all but guarantees exactly the situation the company presents as an excuse for its policy.

On the other hand, Nissan has done more than most in developing the CVT, and one employed in the Sentra exhibits few of the objectionable traits associated with this transmission type in the past, i.e., a sense of the engine and transmission being out of sync. And the one Sentra model (FE+S) that hits the magic 40-mpg highway rating by the EPA sends power to the front wheels via a CVT.

Beyond that, the Sentra’s firmer suspension tuning doesn’t seem to have compromised ride quality; compliance is still supple, no sharp bumps find their way into the bones of those within, and Nissan’s noise-suppression measures have also paid off—the car operates at the quiet end of the compact auditory scale.

Inside, Nissan has updated the Sentra’s trim and upholstery materials (leather optional) and added six-way power adjustability and power lumbar for the driver’s seat along with a redesigned center console, a new shift knob, and a sporty three-spoke steering wheel that affords a very satisfying grip.

There are also new driver assist features, including a customizable 5.0-inch LCD display sandwiched between the tachometer and speedometer registering information such as navigation details, fuel consumption, and safety prompts including blind spot monitoring and rear cross-traffic alert.

The techies have also upgraded NissanConnect infotainment system and added Siri Eyes Free, and there’s a center-dash screen displaying audio info and navigation (optional), although, at 5.8 inches, this is rather small compared with those offered by some of the Sentra’s competitors.

In addition to the standard items—blind spot monitoring and rear cross-traffic alert—the 2016 inventory includes adaptive cruise control and forward emergency braking, which can bring the car to a halt short of a crash. Nissan has earned the Top Safety Pick rating from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.
Base prices range from $17,615 to $23,005 across five trim levels: S, the fuel-saving FE+S, SV (from $19,385), SR (from $21,245), and Premium. And of course there are several option packages.

Our test car was an SL, which came with two option packages. The SL Premium package cost $1,130 and included a power sliding moonroof, eight-speaker Bose premium audio, and illuminated vanity mirrors,. The $1,230 Technology package bundles adaptive cruise control, forward emergency braking, and NissanConnect services (automatic collision notification, stolen vehicle locator, and remote services including car unlock, dealer service scheduling, speed alert, and curfew alert). A set of floor mats ($180), plus an $835 delivery charge, rounded the as-tested total to $25,545.

The Verdict

The Sentra is a solid small car with an impressive reliability heritage. Nissan claims that 93 percent of the Sentras sold in the past ten years—some 200,000 last year alone—are still on the road, and judging by this latest example, that’s not surprising. From a marketing perspective, this is a narrow-focus car—one size fits all, trim levels notwithstanding. One rather tepid engine, no sport model, no coupe, no all-wheel-drive option, no hybrid because, if you want alternative propulsion, Nissan wants you to buy the pure electric Leaf.

There’s nothing remotely exciting here, and material upgrades notwithstanding, the interior doesn’t measure up to some competing compacts. On the other hand, the Sentra looks good; it’s quiet, comfortable, reasonably thrifty, well made, and durable; and the value proposition is solid.

title: The Women of Mustang
subTitle: Don't think a pony car is a women's car? Oh, how sadly wrong you are.
promoTeaserSmall: Don't think a pony car is a women's car? Oh, how sadly wrong you are.
promoTeaser: Don't think a pony car is a women's car? Oh, how sadly wrong you are.
metaDescription: The Women of Mustang: Don't think a pony car is a women's car? Oh, how sadly wrong you are. Read about it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: In honor of National Women’s History Month, today only (Wednesday, March 12), Ford is inviting you to submit questions for the women of the current Mustang team via Twitter. Here’s the link.

It was a Mad Men world back when the first Ford Mustang came out, fifty years ago. Even without the visual evidence of the mid-1960s ads you see here, you could just imagine the macho imagery of advertising for the first pony car, and you’d be absolutely right. "A car to make weak men strong and strong men invincible!"

So it’s especially funny that the very first 1964-1/2 Mustang was purchased by…Gail Wise, a woman from Chicago. Not just a woman, but an elementary school teacher. Then in her early twenties, she traded in her mom's Chevy, putting down the $3,419 two days before its official on-sale date and becoming the first owner of a production Mustang. (And she’s still got the car, a convertible in Skylight Blue with Rally Pac instrumentation and the 260-cubic-inch V-8, now restored.)
It’s not surprising that Ford didn’t make a lot of noise about that fact at the time.
But they made almost a million Mustangs in the first model year, and we’re betting there were a lot more young guys than female school teachers in the buying demographic.

Guys like my dad, Frank Brown, who bought a white ’65 coupe when I was in elementary school myself and he was in his mid-thirties. He couldn’t resist the Mustang’s charms—but then, neither could Mary Jean Wesche, editor of the Mustang Club of America’s Mustang Times. She says she “absolutely fell in love with the car” the minute she spotted it on display at the 1964 World’s Fair. Mary Jean has been a Mustang lifer ever since

In the 1980s, perhaps the woman most associated with the Mustang was Lyn St. James, who raced them. “I’m a product of the muscle car era,” she says, but she pronounces the modern Mustangs “still hot.”

Over the years, the Mustang has been a quintessential hot American car. It may be about to turn fifty, but Ford is to be commended for changing with the times and making an utterly modern new 2015 Mustang that people of any gender can lust after.
Ford is to be commended for changing with the times and making an utterly modern new 2015 Mustang that people of any gender can lust after.

With all of that in mind, Ford can be forgiven for a little woodenness in the way it is pursuing the female demographic. For example, there’s the commemorative nail polish from OPI, a subsidiary of COTY, in Race Red—launching internationally in July. OPI’s co-founder, Suzi Weiss-Fischmann, made the statement that “For women, cars and nail lacquer offer a way to express personality.”

But we’ll let Mustang vehicle line director Marcy Fisher—or Mustang vehicle integration supervisor Michele Lubin Henney—or chief color and materials designer Susan Lampinen—or U.S. Mustang brand manager Melanie Banker “express personality” instead, OK? These women, posing with the 2015 Mustang at the top of this page, understand the athleticism and performance that a Mustang is all about. They’re integral parts of the team bringing it to market. And they’re only the latest in a fifty-year history in which women have been engineers, designers, executives—and customers—of the Ford Mustang.
Kind of makes you want to paint your nails Race Red and hit the gas, doesn’t it?

images.caption: "Sweetheart of the Supermarket Set," eh? Ford's marketing efforts toward women have improved since then.
Desmond (left) and Wolfgang (right) found their Y chromosomes after buying a Mustang. These are actually smart and funny ads for their time.
Mustang team is anchored by Marcy Fisher, Michele Lubin Henney, Susan Lampinen, and Melanie Banker.
Race Red nail polish: okay, joking aside, this is pretty cool.
Ford is working hard to target women for its new Mustang.
The 2015 Ford Mustang: it's still got it.

title: A Teenager's First Road Trip
subTitle: Mom put me in charge of planning the whole drive from Texas to Michigan. Here's my five-point plan.
promoTeaserSmall: Mom put me in charge of planning the whole drive from Texas to Michigan. Here's my five-point plan.
promoTeaser: Mom put me in charge of planning the whole drive from Texas to Michigan. Here's my five-point plan.
metaTitle: A Teenager's First Road Trip - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: A Teenager's First Road Trip: Mom put me in charge of planning the whole drive from Texas to Michigan. Here's my five-point plan. See it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: I am seventeen and in high school, and I’m planning my very first road trip. My mom and I are going on a spring break drive from Texas to Michigan, and I get to do all the planning. I believe the Girl Scout motto, “Be prepared,” is also the rule of the road for long-distance travel, but until now, it has been up to my parents to do the preparing. This time, it's all me! So for my first trip, I broke it down into five planning steps.

Of course, this isn't really the first road trip I've been on. I have been on dozens of driving vacations with my family—it is really a sweet way to travel. My mom and dad do all of the planning as well as the driving, and I just show up. As an only child I have the entire back seat of the car to create my cozy lair—pillows, blankets, snacks, movies, books, etc. And the very best part: I can spend the time watching movies until we magically arrive at our destination. My parents are always telling me to look out the window and see America fly by.

But this time, I will be watching, since I'm in charge of every step of this trip, and as the navigator I will be responsible for everything except the driving. This is my parents’ sneaky way of preparing me for future road trips without them. Here are the steps I'm following.

1. Make a Budget

You need to think about the big picture—food, gas, a roof over your head, and any expenses for activities along the way. You can easily calculate the gas portion by going to the trip planner at fueleconomy.gov. If you enter your vehicle’s specs and your itinerary, it will give you an estimate of the cost of gas for your trip. The accommodation portion will vary depending on whether you will be couch surfing or staying at a five-star hotel. For our trip we are using Airbnb to book our rooms to try and stay at some unique places. It is also important to have access to a credit card in case you have an emergency. And if you are a shopper, keep in mind you will need a little extra cabbage for mementos.

2. Set Your Route

A huge part of a successful road trip starts with planning the route. Once you pick the destination, you have to decide if you are going directly, or do you have time for some stops along the way. Another big decision is the type of road that you want to drive on—all Interstate or highway, or possibly a combination. There are many apps available to make it easy to plan. I used roadtrippers.com to find and add sightseeing opportunities along the way. Start exploring the route ahead of time so you have an adequate amount of time to explore your options. This advance planning will make the trip run a whole lot smoother, and for first-timers like me, it will help make your parents happy. But be flexible when you are on your trip if for some reason you need to take a detour. Sometimes unplanned adventures can be the best part of a road trip.

3. Prepare Your Car

Give your car a thorough once-over before leaving the driveway so you won't have any nasty surprises on the trip. You need to check the fluid levels, tires, belts, hoses, and wipers. If you have an older car, or if you are a novice like me under the hood, it is a good idea to take it to a mechanic for a once-over.

4. Gather Essential Documents

Before you leave on any extended trip, make sure all of your paperwork is in order. Put your registration and proof of insurance in an envelope inside the glove compartment, and double check that your insurance is up to date. It is a good idea to have an emergency kit in the car, such as this one. Chances are you will never need it, but it may prove to be a lifesaver. If I break down, my first call will be to my roadside assistance, but there are circumstances where you need to be prepared to take care of yourself. It is also helpful to stash a few items to cleanup spills in the car in your emergency kit. After all, if you spill a soda in your lap, that is truly an emergency. We all rely on electronic navigation, but it is a good idea to throw in an old-fashioned map like the one my grandparents use.

5. Stay in Touch

It is a good idea to make sure someone knows your itinerary and timeframe before you leave, and then to plan check-ins along the road. If you tend to the adventurous side and have a misadventure, a well-informed friend can get help to you faster—this is especially true if you are a lone wolf. With today’s social media options it is fun to share your progress with your peeps, but as adults have warned me, hold back before you provide too much detail about your location that can be seen by the general public on the Internet.
I'll be checking in from the road next week, so stay tuned! Any last-minute suggestions of things to see between Austin and Detroit will be welcomed!

title: On the Road: GMC Terrain Denali AWD
subTitle: Our mom & daughter trip, days 2 & 3: finding treasures (and trash) in Hot Springs and Little Rock.
promoTitle: On the Road: GMC Terrain Denali AWD
promoTeaserSmall: Our mother-daughter trip, days 2 and 3: finding treasures and trash in Hot Springs and Little Rock.
promoTeaser: Our mother-daughter trip, days 2 and 3: finding treasures and trash in Hot Springs and Little Rock.
metaTitle: On the Road: GMC Terrain Denali AWD - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaKeywords: On the Road: GMC Terrain Denali AWD
metaDescription: On the Road: GMC Terrain Denali AWD: Days two and three, in which mom and daughter travel from Texas through Arkansas and find some treasures (and some trash). Read details on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: If you read A Teenager's First Road Trip last week, you know that I'm a high school junior and I was just given the privilege of being put in charge of planning a cross-country road trip with my mom. On Day 1, we left Austin, Texas, headed north. We've just finished Day 3 of that trip now, and here's how it's going:

Day 2: Dallas to Hot Springs, Arkansas

For the second day of our trip from Austin, Texas, to Ann Arbor, Michigan, we loaded our bags into the 2014 GMC Terrain Denali AWD. Since our hands were always full when we arrived at the car, we were happy that it came equipped with a power rear liftgate. Having survived a brutal Michigan winter, the temperature of nearly seventy degrees Fahrenheit made us opt for shorts, and of course we made sure the sunroof was fully exposed to get some Vitamin-D-replacing sunshine into the car.

In the bright sunshine, we noticed that the Dallas neighborhood where we'd stayed, in lodgings found on Airbnb, was showing signs of new life. Just down the street, the hammers were already pounding as we drove out of town at 9:00 a.m.

We were excited to get to Hot Springs, in the Ouachita Mountains. We had booked ourselves into The Springs Hotel and Spa. The spa part had us so excited that we had not planned any side trips, so that the pampering could begin. The sky was ominous as we worked our way up I-30. The road was thick with trucks and peppered with orange construction barrels. The GMC Terrain can be equipped to monitor both traffic and weather, which would have been really helpful for our drive. Again, I was awed by the smooth pavement and realized how embarrassing the Michigan roads are for our state. I could imagine someone making a spoof “Pure Michigan” ad about our roads.

We exited I-30 in Arkadelphia, Arkansas, and drove through twisty mountain roads. The excitement was building as we neared the town and drove past scenic lakes with islands in the distance. The miles ticked down on the nav screen as the clouds continued to brew overhead. As we started to drive through Hot Springs,  our enthusiasm started to plummet. It was not the quaint mountain town we had envisioned, but actually, we later discovered, had a population of 35,000. The part of town that we drove through was actually quiet, although run down. But we pushed on, remembering that our exciting spa awaited our arrival, and the therapeutic hot springs would revive us.
The miles ticked down on the nav screen as the clouds continued to brew overhead. As we started to drive through Hot Springs, our enthusiasm started to plummet.

Finally we started to see the bathhouses that we had seen online, and our spirits lifted. We pulled up to our spa hotel, parked around the back of the hotel in a grimy chain-link-lined parking lot, and walked around to the front door. The lobby had obviously seen better days, but we checked in and headed up to our room. The elevator was old and creaky, and my mind wandered to horror movies. We laughed and prayed that we wouldn’t get stuck between floors. We did not.

Once we opened the door to our room, the soundtrack to Psycho should have been playing in the background. Right in the middle of the carpet was a perfect burn in the shape of an iron, the smoke alarm was hanging off the wall, and the vents were so dirty that we feared what was living in the walls. But the cherry on top was a necklace sitting on the floor, in plain view. Yep, we ran out of that hotel faster than Scooby and the gang.

I was ready to get the hell out of Hot Springs, but my mom forced me to take a tour of a bathhouse. It is now part of the National Parks system. It was interesting, but also slightly creepy. She also insisted that we drive up to the Hot Springs Mountain Tower. Apparently baseball legends such as Babe Ruth trained on the trails and took advantage of the hot springs. It didn’t appear to me that much had changed since then. I finally convinced her to continue on to Little Rock.

And guess what? It did rock. Little Rock is not only the capital, but it is modern and clean. We checked into the Residence Inn right downtown. The room was like a mini apartment, with full-size appliances and granite counters. We quickly unloaded and walked right across the street and ate a fabulous meal at Dizzy’s Gypsy Bistro. We both ordered soup, but this was no ordinary soup: each bowl was made on the spot. Who knew soup could be gourmet? We waddled home, showered, and nestled down beneath our fluffy white down blankets.

Day 3: Little Rock to Memphis, Tennessee

As we drove into Little Rock we had seen museums, the Clinton Library, and the electric wires of the River Rail Trolley system. I surprised my mom with tickets to the trolley so that we could tour the town. We jumped on right in front of our hotel. It makes a loop through the downtown, and you can jump off wherever you want. We hopped off near a restaurant that we had read about—the Flying Fish. Its claim to fame is if you give them your Billy Bass, they will give you a basket of catfish. But gimmicks aside, the food was great.

We wandered through River Market Books & Gifts. It had mostly used books and crafts from local artists as well as a lunch counter. The shop was enchanting, and we could have spent the afternoon lost in the old books. But we also wanted to get to Memphis.

We headed out of Little Rock with the help of the nav system on I-40. The highway was packed with trucks, but we ticked off the miles solving whodunit stories and listening to Pandora. The side blind zone alert and lane departure warning assisted us as we worked our way north. The car was equipped with a rear-seat entertainment system, but my mom would not be pleased if I retreated to the rear seats. But perhaps tomorrow I can convince her to let me test the multi-flexible  sliding rear seat.
I believe my mom ignored fuel warning signs that had popped up in the infotainment screen. She needs one that says “Hey, lady, get gas now.”

My mom suddenly noticed our gas gauge was below empty. I believe she had ignored warning signs that had popped up in the infotainment screen. She needs one that says “Hey, Lady, get gas now.” Unfortunately for us, it was at the exact time the highway traffic came to an abrupt stop. My mom was really nervous, but we did make it to the gas station and filled our thirsty tank.

At this point we needed to find an alternate route, so we pushed the OnStar button and asked for assistance. The OnStar people pushed a turn-by-turn route into our vehicle, and we followed it right into Memphis. Strangely, the on-board map didn’t function properly, but the voice commands were correct. We used our iPhones to follow the map.
Priscilla Presley used to have her hair done at this restaurant. We ordered gelato to go, walked back, and promptly fell asleep in the town where Elvis slept.

We were a little worried as we pulled into Memphis that we were entering a rough neighborhood, but once we turned the street of our Airbnb house, we realized that it was a great area. It is in the Cooper-Young Historic District, and it is fantastic. We quickly unloaded and walked the block over to have a quick dinner at The Beauty Shop, where I ate my grilled corn beneath a vintage hair dryer. Apparently, Priscilla Presley used to have her hair done at this restaurant. We ordered gelato to go and walked the block back to our house and promptly fell asleep in the town where Elvis slept.

images.caption: Right outside our cabin in Dallas.
Wondering if there was a tornado in the neighborhood.
Twisting roads between Arkadelphia and Hot Springs.
The parking lot at our Hot Springs hotel didn't make a good impression.
Inside the room, we wondered if a murder with an iron had taken place here.
The dust collection on the vent made me sneeze just looking at it.
The second-to-last straw in our sketchy hotel room in Hot Springs was a random necklace on the floor.
The obviously useless smoke detector was the last straw.
One of the many lovely hotels in Hot Springs.
