One of the therapy baths. The tile was pretty, but it really looked primitive.
The view from the top of the mountain in Hot Springs.
The Residence Inn in Little Rock proved to be a little slice of heaven.
Gourmet chicken noodle soup from Dizzy's Gypsy Bistro.
Even the underpass in Little Rock was cute.
Bird's-eye view of the old capitol in Little Rock.
Hold tight, everyone: captain Elle is taking over the trolley.
Mom getting her closeup on the River Rail Trolley System.
GMC Terrain Denali AWD, along the riverfront in Little Rock.
GMC Terrain Denali AWD, along the riverfront in Little Rock.
GMC Terrain Denali AWD, along the riverfront in Little Rock.
Waiting for lunch at Flying Fish in Little Rock
Inside the first ever Billy Bass adoption center.
Packing up outside our sweet hotel in Little Rock.
I think we may have taken a wrong turn into a truck stop.
Construction work is more common than fried catfish.
When we reached the top of the bridge, we were in Tennessee.
Outside our little house in Memphis. Our house is actually in the backyard.
First view of our little house in Memphis.
Sitting in a chair where Priscilla Presley once sat in the Beauty Shop restaurant in Memphis.
Flipping through the vinyl at Goner Records in Memphis.

title: On the Road: Nashville to Home
subTitle: 2014 GMC Terrain Denali AWD from Music Row to a Miley Cyrus concert. Mom-and-daughter trip wraps up.
promoTitle: On the Road: Nashville to Home
promoTeaserSmall: 2014 GMC Terrain Denali AWD from Music Row to a Miley Cyrus concert. Mom-and-daughter trip wraps up.
promoTeaser: 2014 GMC Terrain Denali AWD from Music Row to a Miley Cyrus concert. Mom-and-daughter trip wraps up.
keywords: On the Road: Nashville to Home
metaTitle: On the Road: Nashville to Home - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: On the Road: Nashville to Home. 2014 GMC Terrain Denali AWD from Music Row to a Miley Cyrus concert. Mom-and-daughter trip wraps up. Read the story on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
If you read A Teenager's First Road Trip last week, you know that I'm a high school junior and I was just given the privilege of being put in charge of planning a cross-country road trip with my mom. We just got home, and here's my wrapup.

Catch up with part 1 (Austin to Dallas), part 2 (Arkansas), and part 3 (Nashville, headed north).

Nashville to Cincinnati

We woke up in our dreamy Airbnb rental and planned to spend the day in Nashville. It just fit to be wandering the town in the 2014 GMC Terrain Denali AWD. I was on a mission to get something to wear to the Miley Cyrus concert back home in Ann Arbor the next day, and my mom wanted to get a taste of this town. We listened to our hosts' records while we packed and then headed to the Ugly Mug coffee shop for a quick bagel. Later, we were heading to Cincinnati to pick up two of my girlfriends.

Our first stop was the gift store Welcome Home. I literally wanted everything in the store. I ended up buying awesome temporary tattoos. They seemed appropriate because East Nashville was filled with tattoo-sporting humans. Next we found a cute shopping district, Shoppes on Fatherland, also in East Nashville. As we whipped around these unknown areas, we were happy to have the backup camera. We noticed that the monitor is much clearer than one we have on our Chrysler Town & Country. We came away without a purchase and headed out to find the music scene in Nashville and grab a lunch.

As we searched for the country music part of Nashville that we have seen so many times on TV, we found a barbecue spot, the Judge's Vinegarroon, and ate a delicious lunch. Then we went straight to Music Row. We knew we were there because it was packed with people, and we could hear the music coming out of every bar. The neon signs were great. I am sure that at night this place turns into a giant party. I was overwhelmed by all of the people, though, and convinced my mom to head to a mall so that I could get my Miley outfit.

We spent a few hours there. I know, I know, I was in Nashville, and I shouldn’t have wasted our time. But Miley was going to bring a little country to me in only twenty-four hours. This is what you get when traveling with a teenage girl. When we finally left Nashville, it was starting to get dark, which was actually perfect so that we could get in some night driving in strange territory.

As the sun set behind us, we decided that we were not huge fans of the red lights that light up the GMC Terrain's dashboard and center console. I prefer blue or white lights. In fact, my mom had a hard time getting used to the transmission shifter's lights, too. It had a white light for the gear you are in, and the rest are red. I wonder if they choose red to go with the red stitching that lines the dashboard? I liked the stitching and found the rest of the dashboard both good-looking and easy to use.

The night driving made driving through the construction even more difficult. At night, the side blind zone alert really stood out on our side mirrors, which was very helpful. We were tired and some of the areas had bright lights, and the cement barriers made it seem like the lanes were even narrower. My mom used this as a teaching moment, telling me that until I am a more experienced driver I should always try to reach my destination during the day.

We talked about our week with the Terrain and what we thought about the ride. The fuel economy of the four-cylinder engine was perfect for our highway cross-country trip. We were still able to merge and accelerate when we needed to with ease. Every now and then it would lurch when my mom really punched it. But as a passenger, I felt it was smooth, and inside the cabin it was pretty quiet. Most of the roads on this trip have proved to be smooth, which will not be the case at home in Michigan.
As we pushed through the night, the Terrain's nav failed us and went berserk. Just as we needed it at a tricky interchange, it froze to where it wouldn’t even shut off.

As we pushed through the night, the Terrain's nav failed us and went berserk. Just as we needed it at a tricky interchange, it froze to the point where it wouldn’t even shut off. It finally turned off and back on, but our route was lost, and so we  switched to using our iPhones. This happened twice during our drive and would prompt a trip to the dealer upon our return.

Cincinnati to Ann Arbor

It was dark when we arrived in Cincinnati, but we had planned on a copule of hours to take a quick walk around before we picked up two of my girlfriends from camp, who were joining us to drive up to the concert in Michigan. The Reds fans were everywhere. We had dinner in a great restaurant, Nada, which was directly across the street from the Contemporary Arts Center. The food was fantastic, and it was great to be eating our last meal outside before we would be joined by my friends. In some ways, this was the end of the trip with my mom.

We picked up my girlfriends in Mariemont, just outside Cincinnati, and we were stoked to see each other and even more so about the concert. We quickly crammed their bags into the car—it is amazing how much we girls pack for an overnight. It took some work, but everything fit. My friends agreed to give me some feedback about the back seat, since I had spent our entire trip riding shotgun. They liked how the seat was slightly reclined and were impressed with the legroom. They liked how the entire entertainment system was built into the back of the front seats.

What I Learned

During the past week with my mom, I have learned so much about road trips and how planning them makes things run smoothly. It was nice to have all of our accommodations set beforehand. One thing I learned was that I need to research neighborhoods and parts of town more carefully. If I had been alone, I would not have been comfortable in some of the places we ended up.

The Terrain was an excellent car for exploring the South. All the safety equipment made me feel that we were well taken care of on the road, and this SUV's size made us comfortable, never cramped. The spacious seats and amount of storage as well as the (mostly) great navigation assistance made the time spent driving much more pleasant. The trip with my mom was amazing, and I am so happy I got the chance to experience planning a road trip. As you can see, we all got home in time to get our Miley Cyrus faces on. Now, where should I go on my own road trip?

images.caption: Exploring Nashville by 2014 GMC Terrain Denali AWD.
It was already spring in Nashville. 2014 GMC Terrain Denali AWD.
We gave the GMC Terrain a wash before we left Nashville.

title: 2015 Toyota Camry
subTitle: The high-stakes top-selling sedan is updated, now with more waku-doki.
promoTeaserSmall: The high-stakes top-selling sedan is updated, now with more waku-doki.
promoTeaser: The high-stakes top-selling sedan is updated, now with more waku-doki.
metaDescription: 2015 Toyota Camry: The high-stakes top-selling sedan is updated, now with more waku-doki. See details on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: Toyota’s top seller has just gotten a remake, part of an overhaul of the automaker’s lineup that has seen the introduction of six new products in the past eighteen months.

Toyota Group vice-president Bill Fay headed off this morning’s introduction at the New York Auto Show with the statement, “Toyota is going places.” With the introduction of the 2015 Camry, the automaker is working to keep the title of America’s favorite car.

Since 1983, more than 10.2 million Camrys have found U.S. buyers, and there are a staggering 6.6 million on the roads today. All North American market Camrys are built in the United States with 75 percent North American content.

What's new for 2015?

This newest Camry is sleeker, with a more refined design than its forebears. It gains 1.8 inches in overall length. Visually, its new headlamps and more aggressive front fascia are notable. Mechanically, there’s updated braking, more torsional rigidity, and a retuned suspension.

The revised interior is the standout, with soft-touch materials, French stitching, satin and metallic black chrome, a simpler, more intuitive center stack, and better wireless connectivity. Inside an enclosed bin in front of the shifter, a wireless charging system is now available—first in the segment, says Toyota. The 2015 Camry will be available in ten colors, including the new Ruby Flare Pearl and Celestial Silver Metallic shades that are shown on this page.

Toyota has a watchword: "waku-doki. " That’s the code word for excitement, and, no, it’s not altogether out of place when talking about the Camry. The success of the sportier Camry SE model, which is the choice of 45 percent of Camry buyers, inspired Toyota to add an XSE (shown here) with eighteen-inch wheels, a sportier suspension, and the same mesh grille and fascia treatment as the SE model. Toyota’s proud that the median age of SE owners is twelve years younger than the segment’s average of forty-five; the XSE plans to skew even younger.
For 2015, a Hybrid SE is added for what Toyota insists on calling “an eco-fun driving experience,” but despite the hyperbole, we’ll bet it will be.
The 2015 Camry will go on sale in the fall.

images.caption: A peek at the interior of the 2015 Camry on the New York Auto Show floor.
Interior of the 2015 Toyota Camry shows soft-touch materials.

title: Fanfic: Mini Special Edition
promoTeaserSmall: Hundreds of fans tried, but one college student's custom Mini Cooper S won, and now you can buy it.
promoTeaser: Hundreds of fans tried, but one college student's custom Mini Cooper S won, and now you can buy it.
metaDescription: Fanfic: Mini Special Edition. Hundreds of fans tried, but one college student's custom Mini Cooper S won, and now you can buy it. See it on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio: Holly has reported on cars, lifestyle, travel, and everything else for publications including the New York Daily News, Redbook, Elite Traveler, and Fox TV. She lives in New York City with her family, including Jack, a toy poodle (and test driving partner!).

pageElements.text: Mini USA is known for its emphasis on style and customization, bragging there are "over 10 million ways to configure" a Mini Cooper. The BMW subsidiary has taken that to a new level with a contest that let fans design their own look for a Mini Cooper, and the winner is a Mini you can actually buy.

It was all in service of the new 2014 Mini Cooper's launch at the New York Auto Show earlier this month. From more than 800 submissions, nine winners and a “fan favorite” were selected by online voting to have their test drives captured on video. Each of the top ten vote getters had the opportunity to sit with an illustrator and create their own design and options packages. (See the test drive video here.)

image.altText: Mini Cooper DeLux at New York Auto Show

pageElements.text: When it came to the final draw, the Mini community voted Alex Coyle’s “DeLux” as their favorite. Coyle, a nineteen-year-old sophomore studying creative advertising and photography at Virginia Commonwealth University, created her “Mini Originals” package inspired by black lights. The result is a stunning black Mini with blue exterior graphics.

“‘Lux’ is the root meaning of ‘light,’ ” explains Coyle. "After I went through all the options I had available to customize the car, I went for all the bells and whistles and created what I call  ‘DeLux.' "

The DeLux package adds $8,900 to the $24,395 base price (including destination charge) of the 2014 Mini Cooper S, for a total price of $33,295. It includes the graphics kit on a Midnight Black exterior, plus eighteen-inch silver wheels, chrome exterior trim, LED foglamps and auto headlights, a spoiler, a six-speed manual Getrag transmisison, and a carbon black leatherette interior.
Want one? There will be fifty-six “DeLux” edition Mini Coopers available for order on MINIUSA.com and through MINI dealerships across the country between now and the end of the year.
The still photo gives a good idea, but for real artistry, check out this video.

title: 2015 Subaru WRX STI Launch Edition
subTitle: A car to put on your bucket list, even if you're budget minded.
promoTeaserSmall: A car to put on your bucket list, even if you're budget minded.
promoTeaser: A car to put on your bucket list, even if you're budget minded.
metaTitle: 2015 Subaru WRX STI Launch Edition - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 2015 Subaru WRX STI Launch Edition: For the bucket list of the budget minded. See my short, sweet video review on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
Vital Stats

Base price: $27,090 (includes destination)
This car's price: $38,190 (includes destination)
EPA fuel economy: 17 mpg city/23 mpg highway
Engine: Turbocharged 2.5-liter horizontally opposed four-cylinder, 305 horsepower, 290 pound-feet of torque
Transmission: Six-speed manual
Safety features: New driver’s knee airbag brings total number of airbags to seven; 2014 and 2015 models not yet tested by National Highway Traffic Safety Administration or Insurance Institute for Highway Safety
Tech features: Symmetrical all-wheel drive, multi-mode dynamics control, Intelligent Drive powertrain management system with Intelligent, Sport, and Sport Sharp modes, Brembo performance brakes
Chief competitors: Audi S4, Ford Focus ST, Mitsubishi Lancer Evo GSR
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/UryqHUfPG6E?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Subaru boxer engine graphics in video courtesy of Designory.com.

Key Points

• The WRX STI is Subaru’s performance flagship model–aimed at boy (and girl) racers.

•  The redesigned 2015 Subaru WRX  drops the Impreza name and, at the base level, reflects no price increase over the 2014 model. The car we're testing here is a midlevel WRX STI Launch Edition, which has no options and slots in under the psychologically important $40,000 mark.

•  The 2015 Subaru WRX STI Limited is the top-of-the-line model. It starts at $39,290, including  destination, a $650 price increase over the 2014 model. 
 
•   Subaru will build just 1,000 units of the Launch Edition model for 2015.
•  The special model comes in traditional WR (World Rally) Blue Pearl exterior paint with gold-painted eighteen-inch BBS alloy wheels, a color combination associated with Subaru competition cars.

•  The Subaru WRX STI is surprisingly loaded with features, including a leather-wrapped steering wheel, performance front seats, and a six-speaker audio system. The Launch Edition adds keyless access. Option packages (not on the car we tested) include a $2,000 navigation and audio system with nine speakers.

•  Subaru is expanding the reach of the WRX STI. At the 2014 New York International Auto Show, it rolled out this 2015 WRX STI sedan in Rallycross Supercar trim, a special livery done in partnership with the RedBull Global Rallycross Championship.

•  At the same time, Mitsubishi is getting ready to pull the plug on the Lancer Evolution, the brand’s all-wheel-drive performance sedan (pictured). The Japanese automaker hasn’t confirmed when it will stop building the Lancer Evo, but it won’t introduce a successor to the current generation. This eliminates Mitsu’s last sporty offering in the U.S. market as it shifts its lineup toward utility vehicles and EVs.

images.caption: 2014 Subaru WRX STI Launch Edition has a prominent spoiler.
2014 Subaru WRX STI Launch Edition. That color: World Rally Blue Pearl.
I was no fan of the gold-colored wheels on the 2014 Subaru WRX STI Launch Edition.

pageElements.text:
Vital Stats

Base price: $20,745 (includes destination)
This car’s price: $38,190 (includes destination)
EPA fuel economy: 25 city/38 highway
Engine: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 189 horsepower Transmission: Six-speed Getrag manual
Safety features: Eight airbags, including side curtain and front knee airbags, stability control, corner brake control; not yet tested by National Highway Traffic Safety Administration or Insurance Institute for Highway Safety
Tech features: Bluetooth and USB/iPod interface, HD radio, interior LED “mood lighting”
Chief competitors: Fiat 500 (base price $16,995), Hyundai Veloster (base price $18,610), Volkswagen Golf (base price $20,815); all prices include destination charges
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/KpZc-tZJF3c?list=UUKWoLlV8-sE8zQnoWHI9qoA" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Key Points

• The Mini Cooper S shown here is well equipped, but not fully loaded; it includes eight options totaling $3,200. The most expensive is a $1,000 panoramic moonroof. The least expensive option is white turn signal lights, which are priced at $100.
• Its fuel economy falls just short of the magic 40-mpg highway number that is the Holy Grail for automakers. In comparison, the 2014 Fiat 500 with a 1.4-liter four-cylinder engine and five-speed manual transmission gets 40 mpg on highway. The 2014 Volkwagen Golf with a 2.0-liter four-cylinder diesel engine and six-speed manual or automatic transmission gets 42 mpg on the highway.
• The car we tested does not have this feature, but 2014 Mini Coopers equipped with the optional six-speed automatic transmission (available on all variants) feature the Cooper’s first stop-start function to save fuel.
Mini is going for a more conventional look and feel with less of a retro-chic cabin than in the past, and is moving upscale with such items as optional LED headlights.

• Mini Driving Modes (Sport, Mid, and Green) are standard, operated using a rotary switch at the base of the gearlever. This is designed to make the car more fuel efficient, depending on what the driver dials in. In Green mode, the energy is cut to the air conditioning and exterior mirror heating.
• Mini offers lots of new optional safety features: a head-up display above the steering column, a Driving Assistant system with camera-based active cruise control, collision and pedestrian warning, speed limit information, and a rearview camera. (None are on the car we tested.)
• The range of “Original Mini Accessories” has been completely redesigned for the new model year. This is a way for buyers to put their personal stamp on the car.
• All the classics are still there, including the much-loved roof graphics. But what’s new is a design concept for the exterior and interior made up of four Mini Design Lines. This coordinates the look inside and out. (Again, not on the car we tested.) They are called Vivid Green, Speedwell Blue (the most British, with a reinterpretation of the red, white and blue of the Union Jack), John Cooper Works Pro (checkered flag in black, red, and gray), and Essential Black (with checkered pattern on diagonal).
• You now have a choice of nine roof graphics; for cars with the optional panoramic roof, there are six.
• Mini claims you can come up with “10 million” different looks for the car.

• This is the third-generation Mini.
 • Parent BMW says the emphasis is on a new “more mature character.” Is it still Mini enough?
• The new version has grown by almost five inches in length, and the trunk can now hold more luggage. However, it is still 8.5 inches shorter than a Ford Fiesta hatchback.
• Mini is continuing to adopt a more conventional look and feel with less of a retro-chic cabin than in the past, and is moving upscale with such items as optional LED headlights.
• Mini debuted in 1959 and is considered an icon of the 1960s.
• For the first time, both three-cylinder and four-cylinder engines are available, all turbocharged.
• The car we tested is a four-cylinder; with that engine, the Mini Cooper accelerates from 0 to 60 mph in 6.5 seconds. Peppy.

title: The Weekly Windup!
promoTeaserSmall: Start this Mother's Day weekend with our collection of fascinating trivia from around the web.
promoTeaser: Start this Mother's Day weekend with our collection of fascinating trivia from around the web.
metaDescription: The Weekly Windup: Start this Mother's Day weekend with our collection of fascinating trivia from around the web. See it on JeanKnowsCars.com

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text: 1. Take a trip back in time and watch My Mother the Car to kick off your weekend.
2. You could win a Ford Mustang by taking a selfie using your freshly waxed car as the mirror. https://www.turtlewax.com/reflectie
3. You may be offended by the gratuitous babe, but the thirty-three exotic and classic cars are worth it.
4. Note to self: Make sure you're not in gear when you want to rev the engine.
5. Does this ad make you want to try it at home?
6. This website is so cool that I actually want a motorcycle. I would also be happy with any of their apparel.
7. You're traveling to another dimension, a dimension not only of sight and sound, but also of mind; a journey into a wondrous land where all the vehicles in the U.S. are electric.
8. What it's like to live in your car on the streets of New York City.
9. DIY gift idea for Mom?

pageElements.text: Alfonso Albaisa is a romantic, a dreamer, a visionary, whose twenty-five-year tenure at Nissan included several senior design positions. He became design director of Nissan Design America in 2004, then vice-president of Nissan Design Europe in 2007, returning to the U.S. in 2011 as vice-president of NDA. Before recently moving to the brand’s luxury marque, Infiniti, as executive design director, Albaisa had risen to design director for Nissan’s Global Passenger Vehicles and Electric Vehicles.

If you hadn’t noticed, Nissan Design is hanging it all out. Albaisa’s vision follows in harmony with that of his boss, Shiro Nakamura, who has been an extraordinary iconoclast his entire career. Between them, their portfolio of striking and strikingly unusual vehicles—from Murano to Cube to Juke to Murano Cross Cabriolet—has put Nissan on the map after a near-fatal spell arrested in mid-plunge by Renault.

The latest concepts for Infiniti, however, have been anything but unusual. Sensational and sensual, the new Q-ship concepts are pointing the way toward an unprecedented explosion of new products aimed at the top of the Infiniti range.

In this video, shot at the Los Angeles Auto Show, Albaisa gives me the inside tour of the Q80 Inspiration Concept, which was first revealed in September at the Paris Motor Show. Our only question: Will it make it into production?
<iframe width="853" height="480" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/hL6ndrW2Opg" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Ralph Gilles made his name early, when he completed the production design of the award-winning 2005 Chrysler 300 from a concept by the renowned designer Freeman Thomas. He quickly rose to head Chrysler design, running Dodge for a while and adding SRT to his duties.

He is a performance nut, spending as much time as possible at racetracks with Mopar enthusiasts.
If you're not one of Ralph's 22,000 Twitter followers, you're missing out on the action. But you can get a sample of his straight talk in this walkaround of the 2015 300S.

pageElements.text: Did you miss me?
Because I’ve certainly missed you!

Now that the dust has cleared on the relocation of Jean Knows Cars (from the owners of Automobile Magazine to my newly established LLC, and from Ann Arbor to Chelsea, Michigan), I would like to welcome you to life in bucolic Chelsea. It is the home town of the wonderfully versatile Jeff Daniels (Arachnophobia, Fly Away Home, Dumb and Dumber 1 and 2, The Network) and his Purple Rose Theatre, and home of the Chrysler Proving Grounds where I worked for three amusing years. Classic shot-and-shell joint Seitz’s Tavern is just around the corner. The gleaming white grain silos of Jiffy Mix are hard by the railroad tracks, towering over the cozy Jean Knows Cars office.
Please don’t drop in.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/lSyBOIQdJzM" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

We have returned (not tanned, hardly rested, but certainly ready), we being Jean, executive editor Laura Sky Brown, and creative director Molly Jean. Having plotted our comeback all summer, we launched ourselves into the breach—covering the Los Angeles Auto Show in November, filming video reviews until Jean’s Driveway was buried in snow, and marching right on through the Detroit Auto Show in January—working from kitchen tables. We secured the office, desks, and computers just in time to hit the Chicago Auto Show, where we also took a day to bond with our new partner, Tribune Publishing, which will be syndicating our work across its vast network of print and digital properties.

Basically, we’re working our asses off in between multiple trips to Ikea and sweet-talking AT&T for a free microcell to turn 318 North Main Street from a cell-free zone to a full five bars on the iPhones. That, and having a great time plotting Internet domination. Be part of our march to the sea! Find us, follow us, Like us, LOVE us here on JeanKnowsCars.com and at Facebook.com/JeanKnowsCars, Twitter.com/JeanKnowsCars, and Instagram.com/JeanKnowsCars.

pageElements.text:
Vital Stats

Type: Five passenger, front- and all-wheel-drive compact crossover
Base price: $24,200 (including destination) for CR-V LX 2WD
This car: $33,650 (including destination)
Engine: 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 185 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic with Sport mode
Safety ratings:4 of 5 stars for rollover, no front and side crash results yet available from National Highway Traffic Safety Administration
Insurance Institute for Highway Safety gives the 2015 CR-V its Top Safety Pick + designation, with top Good ratings in all areas
Standard safety features: Six airbags, multi-angle rearview camera, stability assist with traction control, brake assist
Tech features: Seven-inch touchscreen, navigation
Options on this model: None
Fuel economy: 26 mpg city/33 mpg highway (27/34 mpg for base front-wheel-drive LX)
Chief competitors: 2015 Ford Escape (base price $23,855), 2015 Hyundai Santa Fe Sport (base price $25, 825), 2015 Toyota RAV4 (base price $24,565); all prices include destination charges
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/MMZSDSUq07o" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Key Points

• The CR-V Touring, the new top trim level for the popular SUV, features Honda's first use of two driver-assist safety technologies: collision mitigation braking (automatically brakes to help you avoid or minimize a frontal crash) and lane-keeping assist. They are standard on this model, along with adaptive cruise control, forward collision warning, and lane departure warning
• The 2015 CR-V has been redesigned at mid-cycle with a more expressive grille and a lower stance that Honda says is "sportier"
• This redesign is a crucial part of Honda’s push to keep its lead in this super-competitive crossover segment
• A new powertrain: the combination of a 2.4-liter four-cylinder direct-injection engine and a continuously variable transmission, replacing the previous five-speed automatic
• Among the new features are a center console armrest, rear ventilation ducts, and an optional power tailgate
• Compact SUVs/crossovers are the fastest-growing segment in the U.S., with twice as much market share as ten years ago
• The CR-V has claimed the No. 1 spot in seven of the past ten years
• The CR-V is Honda’s second-best-selling vehicle behind the Accord (the two account for more than half of Honda’s U.S. sales)
• It's hugely popular with women because it offers a reasonable price, good cargo space, good fuel efficiency, and a commanding view of the road
• The roll call in this segment is constantly growing: consumers can also consider the Buick Encore, Ford Edge, Ford Flex, GMC Terrain, Jeep Cherokee, Kia Sportage, Mazda CX-5, Nissan Juke, Nissan Murano, Nissan Rogue, Subaru Forester, Toyota Highlander, Toyota Venza—and more
• 2015 CR-V improvements include improved torque (up 11 percent to 181 pound-feet)
• Overall fuel economy has improved 4 percent

pageElements.text: I am not driving through another dreadful Michigan winter in this big old 2007 Chevrolet Suburban without a set of winter tires.

It has four-wheel drive, which I thought was good enough. But then there was that night I was convinced we could go to town for a party, despite the raging snowstorm outside. We didn’t make it a mile before two cars in front of us slid off the two-lane and pirouetted into the ditches on either side of the road. We nearly executed a four-wheel-drive version of the same maneuver trying to stop.
Enough.

This year, I proposed a Real World Test of Bridgestone Blizzaks, as experienced by my aircraft-carrier-sized, zillion-pound four-wheel-drive Suburban. Bridgestone isn’t the only maker of winter tires. You can find them as well as many other choices at Tire Rack, America’s go-to online tire and wheel warehouse. Tire Rack is a non-denominational supplier of all good tire brands, and the company conducts its own independent tests, even going above the Arctic Circle to test winter tires. (Check their great videos at TireRack.com.)

Step One was entering make, model, and year of our vehicle in the middle of Tire Rack’s home page. Then we clicked on the Winter tab, which brought us to the Bridgestone Blizzaks Preferred Winter/Snow Tire & Wheel Package, priced at just over $1,000.

Tire Rack volunteered the tires and sent them mounted on a new set of rims (you can save money by using basic wheels—“steelies”). They were already balanced and fitted with a Tire Pressure Monitoring System (TPMS). A special jack and thin-wall socket for the deep-set lug nuts was included. I thought Tire Rack did all that as a special media favor. But the same courtesy is afforded any customer who orders the Preferred Winter/Snow Tire & Wheel Package.

My local garage, K&J Tire and Auto Repair in Jackson, Michigan, checked the tire pressures and mounted them on the Suburban, something I could have done in my garage. But I’d have gotten dirty. They tried to charge nothing. I bought them pizza.

I will come back over the course of the winter and report on our experience with the Blizzaks. I want to know how accurate (or annoying) the TPMS proves to be.

What about fuel economy, you ask? Don’t know. We will measure. Will the Suburban ride more roughly? Will the Blizzaks be louder? How will they wear?
All questions for the winter ahead. Send your own questions (and advice), and we will respond to all based on our Real World Testing.

Love,
Jean
<iframe width="853" height="480" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/7bdafSaz6q0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

title: 5 Must-Have Gadgets for the Driver
subTitle: You didn't know you needed them. As seen at the the Consumer Electronics Show.
promoTeaserSmall: You didn't know you needed them. As seen at the the Consumer Electronics Show.
promoTeaser: You didn't know you needed them. As seen at the the Consumer Electronics Show.
metaDescription: You didn't know you needed them. As seen at the the Consumer Electronics Show.

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. I currently write the Family Tech column in Family Circle magazine and Family Tech with Christina at FamilyCircle.com, and I blog on the Geek Girlfriends site. Clients--past and present--include Better Homes and Gardens, Popular Science, This Old House Magazine, USA Weekend, PC Magazine, PC World, Jaguar, Saks Fifth Avenue, and many others. I am thrilled to be a part of Jean Knows Cars.

pageElements.text:
1. MyQ Wi-Fi Garage Door Opener

$129.99
Did you just leave the garage door open–with the bikes, kayaks, and dive gear in it–when you left on your commute to work? D'oh! But there is no need to drive home to check. With MyQ, just look at your phone, tap to close the garage door, and carry on. It’s easy to install. Plug the connector dongle into your existing garage door opener to connect it to your Wi-Fi network. Download the app to control the garage door from your phone.

2. KeyFree

Pricing and availability not yet announced
Lose your keys. Go ahead. Don’t worry about it. Just don’t lose your phone. Because once you install the little Bluetooth dongle in your car and download the KeyFree app, your smartphone is your car key. You can open the car automatically as you walk toward it, remote start the car while you sip coffee in the warmth of your house, get car diagnostics delivered to your phone, and even send a key to someone else so they can drive your car if you aren’t around.

3. Satechi BT Home Button

$24.99
Admit it! You can't resist looking at your phone to ask Siri or Google Now a question when the driving gets boring. The asking is a sign of an active mind. The looking at your phone is dangerous. Attach the Satechi BT Home Button to your dash, tell it what you want it to pull up on your phone, and just press a button next time to hail answers from the oracle. Eyes on the road! The BT stands for Bluetooth, and the gadget will become available later this month.

4. Life360

Free
How many times a day do you ask your spouse or kids where they are? There is an easier way. Install the Life360 app on your Apple, Android, or Windows smartphone, and you can just look to see if he left work, if she made it to school, and how far away she is if you want to start dinner. You can message each other within the app, too. And it’s all fun. (And you can easily go incognito if you’d rather keep your current location–ahem–mum.) Ford recently partnered with Life360 so that if you get into your Ford with Sync, it will automatically tell everyone in your circle you are driving and not responding to texts. It will also automatically let them know when you arrive and are available again. That’s a good message to send to teen drivers.

5. RemoteLink

Free with OnStar
Do you drive a car with OnStar? Lucky you. Download the RemoteLink app right now! (If you haven’t already.) You can turn on the heat before you get to the car, lock the doors without going back outside to check, see if the car needs gas before you get out of bed to drive, or unlock the car for your teenager when she locks the keys inside not for the first time. Free (and so necessary) if you already have OnStar!

title: Wi-Fi in Cars: The View from CES
subTitle: Find out which cars hook you up, and which go a step further and hook up everyone riding with you.
promoTitle: Wi-Fi in Cars: The View from CES
promoTeaserSmall: Find out which cars hook you up, and which go a step further and hook up everyone riding with you.
promoTeaser: Find out which cars hook you up, and which go a step further and hook up everyone riding with you.
keywords: Wi-Fi in Cars: The View from CES
metaTitle: Wi-Fi in Cars: The View from CES
metaDescription: Find out which cars hook you up, and which go a step further and hook up everyone riding with you.

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. I currently write the Family Tech column in Family Circle magazine and Family Tech with Christina at FamilyCircle.com, and I blog on the Geek Girlfriends site. Clients--past and present--include Better Homes and Gardens, Popular Science, This Old House Magazine, USA Weekend, PC Magazine, PC World, Jaguar, Saks Fifth Avenue, and many others. I am thrilled to be a part of Jean Knows Cars.

pageElements.text: The Consumer Electronics Show this year was all about the future: Cars that drive themselves, 3D printers, drones, and slick wearables. But that thing that seems ever so possible and that you want every day (Right now! Today!)? (That, for this geek anyway, being a Wi-Fi connection in my car.) That was not everywhere you look.

Not unless you are looking at cars with OnStar, that is. In that case, it’s wherever you look. By the end of 2015, 4G LTE will be standard in pretty much all General Motors cars. Even the $12,000-range Chevrolet Spark comes standard with a six-month OnStar plan.

Lots of cars have connectivity. (Well, mostly high-end cars. But lots of those.) A connected car is awesome! It can access a server for updates to its telematics or core car functions. Or the car itself has an Internet connection so it can access online maps or surf the Internet from the in-dash telematics system. Or that in-dash telematics system connects to your phone, and uses its connection to the Internet, so you can use the apps you love right from the car’s dash. In one way or another, this is what BMW’s ConnectedDrive, the Audi A3 (which has Google in the dash!) with Audi Connect, and Ford Sync do.
The car connects. But the car doesn’t connect you.

A subtle distinction? Not when you are sitting in the passenger's seat trying to file a story to your editor while flying down the freeway at 80 mph and that story is on a laptop that needs Wi-Fi. Not when the teenager in the back seat sighs melodramatically for the thousandth time and asks “Are we there yet?” to remind you that his tablet is just a dead weight with no Internet connection. Not when you have to answer e-mail on your phone for an eight-hour drive even though your laptop is sitting right there.

I love a car with connectivity. I think it’s an important feature to shop for. But I’d really love it if the car would share that connection with everyone in the car so we can use all of our devices when we are on the road, just like when we are at home.
Aftermarket, you can get that kind of connectivity through some aftermarket additions such as the Delphi Connect ($200 plus plan).
But drones and 3D printers are cool, too.

pageElements.text: I can't tell you how much I look forward to going to the Detroit auto show. If you saw any of the coverage of the Consumer Electronics Show, you know just how wild the North American International Auto Show at Detroit's Cobo Center is going to be.

The show has already begun for automotive journalists, who've been treated to advanced previews of some of the vehicles that will be hitting the show floor in two days. Some of us have already seen the brand-new Cadillac CTS-V, the next Nissan Titan pickup truck, the second-generation Chevrolet Volt, and many more.
An auto show without a knockout surprise is a sad auto show indeed.

More exciting are the vehicles we don't know about, the surprises. There are hot rumors, for instance, that the long-awaited next-gen Ford GT will be revealed, and those are probably true. (oh, please be true!), but there will hopefully be a few projects that have been kept so tightly under wraps that we'll be completely blown away. That's what I'm looking for. That's what auto show is all about. An auto show without a knockout surprise is a sad auto show indeed.

In the meantime, I'll be traveling around the show floor with a videographer, stopping at ten or so manufacturers to meet with their chief designers and have them show us the their stars of the show. We'll roll those videos out over the course of the next two weeks.

As always, we're very interested in your comments.
See you Monday morning!

title: 2016 Lexus GS F
subTitle: With 467 horsepower, the newest Lexus F aims at high-performance sedan market.
promoTeaserSmall: With 467 horsepower, the newest Lexus F aims at high-performance sedan market.
promoTeaser: With 467 horsepower, the newest Lexus F aims at high-performance sedan market.
metaDescription: With 467 horsepower, the newest Lexus F aims at high-performance sedan market.

pageElements.text: It’s no secret that luxury performance sedans are earning an increasing share of the vehicle market, so it should come as no surprise that Lexus wants to increase its share of that increase.

If that does surprise you, the GS F provides yet another verification of the corporate strategy. This rear-wheel-drive high-performance sedan was presented to media at Detroit's North American International Auto Show this week. It is the latest addition to the Lexus F lineup, a relatively new sub-brand devoted to higher performance.
The mid-size GS sedan already has an F variant, the GS 350 F Sport, but this newly introduced GS F promises to provide a much more compelling (and fast) experience.

The key distinction between the two can be found beneath their hoods. The 350 F Sport's 3.5-liter V-6 generates 306 horsepower. Allied with the new eight-speed automatic that became available in 2014, a rear-wheel-drive GS 350 F Sport (also available with all-wheel drive) can be reasonably expected to reach 60 mph in a little over 5.5 seconds.
That’s respectable, but not enough to challenge in the realm Lexus wants to invade, a milieu populated by rides like the BMW M5, Cadillac CTS-V, Jaguar XFR, and Mercedes-Benz E63 AMG.

To that end, the GS F brings a much bigger punch to the free-for-all: a 5.0-liter V-8 rated for 467 horsepower, channeling thrust to the rear wheels via the new eight-speed automatic.The V-8 is the same engine that powers the Lexus RC F coupe, a certifiable thrill ride.
Although most of the benchmark competitors bring more power to the game, Lexus claims the GS F will be about 300 pounds lighter, give or take, than its rivals.

Other upgrades include structural stiffening and firmer suspension tuning. Also, the Lexus Torque Vectoring Differential (TVD) is standard equipment, enhancing transient response and reducing the angst of arriving a little too hot at a decreasing radius corner. Plus, it has unique orange brake calipers.
How will it hold up against its powerful competitors? We'll find out after the 2016 Lexus GS F goes on sale in the fall.

title: Buick Avenir and Cascada
subTitle: Striking flagship sedan concept, along with 2016 Cascada convertible, greeted the media in Detroit.
promoTeaserSmall: Striking flagship sedan concept and 2016 Cascada convertible greeted the media in Detroit.
promoTeaser: Striking flagship sedan concept and 2016 Cascada convertible greeted the media in Detroit.
metaDescription: Striking flagship sedan concept and 2016 Cascada convertible greeted the media in Detroit.

pageElements.text: Buick has just rolled out a pleasant surprise for anyone who may have found the General Motors brand a little boring in recent decades. The Buick Avenir concept is a very attractive flagship sedan that was greeted with approving interest when it drove onto the stage to face the media at the Eastern Market in Detroit on Sunday night.

Buick Avenir Concept

The Avenir is a rear-wheel-drive, four-seat sedan with a next-generation V-6 engine and a nine-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters. The sedan’s exterior was designed in Australia, while the interior is a U.S. design. The cool cat-eye center infotainment screen is a desirable touch, while the two passengers in the deep rear bucket seats get USB ports and video screens of their own.

A full set of LED lighting, 20-inch wheels, and driver-selectable suspension damping are among the highlights. The grille brings back Buick’s three-color look from the past, and there’s a smooth-looking variation on the traditional Buick portholes.

The concept’s name is French for “future,” although the automaker gave no hint on when or how it will produce the Avenir.  But the desire to do so is plainly there: Mark Reuss, executive vice-president for global product development, called it “pure essence of Buick,” and design chief Ed Welburn mentioned the Avenir in the same breath as the Y-Job, the classic Buick concept from 1938.

People born in 1938 or earlier could love this car, as you’d expect from any Buick, but if the next production flagship from Buick looks anywhere near this sleek, its appeal will cross a lot of age boundaries.

2016 Buick Cascada

In the realm of cars you’re likely to see on the road soon, Buick showed off its 2016 Cascada, a convertible that will go on sale next year. This will be the first Buick convertible in a quarter-century – the last was the Reatta – and it should appeal to people who like cars like the Volkswagen Eos or Beetle convertibles or the Audi A3 Cabriolet. It has a soft convertible top that goes up or down at the push of a button in seventeen seconds, at speeds up to 31 mph.

The Cascada is a front-wheel-drive car, powered by a turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine that makes 200 horsepower. It comes only with a six-speed automatic transmission. Heated seats and steering wheel are among the amenities. It also has the HiPer Strut front suspension that is already on the LaCrosse and Regal, and GM president Dan Ammann pointed out that Buick buyers want “special attention to acoustics and refined ride.” Pricing hasn’t been announced yet, but somewhere in the mid-$30,000s is likely.
If Buick is looking for a younger, more style-conscious buyer, which we know the GM division is, these two new designs should go a long way toward getting those people to look at the product lineup.

images.caption: The Buick concept that started them all, the 1938 Y-Job.
This is not what the weather looks like in Detroit now, but the Buick Cascada was made for climes like this.
Buick Cascada's folding rear seat is highly picnic-able.
2016 Buick Cascada convertible, top up and down, at Eastern Market in Detroit on Jan. 11.
2016 Buick Cascada convertible takes the stage in Detroit on Jan. 11, 2015.
Media get first look at the 2016 Buick Cascada in Detroit on Jan. 11, 2015.
Buick Avenir concept's rear-seat passengers get their own screens.
Buick Avenir concept, showing the traditional Buick logo.
Porthole variant pays homage to Buick's styling history.
LED lights all around on the Buick Avenir concept.
Buick Avenir concept in Detroit, Jan. 11, 2015.
Cockpit of the Buick Avenir concept.
Buick Avenir concept in Detroit, Jan. 11, 2015.

title: 2017 Ford GT
subTitle: It will take Ford back to Le Mans, but first, let's just look at it a little longer.
promoTeaserSmall: It will take Ford back to Le Mans, but first, let's just look at it a little longer.
promoTeaser: It will take Ford back to Le Mans, but first, let's just look at it a little longer.
metaDescription: It will take Ford back to Le Mans, but first, let's just look at it a little longer.

pageElements.text: The 2015 North American International Auto Show was chock-a-block with heart-pounding  new rides—the long-awaited Acura NSX supercar, the 200-mph Cadillac CTS-V sedan—but this one should have rolled out with auxiliary defibrillators.
Pulses raced, respiration was halting, and eyeballs bulged as the GT rotated in Ford's display area at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit.
It was no surprise when the Eyes on Design judges, a panel composed of top automotive designers, anointed the Ford GT as the show’s best production vehicle.

At a glance, this might have seemed a little specious, since Ford billed the GT as a concept. But Ford fully intends to build this blue bullet, in order to qualify for a return to the Le Mans 24-hour race, the crucible that produced the immortal GT40 and four straight Le Mans victories in 1966, ’67, ’68, and ’69.

To enter the race, Ford must build at least 100 production examples. There will certainly be more than that—hard to make a business case for 100 cars, unless the plan is to price them at about $1 million each. As an index, production of the previous GT, conducted between 2004 and 2006, came to about 4,150 cars.
But we digress. Here’s what we know.

The GT is mostly carbon fiber, passenger compartment and body panels, with aluminum subframes to accommodate suspension elements, which are also aluminum. Racing touches include in-board shock absorbers, activated by pushrods, and carbon-ceramic brakes.

Ride height is adjustable, as is the active rear spoiler, which can be varied for both height and pitch. The doors are scissors style, as in a Lamborghini, rather than the gull wings of the earlier GT. The swoopy shape shows wind tunnel sculpting, although Ford refrained from furnishing any values, such as coefficient of drag.

Nor was there any reference to curb weight. However, we do know that the minimum weight for the GT’s Le Mans class—where it will be opposed by cars like the Ferrari 458, Chevrolet Corvette, Porsche 911, and Audi R8—is 2,745 pounds.
The engine will be an updated, twin-turbo version of an EcoBoost V6 (EcoBoost is how you say turbocharged at Ford) generating “over 600 horsepower” according to Ford engineers.

The racing plan targets the 2017 edition of the 24 Hours of Le Mans. Production is due to begin in late 2016. But you can probably open a dialogue with a selected Ford dealer sooner than that. Tomorrow might be good.

title: 2017 Ford Raptor: Walkaround
subTitle: Outrageously Ford from fender to fender, as shown to me by exterior design director Craig Metros.
promoTeaserSmall: Outrageously Ford from fender to fender, as shown to me by exterior design director Craig Metros.
promoTeaser: Outrageously Ford from fender to fender, as shown to me by exterior design director Craig Metros.
metaDescription: Outrageously Ford from fender to fender, as shown to me by exterior design director Craig Metros. See the video of the 2017 Ford Raptor on JeanKnowsCars.com.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Craig Metros, Ford's exterior design director of The Americas, is a native of Dearborn, Michigan, graduated from the College for Creative Studies in Detroit, and has been all around the world with Ford. Now he's back to bring us the 2017 Raptor version of the F-150 pickup.

The Raptor used to be a spidery little truck that you could imagine bouncing around in the desert. Wait a minute. It DID bounce around the desert, down on our southern border of Mexico in the hands of immigration agents.
This new Raptor still looks like an extreme race truck, but now its front end looks like it was chiseled out of an ingot of steel, fender to fender Ford.
No, you don't have to guess who made the truck following you. And God forbid you you be hit with it, because the back of your car would be embossed forever with "Ford," written backward.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/NxhxhaoqLu4" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

pageElements.text: Lincoln caused a stir in the industry when it stole hot young designer Max Wolff away from Cadillac in 2010 to be its first chief designer. But it didn’t pan out.
Lo and behold, Lincoln found a talented replacement right at home.

Actually, David Woodhouse—who was slotted in over Wolff in December 2013—is a Brit, but he’s been working his way through all sorts of Ford design jobs for the past fifteen years. He’s family.
 
The sleek MKX that Woodhouse showed us in Detroit has produced the first real buzz Lincoln has enjoyed as it struggles back to its feet. All the rest of the buzz up to this point has been about when it was going under.
It’s funny to me that the signs of life at Lincoln are emanating from an SUV rather than a car. Then again, the MKX has the width to finally give those tortured Lincoln wings some space to fly.
In this walkaround, Woodhouse shows us a few more design details that give the new MKX its distinctive flair.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/2NhFLX2dgA0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

pageElements.text: When Brian Smith's team approached the task of redesigning the Cadillac CTS-V for 2016, they had to wrap the performance upgrades that came from engineering in a dramatic new body "without making it look like a science experiment."
No Frankenstein here, folks. The Cadillac exterior lead design manager walks us around the flagship CTS-V and explains how it all came together.
I got a little sidetracked by the optional book-matched carbon fiber track package....

pageElements.text: Do you remember that dog food ad with the tagline, “Dogs Love Trucks"? Well, Jean loves trucks. No such thing as a bad truck unless it’s a truck that can’t do its job. This hasn’t been a problem at Ram, and from the looks of the Rebel, the brand is in good hands.

Those hands belong to its chief designer, Ralph Gilles. It’s always a house party when we’re with chief partier, I mean designer, Ralph Gillies.  He loves what he does, from Chrysler 200s to Vipers to award-winning pickups.

They even got their own Ram brand, which is looking mighty fine in its new Rebel suit of armor, don’t you think? Instead of the baby Mack truck look, this Ram now looks like a badass bulldog.
 
I always talk like this when I’m with Ralph.  Just listen to him!
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/NRAeJQYNY6s" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
