pageElements.text: All you need to know about the Infiniti Q60 Concept is that I think it’s absolutely exquisite, and I'm not the only one. It's a tour de force with its elegant, understated, but decisive deign.

Okay, maybe that’s not all you need to know. For instance, the Q60 Concept is very much the car that will come into production in 2016 minus a few show car flourishes. But it was clear that the body panels were stampings and insiders nodded in the affirmative when I quizzed them about the beautiful, quilted leather interior and luxurious console and dash.

It will go head to head with luxury sport coupes such as the Mercedes-Benz C-Class, BMW 4 Series, and Audi A5, and will undoubtedly start around $40,000 and go up from there.

Sadly, Infiniti executive design director Alfonso Albaisa’s voice had all but given up the ghost five minutes before I showed up to do the walkaround with him at the show. We waited a few hours to see if the hot tea helped, but by then his voice was totally gone. (See the walkaround here of the Infiniti Q80 Inspiration Concept, which I did with Albaisa at the Los Angeles Auto Show last fall.)

I soldiered on without him, sycophantic in the extreme. He’ll probably want me to do all his designer walkarounds from now on.
<iframe width="420" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/7Sshew7RdNg" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

title: 2016 Acura RDX
subTitle: The luxury crossover gets Jewel Eye headlamps and other style and substance upgrades.
promoTeaserSmall: The luxury crossover gets Jewel Eye headlamps and other style and substance upgrades.
promoTeaser: The luxury crossover gets Jewel Eye headlamps and other style and substance upgrades.
metaDescription: The luxury crossover gets Jewel Eye headlamps and other style and substance upgrades.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- and all-wheel-drive luxury crossover
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 279 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 20 mpg city/29 mpg highway (front-wheel-drive model); 19/28 mpg (all-wheel-drive model)
Most interesting option: AcuraWatch (includes adaptive cruise control, lane departure warning, autonomous collision mitigation braking, rearview camera), part of Advance option package

At a glance, RDX looks like initials you’d see on the little slip of paper from a pharmacist. In a way, that’s not entirely inaccurate—it’s Acura’s prescription for one of the most popular vehicles in its class.

That class is defined as “entry premium SUV,” and for 2016 Acura builds on the RDX’s best sales year so far (2014) with a freshening that includes styling, safety features, interior trim, and performance. Acura division boss Mike Accavitti calls it “ratcheting up the emotional content.”
Typical of mid-cycle updates, the exterior styling changes are confined to the front and rear of the RDX, plus a new wheel design.

Lighting is an important part of Acura design. The 2016 RDX gets LED projector headlights that Acura calls "jewel eye," already present on Acura models including the ILX and RLX sedans. In back, there are new LED taillamps ringed with "light pipes": LED-fired tubes that emit a neonesque glow.
Interior changes include a black color scheme highlighted by silver trim and standard heated front seats.

Interior changes include a black color scheme highlighted by silver trim and standard heated front seats. The optional Technology package adds eight-way power adjustability for the front passenger seat, a dual-screen multi-information display, a blind spot monitor, and rear cross-traffic alert.

An Advance package option adds keyless remote engine start, front and rear parking sensors, front fog lights, rain-sensing wipers, ventilated front seats, and an auto-dimming driver’s-side mirror. It also includes the AcuraWatch suite of driver assist features, such as adaptive cruise control, lane departure warning, lane-keeping assist, autonomous braking to mitigate collisions, a driver’s-side mirror with expanded view, and a rearview camera.

Based on information supplied by radar and a monocular camera, AcuraWatch is capable of detecting road hazards and pedestrians. The system includes a 4.2-inch TFT display screen, with customizable readouts. Included in the Advance package, AcuraWatch will also be available as a stand-alone option.
Acura’s navigation system, which features voice recognition, is a separate option.

Acura also enhanced the 2016 RDX's structure. Along with the safety technology additions, this should help it sustain top safety ratings from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration and the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. The 2015 model, first introduced three years earlier, has straight Good ratings from IIHS and the top five-star overall rating from NHTSA.

Like the 2015 model, the 2016 RDX is basically a front-wheel-drive vehicle with an all-wheel-drive option and a 3.5-liter V-6 engine. The chassis engineers have reprogrammed the all-wheel- drive system to deliver a higher percentage of the engine’s output to the rear wheels as needed.

The engine, which includes a cylinder deactivation feature for light load situations, provides what Acura calls an “important performance boost,” adding six horsepower (up to 279) and one pound-foot of torque (to 252), across a broader curve. Accompanying this all-but-intangible output increase is a 1-mpg improvement in EPA highway fuel economy ratings: 20 mpg city, 29 highway with front-wheel drive, 19/28 with all-wheel drive.
The 2016 Acura RDX is due to go on sale this spring. Prices weren't announced yet, but the 2015 model starts at $36,015 (including destination).

title: Our Ride in the 2016 Ford Interceptor
subTitle: At the Chicago Auto Show, we got to take a quick spin in the brand-new, Explorer-based cop vehicle.
promoTitle: Our Ride in the 2016 Ford Interceptor
promoTeaserSmall: At the Chicago Auto Show, we got to take a quick spin in the brand-new, Explorer-based cop vehicle.
promoTeaser: At the Chicago Auto Show, we got to take a quick spin in the brand-new, Explorer-based cop vehicle.
keywords: Our Ride in the 2016 Ford Interceptor
metaTitle: Our Ride in the 2016 Ford Interceptor
metaDescription: At the Chicago Auto Show, we got to take a quick spin in the brand-new, Explorer-based cop vehicle.

contributors.displayName: Laura Sky Brown and Molly Jean

pageElements.text:
2016 Ford Police Interceptor Utility

Type: Five-passenger, all-wheel-drive utility vehicle
Engine: 3.7-liter V-6, 304 horsepower, or turbocharged 3.5-liter V-6, 365 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic with Pursuit mode
Most interesting option: Choice of 25 light patterns, including blinking white "wig-wag" function offered "in a nod to police vehicle nostalgia"

Media days at the 2015 Chicago Auto Show start tomorrow, but today, we strolled through the Concept and Technology Garage inside McCormick Place, following the sound of sirens, and there it was: the new 2016 Ford Police Interceptor, lights flashing, taking a slow parade lap.
Naturally, we wanted a ride. And we got one, but first, a little about the vehicle.

Ford's police cars have garnered great popularity among police departments, which you may have noticed in recent years. Ford's cop lineup has a dominant 55 percent market share in the U.S. But did you know that the sport-utility vehicle version, based on the Explorer, is the most popular seller? We didn't. In fact, the SUV outsells the sedan version two to one.
Ford spokesman William Mattiace told us that this Police Interceptor "has really changed the face of police vehicles from cars to SUVs."
It's also sold in 80 countries, but it's built 100 percent by Ford and 100 percent in the city of Chicago.

Mattiace invited us in to the cop car (Laura insisted on sitting in back, in the perp seat). We admired the surveillance technology, which uses sensors and the car's rearview camera to spot whether people are approaching the car and will raise windows and lock doors for protection. It was the idea of engineer Randy Freiburger, who was on site.

Chief engineer Arie Groeneveld told us about his team's work on the new model. "We put our heart and soul into the Police Interceptor," he told us. Ford stays in constant contact with a police advisory board and hold formal meetings twice a year, and then they fine tune based on suggestions. Groeneveld was enthusiastic about safety moves like a rear assembly that has been impact tested to 75 mph. "Nobody else does that," he told us. "We're at the top of our game on safety."

The seats are also made to accommodate police officers' weapons, handcuffs, and other items they carry on their bodies, with durability testing to make the seats both comfortable and durable for them. The interior of the Police Interceptor didn't look terribly different from a standard Explorer, except for a lot more controls in the center console. Up on the headliner, Mattiace demonstrated the red dome light that lets officers spend long evening hours in the car without having to get their eyes reaccustomed to the dark when they're done.

It was fun to ride in the car, but we didn't lose sight of the fact that the Police Interceptor Utility is more than just a ruggedly good-looking SUV with cool graphics. With its specialized equipment, all-wheel drive, and the choice of a 304-horsepower 3.7-liter V-6 or a 365-horsepower EcoBoost V-6 turbo, this is a vehicle with serious work to do. Which is why we were met with polite smiles but no comment when we asked where we could find the optional doughnut holder.

title: 2016 Hyundai Veloster
subTitle: A limited Rally Edition is coming in May. Plus updates to the standard and turbo Velosters.
promoTeaserSmall: A limited Rally Edition is coming in May. Plus: updates to the standard and turbo Velosters.
promoTeaser: A limited Rally Edition is coming in May. Plus: updates to the standard and turbo Velosters.
metaDescription: A limited Rally Edition is coming in May. Plus updates to the standard and turbo Velosters.

pageElements.text:
2016 Hyundai Veloster Rally Edition

Type: Four-passenger, four-door front-wheel-drive hatchback
On-sale date: May 2015
Engine: Turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder, 201 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual with B&M Racing sport shifter
Fuel economy: 25 mpg city/33 mpg highway
Most interesting feature: Rays 18-inch lightweight wheels

The Veloster is Hyundai’s iconoclastic four-door hatchback—one door on the driver’s side, two on the passenger's side, plus the hatch. It will roll into the 2016 model year with a variety of updates, including a limited-production version, the Rally Edition.

The Rally Edition is propelled by the same 1.6-liter direct injection turbo four as the standard Veloster Turbo—201 horsepower, 195 pound-feet of torque. It adds stiffer suspension tuning; Rays eighteen-inch aluminum alloy wheels that are five pounds lighter per wheel than the eighteen-inchers on the standard Turbo; a B&M Racing sport shifter; pseudo carbon fiber trim; black sport seats with the word "Turbo" in white on the blue bolsters; plus rally edition badging and floor mats. The only color available is matte blue, as shown here.
Limited edition means just that; there will be 1,200 built.

The regular Veloster Turbo rolls on slightly heavier alloy wheels. There’s a new seven-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission option, and there’s also a Turbo R-Spec special edition, with red seatbelts. Another interior option includes orange seat bolster highlights and interior accents, whose appeal may not resonate with anyone over twenty-one.
Other 2016 Veloster Turbo updates include new front bucket seats with more aggressive bolsters and a new electroluminescent gauge package with sportier graphics.

Enhancements to the standard 2016 Veloster include the family’s new grille and hood design, a new design for the seventeen-inch aluminum alloy wheels, plus the option of the Turbo’s eighteen-inch wheel/tire package.

Like the Veloster Turbo, the standard Veloster will offer a special interior trim package option that includes sport seats with black bolsters and yellow inserts and yellow highlights elsewhere around the interior.

The standard Veloster continues to be propelled by the normally aspirated, 123-horsepower version of Hyundai’s 1.6-liter direct injection four-cylinder engine. You can have a six-speed manual or an optional six-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission with this engine choice.

Infotainment on the 2016 Veloster is upgraded to include navigation, HD radio capability, Apple’s Siri voice command, SiriusXM Travel Link, and the company’s Blue Link telematics, all controlled on a new seven-inch touchscreen.
The 2016 Velosters will begin arriving in Hyundai showrooms in May.

title: 4 Back Seat Rules of the Road
subTitle: Mindful parenting of those citizens of the back seat of your car.
promoTitle: 4 Back Seat Rules of the Road
promoTeaserSmall: Mindful parenting of those citizens of the back seat of your car.
promoTeaser: Mindful parenting of those citizens of the back seat of your car.
keywords: 4 Back Seat Rules of the Road
metaTitle: 4 Back-Seat Rules of the Road - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Mindful parenting of those citizens of the back seat of your car.

pageElements.text: If you have kids, you already know that you have to adapt your choice of vehicle to the needs of your family at different stages. Just as important as finding a car in which your children’s safety seats fit, you should consider their needs for personal space. If they’re comfortable and feel a sense of ownership of their place in the vehicle, your commutes and road trips will be a lot more fun.

When you shop for a car, it can't be stressed too strongly: Ensure that each of your children has  some personal real estate in the back seat. Here are four things to consider that will make the ride better for them back there.

1. Territory.

Have you ever heard of “proxemics”? It’s the science of personal space. You may not know the word, but if you have kids—or ever were a kid—riding in the back seat with siblings, you’re very familiar with the concept of territory. Apparently people in the Western world like a “personal distance” zone of eighteen inches to four feet around them at all times. Any closer is defined as “intimate distance” and makes people uncomfortable.
Short version: Don't make kids sit squashed together, and let each child have a place that is his or her own space. That's what you would want, and they deserve it just as much.
If you have two kids in the back seat, let them each have a side that is “theirs.” If you have more than that? The people who sell three-row SUVs and crossovers are your friends.

2. Security.

You're told this all the time, but it bears repeating: strap your children in properly and use the right size of car seat. Go to a child seat installation clinic to make sure seats are installed snugly and properly. This is not only for safety but for comfort, security, and right-sizing of your child's body to the seat. This photo of three kids strapped in? Only the one on the left is the right size for her seat. The others should be in booster seats where their heads are on the headrest properly.
Beyond that, strap their things in properly. Put heavy items in the trunk or behind the seats, not rolling around loose, in case you have to slam on the brakes.
Some of the time, your kids should know how to be bored in the car; it builds character. It also leads to the ability to imagine, think clearly, and just decompress.

3. Storage.

Get seatback holders for books, papers, and toys if your vehicle doesn't come with them. Clutter, and a feeling of being temporarily plopped into a messy space, are not conducive to a peaceful drive. For you as the parent, the ability to just get into the car without first gathering up a supply of toys and accessories is very freeing as well. If your child has a comfort object such as a stuffed animal or a blanket, consider having one that's just for the car. (My youngest had a "vacation blankie" that was meant specifically for car trips. Works great, and you don't have to remember to pack the regular one.)

4. Electronics in Moderation.

It is very tempting to hand each child a tablet or iPhone or to drop in a DVD in the rear-seat entertainment system. That's one of the advantages of modern life in cars. It's also a trap. Some of the time, your kids should know how to be bored in the car; it builds character. It also leads to the ability to imagine, think clearly, and just decompress from an overpacked life of ballet lessons, school, sports, and play dates.

If you have crayons or markers, paper, books, and other creative supplies in the car, your kids can occupy themselves with these. Sure, screens have their place, but so does quiet time. Make your kids' rides in the car into an oasis and a respite, not a continuation of the constant plugged-in state they're already in.
Center photo: Thinkstock

title: 100 Real People to Get Self-Driving Volvos
subTitle: The roads around Gothenburg, Sweden, are about to get really interesting.
promoTitle: 100 Real People to Get Self-Driving Volvos
promoTeaserSmall: The roads around Gothenburg, Sweden, are about to get really interesting.
promoTeaser: The roads around Gothenburg, Sweden, are about to get really interesting.
keywords: 100 Real People to Get Self-Driving Volvos
metaTitle: 100 Real People to Get Self-Driving Volvos - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: The roads around Gothenburg, Sweden, are about to get really interesting.

pageElements.text: I remember hearing that, when the television was first invented, many people scoffed. "We don't have time to sit around staring at that," they said. I remember when the microwave oven first came out and there were those, including myself, who gave them a wide berth, feeling it was just not right or natural to take this shortcut to food preparation.
Well, we got over those objections and integrated the technology into our lives.

And, I suspect, drivers are going to do something similar now that Volvo Cars has announced its "complete production-viable autonomous driving system." In other words, the self-driving car is no joke, not anymore.

To underline how close we're getting, Volvo announced today that it will put 100 regular people into quite normal-appearing Volvo XC90s. They will be driven on public roads around Volvo's world headquarters of Gothenburg, Sweden. By 2017, the project will be in full swing, and the cars will be able to take over "every aspect of driving."
It's part of Volvo's Drive Me project, now in its second year.

Hate the idea? Maybe you haven't been out on the highways and streets of southeastern Michigan this winter, as I have. Driver error, or sometimes just driver inattention, can and does lead to all sorts of trouble. Volvo stated an ambitious goal to make cars accident-free by 2020. These autonomous cars will be ready for production by then, or at least, Volvo Drive Me technical expert Henrik Lind says, that's "a realistic target." Who can deny that roads will be safer if the cars can offer more assistance?

The Technology that Creates the Autonomy

For now, the tech takes up a whole lot of trunk space, but Volvo says that by 2017, it will have "significantly shrunk the required space, allowing a vacation with a family." And by 2020, Lind says, all this tech will be so integrated into the car, it will be all but "invisible" as part of the vehicle.

This is just some of the on-board tech:

• Radar. There are seven in all, starting with one in front looking ahead. Four radar sensors, one on each corner of the car, sweep left and right, transmitting "waves that bounce off against signs, poles, and tunnels." And two long-range radars in the back bumper help out by detecting other vehicles coming up quickly from behind.

• Cameras. There's one under each outside mirror, one in the bumper, and one in the grille. These can adjust to changes in lighting conditions, and they're what keep track of lane markings. There's also a trifocal (three lens) camera behind the upper part of the windshield, which can spot pedestrians and "other unexpected road hazards," Volvo says.
• Lasers. There's a multiple-beam laser scanner. It is located below the air intake, and it can identify objects for 140 degrees in front of the vehicle. It can also distinguish between objects.

• Drivers. The 100 test drivers will be chosen based on customers who use the chosen roadways already. Volvo technical specialist Erik Coelingh says they'll be selected to create a mix of age groups, levels of driving experience, and attitudes toward autonomous driving: "early adopters and people that are [skeptical]." They'll be driving leased vehicles with no pay and no extra charge to participate in the study.

Where They'll Drive

The drivers will be able to act normally, and so will the XC90s, taking hands off only where autonomous drive is approved for the pilot project in the Gothenburg area. The driver will be able to choose "regular" manual driving, adaptive cruise control, or "highly autonomous" driving. The idea is to let drivers turn over decision-making tasks to the car in dull, uneventful driving such as commuting on the highway.
In the case of "really adverse" weather conditions, control goes back to the driver, thanks to the car's ability to monitor and make "decisions," Volvo's Lind says.

So, Let's All Get Over It

You can still read a hardcover book rather than watch a screen; you can still put your baked potato or frozen dinner into the oven rather than the microwave. And you will always be able to drive a car the way God intended, with your own brain and hands and feet making the decisions.

But isn't it great that Volvo is making driving safer and giving a hand to those who want or need it?

Volvo on the autonomous route in Gothenburg, Sweden.

title: The First Mazda Miata and Me
subTitle: The car that reset my brain.
promoTitle: The First Mazda Miata and Me
promoTeaserSmall: The car that reset my brain.
promoTeaser: The car that reset my brain.
keywords: The First Mazda Miata and Me
metaTitle: The First Mazda Miata and Me
metaDescription: The car that reset my brain.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Kenichi Yamamoto was the chairman of Mazda when the Miata was born, having been chief engineer for some years. At the time, he was more famous for being the godfather of the rotary engine, but there is no question that the Miata under his watch was his finest accomplishment.
We became friends immediately, bonding over our hometown baseball teams: mine the Detroit Tigers, his the Hiroshima Carp, which Mazda had a financial stake in.  We traded baseball hats.
I was in Hiroshima the night in 1984 the Carp won the pennant. There was free sake in all the bars, and a lot of salarymen lying in the gutters in their three-piece suits, stone drunk.

I brought home the front page of the next day's Hiroshima newspaper, celebrating the win, and I framed it. It hung for years in my office alongside the front page of the Detroit paper with the iconic photo of Kirk Gibson leaping in the air the night the Tigers won the World Series.

Based on our love of baseball, Mr. Yamamoto invited me to come to Japan in 1988 to see a new car they were working on. This was a big deal to me. I had been an automotive journalist for only eight years, and Automobile Magazine was only two years old. To be invited by the chairman of Mazda to come all by myself to Japan was pretty exciting.

They picked me up at the airport and took me out to the Miyoshi proving ground and test track. And then they brought out the Miata prototype. I was blown away. You have to remember that at that time, virtually all little two-seat roadsters had gone away, mostly because they were cute but crappy.

The Miata looked very much like a Lotus Elan, only it had an incredibly sophisticated suspension, double wishbones front and rear. So I quickly began to think of it as a Lotus Elan that was perfectly screwed together and wouldn't leak pools of oil in your driveway.
I will never forget that day. All by myself in Japan, no other journalists, no other cars, in this super-secret open-air roadster.

I was surrounded by engineers from every single department that worked on that Miata. That was a little nervous making. They asked me just to take it out on the track and then come back in and tell them what I thought about it. I will never forget that day. All by myself in Japan, no other journalists, no other cars, in this super-secret open-air roadster that had the tiniest, most perfect little shift lever. I couldn't believe I was there.

I discovered, as did more than a million Miata owners after me, that Mazda’s precious little roadster was a riot to drive without having to go 100 mph to have a good time. It instantly reset my brain about what made a car fun to drive. It had everything to do with how close my eye was to the front wheel. I could literally lean a little to the left and see the apex as I was going around it. I could almost touch it. The five-speed manual shifter was absolute perfection. It was a short throw and you could whip through the gears so precisely, you felt like a genius. The engine was a 1.6-liter straight four-cylinder. It didn't make a lot of horsepower (116), but because the Miata weighed only about a ton, the relatively low horsepower didn't really matter.

It was not a high-powered racing car. Not a Ferrari, not a Porsche, not a Corvette. It was a perfect vehicle for a perfectly twisty road on a sunny day when you didn't have a care in the world. Nowhere to go, nothing to do but look at the scenery.
The Miata was like nothing I had ever driven in my life, and it was about the most fun I had ever had.

It got less fun when I got off the track and was surrounded by the engineers, who led me to a small trackside building, filed in around me at the table, standing room only, and began to ask me questions about my experience. By the time they were done, I felt they had squeezed everything out of my brain. I begged them to stop and then they all bowed and apologized, and that was that.

When I came back to the States, I wrote the first review story for Automobile Magazine. We thought so highly of the Miata that we created Automobile of the Year for it, in 1990. It then won many, many All-Star awards in years to follow, and I wrote a disproportionate share of those stories. I always found something new to say. After testing Miatas over the past twenty-five-plus years, I want to reiterate what I once wrote (about the 2006 Miata): that gentle motoring has a place in our hectic world. It can even be alluring, depending of course on the transport.
My husband bought me a turbocharged Mazdaspeed Miata in 2004, and I became one of the many, many journalists who own their own Miatas.

Other journalists from each of the major automotive publications were also individually invited to Japan to drive that first Miata prototype in 1988, but a few years ago, when former Road & Track editor Thos. Bryant wrote a book about the Miata, he discovered and told me that I was the very first journalist in the world to drive it. Wow. Well, it's possible that I'm still its number-one fan.

images.caption: Driving the first-gen Miata in the U.S. for Automobile Magazine.

title: Real-World Test: Head-Up Display
subTitle: Useful or just one more thing that distracts? We tried it on the 2015 GMC Acadia Denali.
promoTeaserSmall: Useful or just one more thing that distracts? We tried it on the 2015 GMC Acadia Denali.
promoTeaser: Useful or just one more thing that distracts? We tried it on the 2015 GMC Acadia Denali.
metaDescription: Useful or just one more thing that distracts? We tried it on the 2015 GMC Acadia Denali.

contributors.bio: Liane Yvkoff dipped her toe in the pool of automotive writing five years ago and fell directly into the deep end. Since then, she has written about cars for CNET.com, AutoUSA.com, Babble.com, and, oddly enough, Hustler. Residing in the Seattle area, she obviously drives a Subaru Outback.

pageElements.text: The proliferation of GPS-enabled smartphones is threatening to make the once bleeding edge in-dash navigation system obsolete. But head-up display technology is breathing new life into aging systems by putting information front and center—where it should be. I tried it out on a 2015 GMC Acadia Denali SUV, an example of the increasing availability of this technology on mainstream vehicles.

A head-up display (HUD) is a like a movie projector that uses lasers tucked snugly inside the dashboard to display vehicle data, such as your driving speed, directions, and upcoming traffic alerts, on the driver’s side of the windshield. This may sound distracting, but it’s the opposite. The HUD projects data directly in front of a driver’s field of vision so you, the driver, can digest information without turning your head or diverting your eyes from the road ahead.

And you're more likely to encounter it in the future. Only two percent of automobiles sold in 2012 had HUDs, according to industry analytics firm IHS, but the research group predicts that the percentage will rise to 9 percent by 2020.

This technology originated with military aircraft as a way to help fighter pilots absorb 
data quickly. A General Motors spokesperson couldn’t provide any hard statistics but 
assured me that because you’re not removing your eyes from the road ahead, it’s 
“far more safe than glancing down at the navigation screen.” Reaction time is 
faster, and drivers are able to process information 50 percent faster using HUD, 
according to BMW research.
In the driver’s seat, I was able to adjust the information display to my height. Where has HUD been all my life?

HUD is currently found in many luxury brands, such as BMW, Audi, and 
Mercedes, but is slowly making its way to more approachable and mainstream 
vehicles, such as the Acadia.

When I tried it out in the 2015 GMC Acadia Denali, I promptly wondered: Where has HUD been all my life? In the driver’s seat, I was able to adjust the information display to my height so that it appeared just above the steering wheel. The blue monochromatic text and graphics never obscured vision. On the other hand, they could be hard to see under some driving conditions, primarily when there was a blue car in front of me.
The GMC Acadia Denali is by any measure a large vehicle with a big engine. But the prominent digital display of my speed directly in front of my eyes helped me keep the laws of physics in check.

Paired with navigation is where HUD really shines. Native navigation systems in vehicles have become in many ways harder to use than the GPS system on a mobile phone, but integration of turn-by-turn directions with HUD made pecking out the destination on the LCD worthwhile. Distance markers and turn prompts become more clear, and because you’re not looking at an LCD in the center stack to see which in which direction you should go, the drive feels safer.

title: Get Ready for Your Teen's First Car
subTitle: Six sources of valuable information. Consult them before you shop.
promoTitle: Get Ready for Your Teen's First Car
promoTeaserSmall: Six sources of valuable information. Consult them before you shop.
promoTeaser: Six sources of valuable information. Consult them before you shop.
keywords: Get Ready for Your Teen's First Car
metaTitle: Get Ready for Your Teen's First Car - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Six sources of valuable information. Consult them before you shop.

pageElements.text: As spring arrives and graduation ceremonies loom in the near distance, you may be facing the temptation, either to buy your teenager a car or help him or her with the cost. There's a lot to think about first: How much you'll pay and how much the teen will pay. The safety rating. How much gas it guzzles. Keeping it repaired. Paying for insurance! Here are six quick sources you can consult to do some preparatory homework.

1. Insurance Institute for Highway Safety's Shopping List for Used Cars

The safety-focused nonprofit surveyed parents in 2014 and found that the median purchase price for a teen's car was $5,300. This is the same group that issues Top Safety Pick awards to vehicles, rewarding those that are well equipped with safety technology. Since most of those newer models are out of reach on a budget, IIHS has a list of recommended used cars for teens, grouped into under $20,000 and under $10,000 lists.

2. National Highway Traffic Safety Administration's "Purchasing with Safety in Mind"

The federal government agency that does the crash tests offers this brochure, which explains its tests in detail and lists safety ratings for 2014 models. The agency's website also lets you search safety ratings by make and model for vehicles from 1990 to 2015 model years.

3. Consumer Reports' Recommendations: 10 Used Cars for Teen Drivers

The publication that geeks out on product testing has just issued a list of what it calls the "safest used cars under $10,000" for teenage drivers. These cars were chosen based on the presence of electronic stability control (required on all cars starting with the 2012 model year) and side and curtain air bags. CR recommends mid-size or full-size sedans over SUVs, believing their lower center of gravity makes them more stable.
Before you even start looking at cars, it's good to get the straight story on how much it will cost to insure various kinds of vehicles and make a plan to pay for it.

4. U.S. Department of Energy's Fuel Economy Check

Gas prices are looking good right now, but there are two reasons they still matter to teen drivers: (1) this will be a major new expense that they'll want to minimize, and (2) if they're interested in ecological correctness at all, they'll want to explore choices in hybrid, diesel, and fuel-sipping vehicles.

5. AAA's Teen Driver Insurance Guide

The cost of insurance for young drivers can be daunting. Before you even start looking at cars, it's good to get the straight story on how much it will cost to insure various kinds of vehicles and make a plan to pay for it. The insurance company also has a brochure, So Your Teen Wants a Car? (To which we answer, Duh!)

6. AutoMD's Teen Driver Maintenance Guide

Open your teen's eyes to the responsibilities inherent in maintaining that car. This downloadable guide has a checklist of tasks and a brief explanation of how to carry them out, from replacing wiper blades to changing the oil.
Header: Photodisc/Thinkstock

title: 3 St. Patrick's Day Reminders
subTitle: Drivers, you can embrace the fun and tackiness of this holiday and still be safe.
promoTeaserSmall: Drivers, you can embrace the fun and tackiness of this holiday and still be safe.
promoTeaser: Drivers, you can embrace the fun and tackiness of this holiday and still be safe.
metaDescription: Drivers, you can embrace the fun and tackiness of this holiday and still be safe.

pageElements.text: St. Patrick's Day may be in the middle of the week this year, but chances are there are still people out there making poor choices about drinking and driving. We know you aren't among them, but take this reminder to be an example for others, not least to your own kids, teenagers, and other young adults in your life.
Here are three things you should do on this and every celebration-oriented holiday (actually, every time you go out).

1. Always have a designated driver.

Before you (or your kids) go out, agree on who that person will be.

2. But have a backup plan, too.

If you don't have a sober driver on hand, get a taxi or call a friend for a ride. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration offers an app for that called Safer Ride. It's on Google Play and the iTunes Store. Set up its uncomplicated interface, and have it ready when you need it. Ensure your kids do the same.

3. And find some non-drinking ways to have fun.

St. Patrick's Day is one of the dangerous holidays, both for good taste and for good behavior. If you're having a party, serve plenty of food and non-alcoholic drinks, stop serving alcohol a few hours before the end of the party, and don't let underage people drink at all.
St. Patrick's Day can be the most sincere, yet the most tacky of holidays. Go ahead, embrace the whole Erin Go Bragh theme and the silliness of it all. I mean, why not? And you don't have to be drunk to do that.
NHTSA reminds you that there were thirty-one deaths in drunk-driving crashes in 2013. Don't be a statistic, and don't let the people around you be a statistic.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: With the Geneva Auto Show behind me, I lined up a flight to Fort Lauderdale by way of Amsterdam and Atlanta, to spend a few days warming up before the 20th Amelia Concours d’Elegance, my favorite. I fell asleep, tightly bookended between two businessmen, the second I boarded in Geneva, and never stirred until we touched down. I thought I was in Atlanta and it took a second to realize that I’d only just begun my long, arduous day in the great prison ships of the sky.

You will perhaps be surprised that I really like Delta. KLM, not so much. I might actually hate them, but that would imply that I once loved them. This trip, I had to rush to get to the surly security and the world’s worst X-ray line—the only one I’ve experienced that has you unload not only your computer, but also your power cords, headphones, Flip cameras, iPhone, iPad, camera, electric nostril hair clippers, while the agent on the other side of the conveyor harangues you out of your hat, your coat, your belt, your watch, your shoes, and your dignity. It looked like a Buster Keaton movie.
Champagne, slipper socks, lip balm, a gourmet lunch. A perfect flight attendant named Tom who looked exactly like former Ford CEO Alan Mulally, whom we all miss terribly.

The Delta crew welcomed me into the comfort of business class. Champagne, slipper socks, lip balm, a gourmet lunch menu to consider. A flat bed with fluffy down comforter. A perfect flight attendant named Tom who looked exactly like former Ford CEO Alan Mulally, whom we all miss desperately.

We were rudely awakened from the near-swoon of privilege by the captain who announced that there had been a security breach—a door to the unsecured concourse was open during the entire boarding process. We needed to put down our champagne, crawl out from under our blankies, and leave the plane immediately with all of our belongings. Stop it.

Back to the wrong side of the X-ray bureaucrats we went, while security tapes were scrutinized, only to discover that the KLM snotwads hadn’t secured the door. Of course we had to once again surrender our power cords, our clothing, our shoes, our dignity, et cetera, to reboard. Tom/Mulally was waiting our return with fresh champagne, but the thrill was gone. Of course, my connecting flight was also gone, the next flight had fifty people waiting standby, and my luggage had fallen off the radar. Kind of a quad-fecta of bad luck.

But things picked up significantly from there. The temperature in southern Florida was approximately 113 degrees warmer than when I’d left Michigan, give or take a degree or two. That, and the fact that a Hermosa Blue 2015 Infiniti QX60 3.5 with ventilated front seats was waiting for me and my next adventure—the road to Amelia Island.
Who could bitch, right?

Love,
Jean

title: 2016 Kia Sorento SX AWD
subTitle: A solid utility player in a crowded crossover marketplace. Is it the one for you?
promoTeaserSmall: A solid utility player in a crowded crossover marketplace. Is it the one for you?
promoTeaser: A solid utility player in a crowded crossover marketplace. Is it the one for you?
metaDescription: A solid utility player in a crowded crossover marketplace. Is it the one for you?

pageElements.text:
Type: Five- or seven-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive crossover vehicle
Base price: Sorento SX: $38,965 (including destination charge)
This car: $40,595 (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.3-liter V-6, 290 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 17 mpg city/23 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Navigation system (standard on SX)
Option I can’t live without: Infinity premium surround sound audio system
Notable standard features on this model: Panoramic power sunroof, navigation, heated leather seats, premium audio, power rear liftgate
Notable options on this model: All-wheel drive ($1,800)
You might also be considering: 2015 Ford Edge Titanium AWD ($38,415), 2015 GMC Acadia SLT-2 AWD ($45,020), 2015 Mazda CX-9 Sport AWD ($32,455), 2015 Nissan Pathfinder SL 4WD ($38,635), 2015 Toyota Highlander LE AWD ($33,710) (prices include destination charges)

Like its Hyundai parent, Kia is a car company that has come a long way in a remarkably short time, and the 2016 Sorento is yet another manifestation of its steady climb. Attractively styled (by SUV standards), solidly assembled, handsomely appointed, and dynamically competent, this third generation of Kia’s mid-size crossover is an appealing package in a market crowded with appealing packages.

So where does the Sorento stand out from the crowd? The short answer is: nowhere in particular. The Sorento is like a baseball major leaguer who can play any position on the field, none of them at an all-star level, but all of them pretty well.

Fundamentals: This is a substantially roomier Sorento. Thanks to a 3.1-inch wheelbase stretch, to 109.4 inches, and a small increase laterally, there’s more space for second-row passengers to stretch their legs, as well as more cargo space behind the rearmost seats. The Sorento is available in both five- and seven-passenger versions. In the three-row version, those wayback seats are still pretty tight and really best suited to young kids. But this criticism is not unique to the Sorento.

Structure and assembly are impressive strong suits, qualities that communicate themselves to the driver on gnarly pavement and/or washboard stretches of gravel, such as Forest Service roads en route to a vacation cabin. Never a quiver, never a shudder, never a buzz, squeak, or rattle. This is attributable to a unibody composed of a much higher percentage of high-strength steel, yielding a sense of reassuring solidity.
The development team invested heavily in noise reduction, which pays off with one of the more serene interiors in this class.
A new electric power steering system amplifies the overall sense of competence, and the suspension offers respectable responses complemented by supple ride quality.

Keep in mind that we’re talking about a large vehicle with substantial mass and substantial height, along with enough ground clearance to make off-pavement travel plausible. These are not sports car specifications, ladies and gentlemen. Do not expect sports car performance and/or agility. But you probably knew that already.

There are three engine options for the 2016 Sorento. The standard engine in the base version is a 2.4-liter four-cylinder, with a performance upgrade for the new Sorento, to 185 horsepower. Optional powerplants include a 290-horsepower 3.3-liter V-6, carried over from the previous generation, and, new to the inventory, a 2.0-liter turbo rated for 240 horsepower.

The turbo delivers a lovely torque surge, but the V-6 has substantially more grunt, to handle the mass of a Sorento seven-seater with all-wheel drive, and also to raise the towing capability from 3,500 to 5,000 pounds.

All Sorentos are equipped with a six-speed automatic transmission. This crossover comes as front-wheel drive or, like our test car, all-wheel drive. You also have a choice of five- or seven-passenger models.

As you’d expect, fuel economy suffers slightly with the more potent engine—the V6 is EPA rated for 18 mpg city, 23 highway (we averaged a drop or two over 19 mpg in a week of suburban and rural travels).

Consistent with an overall strategy of moving Kia vehicles steadily upscale, the new Sorento’s interior is distinguished by meticulous workmanship, quality materials, soft touch surfaces, elegant stitchery, attractive instrumentation, and, as noted, more room for first and second-row passengers, as well as small increases in cargo volume.
It’s also distinguished by exceptionally quiet operation at all speeds. The development team invested heavily in noise reduction, which pays off with one of the more serene interiors in this class.

Our SX test unit was one rung below the top of the Sorento price ladder, so its list of standard features was extensive—heated perforated-leather seats; user-friendly navigation, accessed on a large (eight inch) center-dash touchscreen; telematics galore; high-end Infinity audio; giant power moonroof; power rear hatch; all-wheel drive; nineteen-inch wheels; and a respectable (though not exactly outstanding) array of safety features.

There’s a lot of content baked into that trim level. But if $40,595 sounds a little steep, the bidding starts well south of there: $25,795 for the Sorento L, a basic front-wheel-drive five-passenger version with the 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine. And basic isn’t very basic at all.

The Verdict:

Like other Hyundai-Kia products, the Sorento comes with a goodly array of standard features, even on the base model, and content becomes increasingly comprehensive going up the price ladder. The price-value index is near the top among competing vehicles, and there are many to choose from: L, LX, EX, SX-Limited, all with a four-cylinder engine; and LX, EX, and SX-Limited models with the V-6.

We suggested competitors for the seven-passenger Sorento—the Ford Edge (also new for 2016), GMC Acadia, Mazda CX-9, Nissan Pathfinder, and Toyota Highlander. There’s also a five-passenger version of the Kia crossover, and in that category you might also consider the Jeep Grand Cherokee, Nissan Murano, and Volkswagen Touareg.

The Sorento does everything well, and it is close to the top of the charts in terms of one all-important metric: quiet, roomy comfort.

images.caption: The Kia Sorento is new for 2016.
2016 Kia Sorento comes in five- or seven-passenger versions.
2016 Kia Sorento. Navigation is standard on the SX model we tried.

title: 2015 Alfa Romeo 4C
subTitle: Alfa returns to the U.S. with a coupe that is all about sport.
promoTeaserSmall: Alfa returns to the U.S. with a coupe that is all about sport.
promoTeaser: Alfa returns to the U.S. with a coupe that is all about sport.
metaKeywords: 2015 Alfa Romeo 4C; Alfa Romeo; sports cars; convertible; Italian cars
metaDescription: 2015 Alfa Romeo 4C: Alfa returns to the U.S. with a coupe that is all about sport.

pageElements.text:
Type: Two-passenger, rear-wheel-drive coupe
Price range: $55,195–$69,695 (including destination)
Trim levels: 4C, 4C Launch Edition
Engine: 1.75-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 237 horsepower
Transmission: 6-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): 24/34 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: Not yet rated
Our favorite standard feature: Carbon fiber chassis
Notable standard features on this model: Paddle shifters, seven-inch digital driver display, four driving modes (All Weather, Natural, Dynamic, Race)
Notable options on this model: Red or black leather upholstery; racing exhaust
You might also be considering: BMW M3, Chevrolet Corvette, Porsche Cayman

Hard-edged and uncompromising, the Alfa Romeo 4C rasps and roars for a highly involving driving experience. It’s like a motorcycle with four wheels. With a short wheelbase, wide stance, and near 50/50 weight distribution, it takes corners like a Black Friday shopper careening into the electronics department. The turbocharged direct-injection four-cylinder engine is situated in the middle, just behind the cockpit, and will push the lightweight coupe from 0 to 60 mph in less than 5.0 seconds and on to a maximum speed of 160 mph. The driver can manually operate the transmission with shift paddles or let it change gears automatically. Steering lacks power assist; this is touted as a feature (there’s more feedback, although much more effort is required at low speed). Selecting the driving mode helps the coupe behave in bad weather or misbehave on the racetrack, with normal and sportier settings in between.

The 4C is all about sport, and you wouldn’t choose it over your SUV for a trip to the market, as there’s virtually no cargo capacity or interior storage space. Alfa Romeo chose the 4C to spearhead its return this year to the United States in order to emphasize the brand’s sporting heritage, with several more models promised in the coming years. A roadster version of the 4C will go on sale this summer.

New for 2015:

The 4C is an all-new model for 2015.

More about the Alfa Romeo 4C

2015 Alfa Romeo 4C Spider January 12, 2015

Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. pageElements.text:
Type: Seven-passenger, front-wheel-drive luxury crossover
Base price: $43,395 (including destination charge)
This car: $54,690 (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 265 horsepower
Transmission: Continuously variable automatic with manual shift mode
Fuel economy: 21 mpg city/27 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Power rear liftgate
Options I can’t live without: Backup collision intervention, blind spot and lane departure warning, intelligent cruise control (part of Technology package, $2,800)
Notable standard features on this model: Rearview camera, heated front seats
Notable options on this model: Navigation, eight-inch touchscreen, Around View monitor with moving object detection and front and rear sonar (part of Premium Plus package, $3,000)
You might also be considering: 2015 Acura MDX ($43,685), 2015 Audi Q7 ($48,300), 2015 Buick Enclave ($39,050), 2015 Lincoln MKT ($43,210) (prices include destination charges)
The Infiniti QX60 3.5 looks like a big SUV (it’s actually mid-size), but it is surprisingly easy to drive and to live with, for a three-row crossover.

It helps that the QX60 has just a ton more style than cars of this ilk. The side profile is quite lovely, and both front and rear views aren’t the locomotives we’ve become used to seeing. And it helps that the interior is a beautifully, thoughtfully trimmed luxury palace, even without the $11,000-plus in options, which took our test car from a base price of $43,395 to $54,690.

In addition to the standard features you would expect (heated front seats, a good audio system, all of the necessary ports and jacks for your electronics, and a full complement of front, side, and curtain airbags), you’ll be pleased to find leather-appointed seats, a power sliding and tilting glass moonroof, and Bluetooth hands-free phone system.
The interior is a beautifully, thoughtfully trimmed luxury palace, even without the $11,000-plus in options on our test vehicle.

Drivers of smaller stature (and I with my Demolition Derby-damaged neck) will especially appreciate the standard power tilting and telescoping steering column, the power rear liftgate, and a rearview monitor which, together, make the QX60 less daunting. All part of the price of entry.

Options? Oh, buddy, are there options! You are on your own there, but bring your checkbook. The Deluxe Touring package is $3,450 (it’s where you find the air-conditioned front seats and the power-up folding third row). The Premium package is $1,550, and that’s where my beloved heated steering wheel lives. There is also the Premium Plus package ($3,000) with the magic AroundView Monitor with its moving object detection and front and rear sonar. You can sort it and your budget out on Infiniti’s online configurator.

Our test car had all of that razzmatazz and, frankly, I liked it, yes I did. But the only must-have in my book is the Technology package ($2,800). That’s where most all of the advanced safety resides, those technologies that are the precursors to fully autonomous cars: full-speed-range intelligent cruise control, lane departure warning and prevention, blind spot warning and intervention, intelligent brake assist with forward collision warning, and backup collision intervention. You’ll notice that most of these are more than warnings and alerts; they actually intervene when you’re just not cutting it behind the wheel.
And isn’t that what autonomous cars are all about?

You’ll still be doing the driving in the 2015 QX60, so it’s good to know that the 3.5-liter V-6 produces 265 horsepower—not a barnstormer off the line, but it will take you easily to 80 mph. It has a continuously variable automatic transmission (CVT), which Infiniti is very big on, and there are Standard, Sport, Snow, and Eco drive modes. The main CVT benefit is that there are no gears to mesh and gnash and make loud noises while straining to up- and downshift. CVTs do a better job of maintaining optimum engine revs. And that pretty much works. The QX60’s CVT tends to hem and haw a little at higher speeds, but probably not enough to bother most drivers. You can ameliorate it by changing the drive mode switch to Sport.
More things in life should have a Sport option.

Three-row crossovers attract a specific clientele that are not me. I have no children, I don’t have that many friends that need carting around, and the ones I have would rather walk than crawl into the wayback of an SUV.

I tested the QX60’s cargo area by bringing everything I owned and my husband’s golf clubs for an 1,100-mile trip across Florida. With mid-size utility vehicles, you have to give up cargo to get that third row of seats. We did the opposite, accessing maximum cargo space with the power liftgate and power buttons that flipped down the 50/50 split-folding third-row bench. The low load floor is a boon to women of the world with girly amounts of shoulder strength.
That third row is pretty plush, with plenty of knee room and seatbacks that recline. Getting back there is made easier by a clever forward flip of the second-row seat.

Three rollerboards went in upright, followed by the bag of clubs, four stuffed duffels, a few hatboxes, two garment bags, and, yes, more. And you could still see out the rear window from the rearview mirror. Without those clubs, we could have left 50 percent of the bench up for a passenger.

When you don’t need room for antiquing, that third row is pretty plush, with plenty of knee room and backs that recline. Getting back there is made easier by a clever forward flip of the outboard second-row seat behind the driver. This sets it up to slide forward on the same tracks that allow second-row passengers to fine tune legroom. Even cooler is the ability to leave a child seat attached in place, while accessing the third row. You won’t have to make your kids crawl in through the rear and scale the back seat from behind.

There’s an overhead handhold and an indentation in the sill to give you a boost. I gave it a go, got my six-foot frame up and through the generous opening, and was impressed. However, getting out of the third seat almost crippled me. I’d recommend calling dibs on that second row with its cushy reclining and sliding seats and its own climate controller, complete with precise temperature settings.
I, meanwhile, will stick to the driving.

title: 2015 Audi R8
subTitle: A powerful expression of the Audi aesthetic.
promoTeaserSmall: A powerful expression of the Audi aesthetic.
promoTeaser: A powerful expression of the Audi aesthetic.
metaKeywords: 2015 Audi R8; Audi; sports car; German
metaDescription: A powerful expression of the Audi aesthetic. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: All-wheel-drive sport coupe or convertible
Price range: $117,150–$183,750 (includes destination)
Trim levels: R8 V8 coupe and convertible, R8 V10 coupe and convertible, R8 V10 Plus coupe
Engines: R8: 4.2-liter V-8, 430 horsepower; R8 V10: 5.2-liter V-10, 525 horsepower; R8 V10 plus: 5.2-liter V-10, 550 horsepower
Transmissions: Six-speed manual, seven-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): R8 manual: 11/20; R8 automatic: 14/23; R8 V10 and V10 plus manual: 12/19; R8 V10 and V10 Plus: 13/22 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: Not yet rated
Our favorite standard feature: Gated manual shifter
Notable standard features on this model: Power-folding heated exterior mirrors
Notable options on this model: Diamond-stitched Alcantara headliner
You might also be considering: Ferrari 458 Italia/Spider, Porsche 911

The Audi R8 is the exception to the rule that all Audis are elegant and sedate. Elegant, yes, but the R8's ground-hugging stance and sculpted side panels is on another, more sporting level entirely. Equipped with the automatic transmission, the 4.2-liter engine propels the R8 coupe from 0 to 60 in 4.2 seconds. The R8 V10 makes the same sprint in 3.4 seconds. Audi has gone to significant lengths to create a sports car that is as comfortable around town as a sedan. All R8s have Audi’s Quattro all-wheel-drive system. A cozy high-tech interior accommodates two tall adults comfortably in leather-stitched sport seats. Drivers can choose between a handsome coupe and a convertible, although the R8 V10 Plus is available as a coupe only. A lighter, flatter, more powerful 2016 model R8 made its debut at the Geneva Auto Show in March, so that's something to look forward to next year.

New for 2015

An Alcantara headliner is now standard on R8 V10 coupe and R8 V10 Plus models.

Who Wants to Drive an Audi R8? October 29, 2013

title: 4 Cars with Tech to Help Your Teen
subTitle: 2016 Chevrolet Malibu is the latest car with features to limit teens' ability to get into trouble.
promoTitle: 4 Cars with Tech to Help Your Teen
promoTeaserSmall: 2016 Chevrolet Malibu is the latest car with features to limit teens' ability to get into trouble.

keywords: 4 Cars with Tech to Help Your Teen
metaTitle: 4 Cars with Tech to Help Your Teen - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: 2016 Chevrolet Malibu is the latest car with features to limit teens' ability to get into trouble.

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. I currently write the Family Tech column in Family Circle magazine and Family Tech with Christina at FamilyCircle.com, and I blog on the Geek Girlfriends site. Clients--past and present--include Better Homes and Gardens, Popular Science, This Old House Magazine, USA Weekend, PC Magazine, PC World, Jaguar, Saks Fifth Avenue, and many others. I am thrilled to be a part of Jean Knows Cars.

pageElements.text: Look back at those kids bickering in your back seat on the way to school, and enjoy them while they last. Before you know it, they’ll be asking for the keys and driving themselves to school.

The most shocking thing about that may be that you will actually hand the keys over and let your baby maneuver that fast, massive, and potentially deadly machine into the world. It may well be the hardest moment that most parents have to face. We’re not wrong to worry. Car accidents are the number-one killers of teenagers. But here are four automakers doing something to help us feel a little less stressed out over it.

1. Chevrolet: Teen Driver

To help mitigate the blind terror of standing in your kitchen hoping she survives the deadly combination of a powerful vehicle and her own youth, Chevrolet is the latest automaker to do something about that. Its new Teen Driver feature will be on the upcoming 2016 Chevrolet Malibu.

Teen Driver is a set of features that helps protect teens from themselves. It mutes the radio till kids buckle the seatbelt, automatically turns on any active safety features the car is equipped with (forward collision alert, lane departure correction, and collision avoidance technology), and allows parents to select a maximum speed between 40 and 75 mph, that, if exceeded, activates a visual warning and audible chime. Other automakers have similar technology, but Chevrolet claims the 2016 Malibu will be the first vehicle to offer up an in-car display of how teens are driving. The system will show, on the car’s infotainment screen, the maximum speed the teen driver reached, distance driven, and the number of times the active safety features were called on while the teenager was behind the wheel.
The 2016 Chevrolet Malibu's Teen Driver feature can mitigate the blind terror of hoping your kid survives the deadly combination of a powerful vehicle and her own youth.

Parental control features in cars are certainly something you want to consider when shopping for a car that your kids might eventually drive. So if you love and covet a Malibu, these technologies could make it the car for your family. But there are other cars with features that help the parents of teens keep their kids alive during this dangerous learning phase of driving. There are even a few aftermarket devices (such as the app-linked Automatic, $99) that let you add some of these features to the car you have.

2. Ford: MyKey

Ford’s MyKey technology is similar to the Malibu's, and it is already in six million Ford and Lincoln cars on the road.The features are tied to the keys. So when you hand your kids their own set of keys, the keys tell the car to mute the radio till kids buckle up, chime if kids drive too fast, block incoming calls to the car when teens are driving, and set a maximum speed for the car. MyKey also adds extra reminders to fill the tank when teens are driving.

3. Lexus: Enform Remote

The Lexus Enform Remote not only lets you lock, unlock, and start some Lexus cars from a mobile device, it lets you create a profile for your teen to set limits on speed and distance or create a curfew. If your teen drives too fast or stays out past the limits of her provisional license, the app sends a push notification to your phone. A call to the Bluetooth-enabled vehicle will rein your recalcitrant teen back in without asking them to take their hands of the wheel.

4. Hyundai: Blue Link

This host of connected features in most 2013-15 model year Hyundais allows parents to set a maximum speed or choose a geo-fenced area. If the car exceeds that speed or leaves the designated area, it will rat the teen out via text. The program will also let you set a curfew for the car that alerts teens it’s time to bring the party home.

There is nothing quite as good as you sitting in the passenger’s seat for keeping a teen driver focused and following the rules, but sometimes you have to let them drive alone. For those times, putting a little technological ear (or a virtual eye) in the car can be almost as good as being there.

title: 2015 Buick LaCrosse
subTitle: Full-size car for the ages.
promoTeaserSmall: Full-size car for the ages.
promoTeaser: Full-size car for the ages.
metaDescription: Full-size car for the ages. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive full-size sedan
Price: $31,990 (includes destination)
Trim level: LaCrosse, Leather, Premium I, Premium II
Engines: 2.4-liter four-cylinder with eAssist, 182 horsepower; 3.6-liter V-6, 304 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 2.4-liter: 25 mpg city/36 mpg highway; 3.6-liter, FWD: 18/28 mpg; 3.6-liter, AWD: 17/26 mpg

Our favorite standard feature: Rearview camera
Notable standard features on this model: OnStar with 4G LTE and Wi-Fi hotspot, 8-inch display screen, articulating headlamps
Notable options on this model: Radar- and camera-based safety features, adaptive cruise control, all-wheel drive, wheels up to 20 inches
You might also be considering: Lexus ES350, Lincoln MKZ, Toyota Avalon

The key statistic with the 2015 Buick LaCrosse is 101 cubic feet of passenger volume. The sedan does not come with overhead straps and rails for those who must stand in the aisle, but otherwise it’s like a bus. This is the big roomy American car for people who’d rather not get out their climbing gear and scale the sheer wall of an SUV. And as always, being a Buick, the LaCrosse represents a sensible value equation, even when it’s loaded with luxury, convenience, and safety features. Otherwise, it doesn’t much resemble the Buicks of yore. It comes with a 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine that’s aided by the “mild hybrid” eAssist feature, an electric drive system that delivers an extra shove in support of the combustion engine. That means 36 highway mpg—really good for a car its size. The optional engine is the nice 3.6-liter V-6, and it can be paired with all-wheel drive for a sure-footedness that the good country doctor didn’t enjoy more than 100 years ago when making house calls in his Buick Model 10. The LaCrosse is everything Buick has always stood for: substantial, discreetly well appointed, durable, and a good value. What’s different is all the advanced electronic systems and features that keep you squarely in your lane while also keeping you in touch and in tunes.

New for 2015

OnStar with 4G LTE and standard WiFi hot spot, improved IntelliLink, four-way adjustable front-seat headrests, new exterior colors, standard rearview camera

subTitle: Aging on good bones.

promoTeaser: Aging on good bones.

Transmission: Six-speed automatic

Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars

Notable options on this model: 20-inch wheels, articulating headlamps, heated and cooled front seats, dual-pane moonroof
You might also be considering: Acura MDX, Infiniti JX, Volvo XC90

With its debut as a 2008 model, the Enclave changed all perceptions of what a Buick could be. It brought a raked windshield, tapering roofline, and undulant bodywork to Buick showrooms, where the staff and clientele were accustomed to boxes. And it was introduced in brown, a rather daring color choice for the time. Since then, brown Enclaves have dotted American neighborhoods. How much has the Enclave changed? The 3.6-liter V-6 makes 13 more horsepower that it originally did and slightly better fuel economy in front-wheel-drive configuration. And there has been a progression of additional features, including this year’s heated wood steering wheel. But otherwise, it’s the same convenient, well-crafted big crossover as always: quiet and capable. To most eyes, it’s also beautiful. An all-new Enclave is expected for 2017, and it will have the advanced collision avoidance and other driver-assistance features lacking on the current model. In the meantime, there’s a strong value proposition for this Enclave. And you can always claim to be driving a future classic.

New for 2015

Available heated wood steering wheel, four new exterior colors, dark plum interior.

subTitle: Grand touring with the grandkids.

Safety ratings: N/A

Notable standard features on this model: The massive V-12 engine, of course. Carbon-ceramic brakes are lighter, dissipate heat more quickly, and resist warping.
Notable options on this model: The Carbon Edition adds carbon-fiber body pieces and interior trim to go with black or white bodywork.
You might also be considering: Bentley Continental GT Speed, Ferrari California T

The Aston Martin DB9 was updated a couple of years ago with deep creases at the nose and along the sills as well as more subtle contouring of the upper body. The result is a no loss of sex appeal for this grand tourer. Be assured, people will notice when you arrive in Newport Beach. And the trip will have been enjoyable, thanks to the V-12 engine’s creamy and nearly infinite power delivery, the supple ride, and the responsive and sure handling. At the touch of a beautiful glass button, throttle, transmission, and suspension responses are transformed, putting the car in electronically determined normal, sport, or track modes. The DB9 is available as a coupe or Volante convertible, and of course it can be ordered according to your preference in materials and finishes. This is the car that rewards you for great success, and it also rewards the grandchildren, who will find the tiny backseat a fun novelty.

New for 2015

The DB9 Carbon Edition.

title: 2015 Aston Martin Rapide S
subTitle: The fastest shape in the esses.
promoTeaserSmall: The fastest shape in the esses.
promoTeaser: The fastest shape in the esses.
metaKeywords: 2015 Aston Martin Rapide S; Aston Martin; British; sedan
metaDescription: The fastest shape in the esses. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Sedan
Price range: $207,820 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Rapide S
Engine: 5.9-liter V-12, 552 horsepower
Transmission: 8-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): 14/22 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: N/A
Our favorite standard feature: A top speed of 203 mph.
Notable standard features on this model: A 1000-watt audio system
Notable options on this model: A headrest-mounted, twin-screen rear entertainment system, four types of interior wood trim and carbon fiber, ventilated front and rear seats, and personalized sill plaques.
You might also be considering: Ferrari FF, Mercedes-Benz S-Class coupe, Porsche Panamera

While Aston Martin’s coupes, roadsters, and grand tourers carry sporting credentials, the Rapide S is the English marque’s sole “normal” car. Aston Martin calls it a coupe and a four-door sports car, but in these parts we say sedan because, shapely as it may be, it has four doors. And it comfortably conveys four persons. There’s no denying it has sedanlike (or even minivanlike) amenities, namely, eight air bags and rear seat entertainment including video screens. No matter the label, it’s a gorgeous thing, and when you behold one parked in front of your resort hotel, you’ll wish it were yours.
The Rapide S is improved for 2015. The V-12 engine now makes 552 horsepower—that’s 18-percent better—and mates with an eight-speed automatic transmission. The car shoots from 0 to 60 mph in 4.2 seconds and reaches 203 mph. The even more advanced stability control adjusts for whatever pushbutton driving mode—normal, sport, or track—is selected. In typical Aston Martin fashion, the options for individualizing the car are nearly overwhelming, so you can choose colors, trim, wheels, and finishes just as you’d like. Then, to ensure that no one else’s Rapide S duplicates yours, specify the optional, personalized door sill plaques and use your nickname. We think Aston Martin’s equipment is sophisticated enough to spell Pookey Bear.

New for 2015

AM29 V-12 engine with Bosch engine management, eight-speed automatic transmission, improved front brakes, revised stability control, additional color and trim options—including a new diamond quilting design for both seats and headliner.

More about the Aston Martin Rapide S

Driving Aunt Mimi July 18, 2013

pageElements.text:

Transmission: Six-speed manual, seven-speed automatic
Fuel economy: V-8, manual: 13 mpg city/19 mpg highway; V-8, automatic 14/21 mpg; V-12: 12/18 mpg
Safety ratings: N/A
Our favorite standard feature: Green, white, and yellow graphics (one of five available color schemes) on the new Vantage GT.
Notable standard features on this model: Powerful brakes using six-piston calipers for tremendous response
Notable options on this model: Rearview camera, heated seats
You might also be considering: Mercedes-AMG GT S, Porsche 911 Turbo

Stuff a big engine into a short-wheelbase car. Apply outrageous graphics and color schemes. No, we’re not talking about muscle cars from Detroit. But the 2015 Aston Martin Vantage is up to those same tricks. It’s a good strategy for an older car. While forever beautiful, the Vantage is showing its age. Crinkles around the eyes, you know. The newest model, the Vantage GT, is the least expensive, starting at $102,525. It pays tribute to Aston’s racing heritage by wearing any of five multicolor schemes ranging from subtle to loud. Like every other Vantage, it’s available as a coupe or roadster. And like all other Vantage V8 models, it’s offered with a six-speed manual or seven-speed automatic, which can be operated via paddle shifters. And then there’s the amazing V12 Vantage S. The seven-speed is the only transmission here. We plopped into a Roadster on a beautiful autumn day, noted the weave of the carbon fiber shift paddles sparkling in the sun, savored the fragrant leather. Docking the beautiful glass “key,” we heard the dual exhausts deliver a message from Jove. As on the more expensive Vanquish, the beautifully lined convertible top operated quickly and without fuss. Driving the car over country roads made us forget all the world’s bad news, freed us from all that is coarse and mundane. There may be newer cars and more exciting technology, but the Vantage V12 Roadster will deliver an unforgettable experience with every drive.

New for 2015

Vantage GT coupe and roadster with six-speed manual or seven-speed automatic pay tribute to Aston Martin’s racing heritage while bringing down the entry-level price by about $20,000.

title: 2015 Fiat 500
