Transmissions: Five-speed manual, six-speed automatic, or single-speed automatic
Fuel economy: Manual: 31 mpg city/40 mpg highway; automatic: 27/34 mpg; turbo: 28/34 mpg; Abarth, manual 24/34 mpg; Abarth, automatic 24/32 mpg; 500e:122/108 mpg-e
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Good in four categories, Poor in small front overlap; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Abarth buyers can attend the Abarth Track Experience for free
Notable standard features on this model: Seven-inch TFT display, leather-wrapped steering wheel
Notable options on this model: Rear park assist
You might also be considering: Ford Fiesta, Mini Cooper, Nissan Leaf, Smart ForTwo

Since introduction to the U.S. market in 2012, the Fiat 500’s range has rapidly expanded beyond the basic coupe we loved at first sight. Regardless of which model you choose, you are assured of the ability to express a glamorous, modern, or sporty aesthetic. For example, there is the new 500 Turbo that fits in between the tame 500 and snarling 500 Abarth. The battery-powered 500e, which is available in California and Oregon, offers range of more than 100 miles in urban driving and can reach 88 mph on the highway. Throughout the line, you choose between coupe or convertible with power-operated cloth top (500e not included) and work from a palette that includes some of the most fashion-forward hues in the automotive realm. Pop, Sport, and Lounge trims differentiate models even further. The Sport includes sixteen-inch wheels, aggressive body pieces, unique seats, and a powerful stereo. Besides these, the limited-production 1957 Edition invokes the Nuova 500 (New 500) that was a European smash hit back then. Cloaked in light blue, shod with matching dish wheels, and furnished within in brown and ivory leather, the 1957 Edition charmingly fulfills the mission of honoring its precursor. The 500 series represents so many things we love about cars: style, personality, economy, and performance. Like the Mini Cooper, it’s more expensive than, say, a Toyota Yaris, but you’re getting something extra special.

New for 2015

Seven-inch high-definition display, Bluetooth streaming audio, additional USB port, high-definition audio, six-speed automatic transmission in the Abarth.

More about the Fiat 500

Arrivederci, Fiat 500 September 18, 2013

title: 2015 Ford Edge Sport
subTitle: The mid-size crossover gets big improvements. Is it for you? Here's what we think.
promoTeaserSmall: The mid-size crossover gets big improvements. Is it for you? Here's what we think.
promoTeaser: The mid-size crossover gets big improvements. Is it for you? Here's what we think.
metaDescription: The mid-size crossover gets big improvements. Is it for you? Here's what we think.

relatedArticles.name: article0
relatedArticles.promoTeaser: How will Ford update its popular crossover? Design manager Kevin George takes us around—and inside.
relatedArticles.title: Ford Edge Concept

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive crossover utility vehicle
Base price: $38,745
This car: $46,180
Engine: Turbocharged 2.7-liter V-6, 315 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 18 mpg city/27 mpg highway (front-wheel drive); 17/24 mpg (all-wheel drive)
My favorite standard feature: Rearview camera
Options I can’t live without: Remote start
Notable standard features on this model: 20-inch aluminum alloy wheels, Sony premium audio, 8.0-inch touchscreen navigation, heated power side mirrors, rearview camera, Ford Sync services
Notable options on this model: Voice-activated navigation, blind spot monitor, lane departure warning, heated rear seats, heated and cooled front seats, power liftgate, park assist, remote starting, 180-degree front camera, HID headlamps (all in Equipment Group 401A, $3,700); panoramic moonroof ($1,595)

You might also be considering: 2015 Dodge Durango ($31,490), 2015 Jeep Grand Cherokee ($30,990), 2015 Kia Sorento LX V6 ($29,195), 2015 Nissan Murano ($30,445), 2015 Toyota Highlander ($30,945), 2015 Volkswagen Touareg V6 Sport ($45,615)

The elements of our automotive purchase priorities change like the seasons, but there’s one—styling—that’s always near the top of the charts. There are obviously other factors—safety features, critical in family vehicles such as this one; connectivity, increasingly important to younger buyers; comfort; fuel economy; dynamics.

But if the vehicle doesn’t please the eye, the prospective buyer is unlikely to bond with it enough to make that purchase. It’s fair to say that tidy good looks made the Edge a serious player among mid-size SUVs beginning with its 2006 debut. Taut, shrink-wrapped surfaces and sporty proportions suggested competence and action-readiness, and in most ways the vehicle measured up to the image.
Inevitably, though, styling success includes an implicit challenge: where did Ford go from there? How do they make it visibly new and simultaneously preserve the athletic good looks of the original?
The 2015 Edge shows improvement in any category you care to name: chassis, powertrain, engine performance, fuel economy, handling, ride quality, interior appointments....

Here’s Ford’s answer. The 2015 Edge shows improvement in pretty much any category you care to name: chassis, powertrain, engine performance, fuel economy, handling, ride quality, interior appointments, interior noise levels, electronic gizmology, safety features.
And styling? Let’s come back to that a little later.

The 2015 Edge is new from the ground up. It's bigger, with a stiffer body, revised suspension and body for a better driving experience, and a longer wheelbase. Overall, the new Edge is 3.9 inches longer, which translates into more interior room. You notice it particularly in the amount of room for second-row passengers and the added cargo space.
Ford’s nifty no-hands rear hatch has been enhanced with a second sensor, essentially allowing it to be opened by passing a foot under either side of the rear bumper.
New to the Edge is a 2.7-liter EcoBoost V-6, adapted from the Ford F-150. With 315 horsepower and 350 pound-feet of torque, it’s the hot rod of the Edge power program.

There are three engine choices. The standard engine is a 2.0-liter EcoBoost four-cylinder, reengineered for more power (245 horsepower) and refinement. There's a 280-horsepower 3.5-liter V-6, the previous standard engine and a carryover from the previous generation, and, new to the Edge, a 2.7-liter EcoBoost V-6, adapted from the Ford F-150 pickup. With 315 horsepower and 350 pound-feet of torque, it’s the hot rod of the Edge power program and is offered only in the Sport model, the one we drove.
All three engines are paired with a six-speed automatic transmission, which includes paddle shifters. All-wheel drive is available across the board: add $1,995.

On the road, the Edge is a gratifying blend of comfort, competence, and agility, particularly in the Sport, with its firmer suspension tuning. The new steering system is a marked improvement over the previous setup, adding tactility and accuracy to the driving experience. And the added power of the 2.7 EcoBoost V-6 certainly makes the Sport version more entertaining to drive, but even the basic 2.0 turbo delivers adequate thrust.
And in addition to improved dynamics, the roomier interior is remarkably quiet at all speeds.

Like every new vehicle rolling out today, the interior of the new Edge improves in terms of material quality and tech features. There’s an impressive array of standard features in the basic SE (from $28,995)—rearview camera, respectable audio, cruise control, tilting and telescoping steering column, paddle shifters, eight airbags, active grille shutters (keeps coolant at optimum temp), torque vectoring, and eighteen-inch aluminum alloy wheels, to hit some of the highlights. And of course, feature content increase as the trim levels advance through SEL (from $32,395), Titanium (from $36,495), and, at the top of the charts, the Sport (from $38,995).
Ford has held the line on SE pricing, but the other trim levels represent hikes—$200 for the SEL, $500 each for Titanium and Sport.

The Verdict:

Based on our brief initial hands-on, there is little to criticize about Ford’s new Edge. Styling? We all make up our own minds about this, but this new-generation Edge looks distinctly bigger, and not in an entirely good way. There’s more front overhang, and the new creases added to the sides and hood may lend a more contemporary look, but the changes have diluted the Edge’s athleticism in the process.

It was also a little disappointing to find the current MyFord Touch system is still in place, despite its unhappy track record, although it’s been modified with a row of buttons replacing the capacitative touch control. A new Sync 3 system will be in place for model year 2016, but it can’t be retrofitted to the 2015 model. If this is an essential item on your shopping list, you might want to think about waiting until the new one makes its debut.

Otherwise, the new Edge is a very appealing package. New tech features, such as park assist and inflatable seatbelts. More interior volume. Quiet operation. A comfortable, handsomely appointed interior. An extensive array of safety features, standard and optional.
But its strongest suit is dynamics. If you’re shopping in this mid-size SUV market, and you like to drive, you owe yourself some seat time in this one.

title: 2015 Toyota 4Runner
subTitle: The rough-and-tumble tradition continues.
promoTeaserSmall: The rough-and-tumble tradition continues.
promoTeaser: The rough-and-tumble tradition continues.
metaDescription: The rough-and-tumble tradition continues. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-to-seven-passenger, rear- or all-wheel-drive sport-utility vehicle
Price range: $34,095–$44,505 (includes destination)
Trim levels: SR5, Trail, TRD Pro, Limited
Engine: 4.0-liter V-6, 270 horsepower
Transmission: Five-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 4x2: 17 mpg city/22 mpg highway; 4x4: 17/21 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: 4 Good and 1 Marginal rating; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 4/5 stars
Our favorite standard feature: Windshield wiper de-icer
Notable standard features on this model: Skidplates for the engine, fuel tank, and transfer case.
Notable options on this model: Entune multimedia system
You might also be considering: Jeep Wrangler, Lexus GX460, Nissan Pathfinder

The 4Runner—redesigned for the 2014 model year—is one of a dwindling number of sport-utilities on the market that still has truck-based underpinnings. It can be had in four different trims—SR5, Trail, Limited, and TRD Pro— and all are powered by a trail-worthy V-6 engine and mated to a five-speed automatic transmission. The 4Runner’s exterior has been refined over the years, but it maintains a tough look. The cabin combines rugged, squared-off styling cues with more refined touches like contrast stitching on the doors. All 4Runner models now come standard with Toyota’s Entune mulitmedia system that includes satellite radio, iPod connectivity, and Bluetooth, and on Limited models, access to mobile apps and data services. Old friends of 4Runners gone by will be happy to see the base SR5 comes with fog lights, skidplates, roof rails, and other off-road-ready gear. The 4Runner’s hatch can hold 47.2 cubic feet of cargo and up to 89.7 cubic feet with the rear seats folded. Go ahead and spring for the more versatile 4x4, since the added pounds have only a marginal effect on fuel economy. If you often carry multiple passengers, consider the optional third row that increases the 4Runner’s seating capacity to seven. Then load up the gang and head out for uncharted territory.

New for 2015

The TRD Pro edition that includes trail-rated front springs, high-performance shocks, a front skidplate, and unique exterior bits.

Trim levels: LE, LE Plus, XLE, Limited, Limited Platinum
Engines: 2.7-liter four-cylinder, 185 horsepower; 3.5-liter V-6, 270 horsepower; 3.5-liter V-6/electric hybrid, 231 horsepower
Transmissions: Six-speed automatic, continuously variable automatic
Fuel economy: four-cylinder: 20 mpg city/25 mpg highway; V-6, FWD: 19/25 mpg; V-6 AWD: 18/24 mpg; Hybrid: 27/28 mpg
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick Plus; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 stars

Notable standard features on this model: Third row brings seat count to eight
Notable options on this model: Second-row captain’s chairs
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Traverse, Ford Explorer, Nissan Pathfinder

In 2014, the Highlander emerged all new with a more rugged exterior and a more refined interior. To simplify the Highlander model line—and presumably to also reduce production costs—Toyota offers no options on its first two trim levels. Instead the LE comes with nice standards like eighteen-inch alloy wheels, touchscreen display, third-row seating and more. Next up is the LE Plus that adds on conveniences like a power liftgate, three-zone climate control, and an eight-way power driver’s seat that includes lumbar support. If you want a moonroof, you’ll have to move up to the XLE, Limited, or Limited Platinum. There are two Limited packages available on both the standard and hybrid Highlanders. Depending on which package you choose, tech helpers like blind spot monitoring with cross traffic alert, a rear parking sensor, pre-collision system, and emergency assistance are available, some as options. The base four-cylinder does its best to get the family around town, but for a zippier feel or for towing the maximum 5,000 pounds, you’ll want the V-6 or hybrid models. Fuel economy is reasonable considering the Highlander's size.

New for 2015

An integrated shelf that runs along the bottom of the dash ideal for storing electronics.

Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 266 horsepower
Transmission: 6-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): FWD: 18/25; AWD: 16/23 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: Top Safety Pick plus; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: 5/5 overall rating
Our favorite standard feature: Side curtain air bags for all rows
Notable standard features on this model: Backup camera
Notable options on this model: The Driver Easy Speak options that projects the driver’s voice throughout the vehicle using the vehicle’s speakers.
You might also be considering: Dodge Grand Caravan, Honda Odyssey, Nissan Quest

While a lot of manufacturers are giving up on the minivan, Toyota keeps improving its Sienna for those who need the versatility only a minivan can provide. The 2015 exterior refresh includes slimmer headlights and sharper front grille. Inside, Sienna veterans will appreciate the new more cohesive dash design. Gone is the asymmetrical swoop in the dash to make way for a thoughtful, driver-oriented center panel that facilitates efficient use of the various controls like the three-zone climate system and displays for multi-media and navigation. Several trims are available beginning with the base L starting at just over $30,000, and climaxing with the Limited trim that will put you well over $40,000. All-wheel drive is available on several models, LE, XLE and Limited, and those with more sporting aspirations will gravitate toward the SE trim and its sport-tuned suspension and more aggressive exterior accents. With the second-row bench and the third row upright, the Sienna can carry eight passengers. If you choose the second-row captain’s chairs, that number is reduced to seven. Should those passengers get out of hand, you have a new ally in the ground-breaking Driver Easy Speak option. It broadcasts your voice—without having to shout—through the vehicle’s speaker system, “Attention, this is your mother speaking. Return the juice boxes to the cupholders!” Who says minivans aren’t cool?

New for 2015

The Driver Easy Speak system is so brilliant it bears mentioning again.

title: 2016 Hyundai Tucson
subTitle: Compact SUV ups the ante in safety, infotainment, connectivity, even size.
promoTeaserSmall: Compact SUV ups the ante in safety, infotainment, connectivity, even size.
promoTeaser: Compact SUV ups the ante in safety, infotainment, connectivity, even size.
metaDescription: Compact SUV ups the ante in safety, infotainment, connectivity, even size.

pageElements.text:
Type: Front- and all-wheel-drive compact sport-utility vehicle
On-sale date: July 2015
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 164 horsepower (SE); turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder, 175 horsepower (Eco, Sport, Limited)
Transmission: Six-speed automatic (SE), seven-speed dual-clutch automatic (Eco, Sport, Limited)
Most interesting feature: Automatic emergency braking with pedestrian detection (optional)
Potential competitors: Buick Encore, GMC Terrain, Ford Escape, Honda CR-V, Mazda CX-5, Nissan Rogue, Toyota RAV4

The Hyundai Tucson is the smallest member of Hyundai’s crossover/SUV trio—8.5 inches shorter than the Santa Fe Sport—but it’s undergone a growth spurt, and smallest doesn’t mean small. Due in showrooms this July, the Tucson’s make-over adds 1.2 inches to its wheelbase, 3.0 inches to overall length, and 1.1 inches to width.

As you’d expect, this adds to cargo capacity—five more cubic feet behind the second row of seats—and of course more stretch-out legroom for rear-seat passengers. Unlike some compact crossovers, the Tucson can comfortably accommodate two large adults in the outboard rear seating positions. But like others in this size class, the center seat probably won’t make anyone very happy.

There’s a much stiffer structure under the new skin—48 percent stiffer, according to Hyundai—as well as a new engine/transmission option: a turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder (175 horsepower and 195 pound-feet of torque) channeling power to the wheels via a seven-speed dual-clutch transmission.

This same combo is employed in the Hyundai Sonata and in the 2016 Kia Optima sedan. In the Tucson Sport and Limited, the EPA projects fuel economy of 25 mpg city, 30 highway with front-wheel drive, 24/28 with all-wheel drive.

The standard engine is a 2.0-liter four-cylinder, rated for 164 horsepower and 161 pound-feet of torque, and paired with a six-speed automatic transmission. EPA ratings are 23/31 FWD, 22/26 AWD, modest highway increases versus the current Tucson.

On the all-wheel-drive Tucson is a feature Hyundai calls Active Cornering Control. Similar to a number of stability control functions, the Hyundai system applies braking to one of the rear wheels to keep the Tucson on the correct cornering path.

Key design distinctions between the current Tucson and the new generation are a new hexagonal grille, projector beam headlamps (LED lights optional), forward-raked wheel arches, 19-inch aluminum alloy wheels, and a longer hood, thanks to windshield pillar relocation.

And as you’d expect of any new vehicle today, the 2016 Tucson ups the ante in terms of infotainment, connectivity, and passive safety features. Pricing for the new Tucson won’t be revealed until show time in the showrooms. The 2015 lineup starts at just over $22,500 and tops out at just under $29,000.

title: 2016 Infiniti QX50
subTitle: A mild appearance change, and the welcome addition of space to the compact crossover.
promoTeaserSmall: A mild appearance change, and the welcome addition of space to the compact crossover.
promoTeaser: A mild appearance change, and the welcome addition of space to the compact crossover.
metaDescription: A mild appearance change, and the welcome addition of space to the compact crossover.

pageElements.text:
Type:Rear- and all-wheel-drive compact crossover
On-sale date: Fall 2015
Engine: 3.7-liter V-6, 325 horsepower
Transmission: Seven-speed automatic
Most interesting feature: Addition of LED daytime running lights and fog lights
Potential competitors: Audi Q5, BMW X3, Porsche Macan, Volvo XC60

The Nissan luxury brand has renamed its whole lineup with Q names. (This compact crossover used to be called the EX.) Along with the new name, the 2016 QX50 receives a modern front end with LED daytime running lights and fog lights incorporated into the fascia, plus the same split mesh grille design you’ll see on other products in the lineup, like the Q50 sedan.

The wheelbase is 2.3 inches longer, adding interior space, especially for rear-seat passengers, but also with more cargo space in the back. That's a welcome change for this smallest of Infiniti crossovers. The engine remains the same: a 3.7-liter V-6 making 325 horsepower. Both rear- and all-wheel-drive versions are available, with standard leather interior and optional 360-degree camera and power-folding rear seats.
Pricing has not yet been announced, but the current model starts in the high $30,000s. The QX50 crossover will hit dealerships in the fall.

title: 2016 Chevrolet Spark
subTitle: The minicar gains horsepower and looks.
promoTeaserSmall: The minicar gains horsepower and looks.
promoTeaser: The minicar gains horsepower and looks.
metaDescription: The minicar gains horsepower and looks.

pageElements.text:
Type: Front-wheel-drive hatchback
On-sale date: Fall 2015
Engine: 1.4-liter four-cylinder, 98 horsepower
Transmission: Five-speed manual or continuously variable automatic
Most interesting feature: Forward collision alert, lane departure warning, and side blind spot alert all available as options
Potential competitors: Fiat 500, Kia Soul, Nissan Versa Note, Scion iQ

The Chevrolet Spark is maturing, and for those shopping for really, really small cars, that's a good thing. This fall, you'll be able to shop for the all-new version of this cute minicar, now with very nearly 100 horsepower and a slightly longer wheelbase. It also has a lower profile, losing 1.6 inches in overall height, which means a less boxy silhouette.

Yes, it's a cheap little car. No, it's not monastic inside. It's got Chevrolet's MyLink infotainment with a seven-inch touchscreen. As an option, you can get OnStar with 4G LTE and GM's built-in Wi-Fi hot spot.

A rearview camera is standard on all models. Even more impressive, you can get forward collision alert, lane departure warning, park assist, and side blind spot alert technology. The 2015 model was already an Insurance Institute for Highway Safety Top Safety Pick, and this one should be, too. That's a great selling point for someone looking to buy a car this small.

Chevrolet is looking to pick up sales in the youth market with all that technology, and there's reason for optimism, considering more than a million people have bought the Chevrolet Spark worldwide since it first came out in 2010.

title: 2016 Smart ForTwo
subTitle: Small wonder gets a bit bigger and a bit nicer.
promoTeaserSmall: Small wonder gets a bit bigger and a bit nicer.
promoTeaser: Small wonder gets a bit bigger and a bit nicer.
metaDescription: Small wonder gets a bit bigger and a bit nicer.

pageElements.text:
Type: Two-passenger, front-wheel-drive minicompact coupe or cabriolet
Price range: $15,400 – $19,230 (prices include destination charge)
Trim levels: Pure, Passion, Prime, Proxy
Engine: Turbocharged 0.8-liter three-cylinder, 89 horsepower
Transmission: Five-speed manual, six-speed dual-clutch automatic
Fuel economy: 34 mpg city/39 mpg highway (manual), 32/39 mpg (automatic), 107 MPGe (electric)
Safety ratings: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA): Not yet rated (Smart Electric Drive: 4/5 stars); Insurance Institute for Highway Safety (IIHS): Not yet rated
Notable standard features: LED daytime running lights, Bluetooth connectivity, twin-section tailgate
Notable options: Panoramic roof (top trim levels): sport package ($600) with three-spoke steering wheel, shift paddles, chrome-tipped exhaust, and lowered suspension; eight-speaker JBL audio system ($490)
You might also be considering: Chevrolet Spark, Fiat 500, Ford Fiesta, Honda Fit, Nissan Versa Note, Toyota Prius c, Toyota Yaris

This is the least likely Mercedes-Benz you will ever see, but it is indeed a member of the family. The Smart ForTwo, just redone for 2016, benefits from the safety and quality commitment of its iconic parent company. Even though it is a minuscule two-seater, in its new version it is 3.9 inches wider, giving you (and your sole passenger) just that extra skosh more personal space. The vaunted tridion safety cell that makes the ForTwo crush resistant has been joined by standard crosswind assist and eight air bags, and now there's also optional forward collision warning. A five-speed manual transmission is standard and a six-speed twin-clutch automatic transmission optional, with either of which you'll get 39 mpg on the highway. If you move to the Electric Drive ForTwo, you'll get 107 MPGe, one very good reason to consider that choice. Smart markets these as leased cars at $139 per month for the coupe and $199 per month for the cabriolet with a three-year lease term.

A car like the ForTwo is for a very special niche: city people who aren't afraid to look and drive a little different. The 8.8-foot-long car with its awesome 22.8-foot turning radius has clear advantages in city traffic and parking situations. The fuel economy is not astoundingly great considering the diminutive size, if that's all you care about. Chances are you will be just as interested in making a bit of a lifestyle statement as a financial decision, if you're interested in a ForTwo.
New for 2016: The ForTwo is all new for 2016.

More to Read:

Smart Electric City Tour

images.caption: Smart CEO Dr. Annette Winkler introduced the 2016 ForTwo at the New York Auto Show this spring.

title: 2015 Kia Cadenza
subTitle: Near luxury, far cries of satisfaction.
promoTeaserSmall: Near luxury, far cries of satisfaction.
promoTeaser: Near luxury, far cries of satisfaction.
metaDescription: Near luxury, far cries of satisfaction. JeanKnowsCars.com

pageElements.text:
Type: Sedan
Price range: $35,725–$44,625 (includes destination)
Trim levels: Premium, Limited
Engine: 3.3-liter V-6, 293 horsepower
Transmission: 6-speed automatic
Fuel economy (mpg): 19/28 (city/highway)
Safety ratings: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety: good overall; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration: not rated
Our favorite standard feature: 10-way adjustable driver’s seat
Notable standard features on this model: Leather-wrapped steering wheel, perimeter approach lighting, 8-inch navigation screen
Notable options on this model: Technology package, luxury package, sunroof, HID headlamps with “dynamic bending light,” heated rear outboard seats
You might also be considering: Buick LaCrosse, Ford Taurus, Chevrolet Impala

If not for the 293-horsepower V-6 and standard paddle shifters for manual control of the six-speed automatic transmission, we would say the Kia Cadenza is a purely sensible car, a nice value for the prudent consumer. But the direct-injection engine is potent, and those paddle shifters are pretty sporty. While you’re not falling too far behind the more renowned sport sedans on the road, you’ll be smiling about all the standard equipment at your fingertips. With a 10-way power-adjustable heated leather driver’s seat and seven-inch driver information display, the Cadenza Premium is well stocked with creature comforts.

A host of driver assistance and safety systems are standard, and a seven-inch TFT display and a heated steering wheel are optional. The Cadenza Limited adopts those features as standard and adds all sorts of additional niceties, from timekeeping (an exclusive analog clock) and interior lighting to additional driver-assistance features like lane keeping, blind-spot detection, and smart cruise control. The Limited also includes ventilated front seats and heated outboard rear seats with Nappa leather trim. The steering wheel’s position is power-adjustable as well. It’s hard to find fault with the Cadenza. The interior is huge, yet the car has a reasonable footprint and looks quite sleek and smart, if somewhat anonymous. What it lacks is razzle-dazzle, the glossy reputation of a BMW, but for some folks, that’s just fine.

New for 2015

Front grille, surround view monitor, panoramic sunroof, eight-way power front passenger seat, available rear cross-traffic alert and other driver assistance features.
